The designers insist on game design decisions based on a game ideal they have in their head, the result is a severely toxic environment where you either like PvP and sabotaging others or you're punished for not liking it. MMO's 20 years ago figured out how and why this approach doesn't work and only benefits the most aggressive and oppressive part of the community, yet as with every other aspect of the game that's needed changing over the years, the devs believe they know better. Adding PvE servers wouldn't result in dead servers as some defenders would imply, it'd give a space for people that otherwise just wouldn't play, and a more positive experience for those who are starved enough for a decent piracy game made in the last 10 years to get into a PvP environment despite not having any interest in the PvP content. If you force PvE players into PvP all you're doing is giving easy pickings to people who like PvP, it's not engaging for the PvPer, doesn't test their skills and it's a negative experience for the PvE player. The only reason a PvP player would want PvE players in their very limited servers is to bully people, or an alternative option if they're too unskilled to engage with anyone actually interested in PvP. It benefits only the least admirable part of the community and I don't understand why the slur spewing toxic part of the community needs a leg up. Why do PvE players have to pay the price for the enjoyment of a volatile subsection of PvP players? It's a bizarre choice when on the other hand they'll censor words as benign as "hangman". Brief side mention that the game is designed to be aggressive to solo players, the only way to really play on your own is to be avoidant or prey on other solo players, anything else and you are violently outclassed by design.

That aside the game has been out for years yet still has routine bugs that go from obnoxious to game breaking, be it crashing, old accounts having consistently more issues so loyal early adopters are punished for believing in the team, textures refusing to load at all, flying ships, unkillable krakens, texture breaking in story mode, physics launching your ship into the sky for parking too close to a dock, and more I'm sure I forgot. The monetization is cosmetic but as there's hardly any goal in game beyond cosmetics you can say that short of pay to win the game is 100% monetized and aggressively so, enjoy paying between 15-20 bucks for one decent ship design, which isn't impossible to get ingame but it relies on waiting on islands for hours to have a chance at getting the equivalent of maybe a dollar's worth of premium currency IF you catch it in time.

This is a game that has solely survived on the hopes and dreams of millions desperate for a good game about piracy which as a theme have ironically been a desert, with the rare oasis and no consistency in genre.
A hole they fill marginally for the time, though with luck not for much longer. If you have 3 friends that show up consistently you might circumvent a lot of the cruelty designed into the game levelled at PvE and especially solo players, otherwise avoid this game. 134779287.review:
I recommend this game to a specific niche of folks out there looking for a particular experience, hence the "not recommended" selection.  The biggest thing to know about this game is the kind of experience that awaits you.

Sea of Thieves is a beautiful open sandbox PvP game.  The game is in no way a PvE adventure with a little PvP.  It perhaps sounds funny to point this out, but most of the marketing surrounding the game promotes added PvE features and mostly overlooks the sandbox PvP elements that make up the core of this game.  One can be romanticized with a sea of treasure-filled adventure and forget that over the horizon there are always other crews out there itching for a fight.

There's an old saying on the Sea of Thieves:  your loot is not yours until you turn it in.  This really best defines how one should measure their expectations within Sea of Thieves.  Loot only grants access to better cosmetics for the most part, so truly any pleasure you get from this game should be measured from the experiences you create rather than how much gold you earn.  Temper your expectations that this is a PvP game and that you will lose often at the start.

The open-ended PvP nature of this game can be a collection of memorable joys as well as crushing experiences.  That's really this games greatest strength:  the ability to create stories.  Both victories or losses can create tales to be shared unlike many other games out there today.  However, there are two big flaws to the game that compelled me to put it to rest personally.

The first is how the game is a poor teacher.  What do I mean by that?  Well, in Sea of Thieves its clunky combat and ship maneuvering is easy to learn but very difficult to master.  There's a lot of mechanics at work when it comes sailing, cannoning, ship boarding, and grenade throwing.  If you die and sink it can take up to ten minutes to sail back and try and meet your opponent again.   However, by the time you get there they may be long gone or the scenario can be completely different.  Ultimately, this can make it very difficult to practice or learn from your mistakes.  Depending on your skill level this means it can take dozens if not hundreds of hours of game play to get a decent grasp of the game.  This includes watching helpful guides on youtube.

The second flaw is the potential "toxicity" you can run into within the game.  More often than not you will run into mean spirited folk whose behavior goes beyond sportsmanlike.  It can be a real drag at times.  It's a sad reality within a game that conveys its setting as so bright and cheerful, but it is what it is.

In summary, who is this game for?  If you love PvP and the idea of an open sandbox PvP game:  this can be for you.  You will need patience, a willingness to learn from others, and a tough skin.  No one outside of your own crew can be trusted.  You will lose and you will lose often, but then eventually you will start achieving what you seek.  All in all:  make good stories along the way with your experiences.  Be a good sport when you win.  Be a great sport when you lose.   You might embrace a game that's quite special.

I've put down my pirate hat for now, but maybe down the road I'll pick it up again and hope for some high adventure on the seas.

140487178.review:
[h1]The Storymaker[/h1]

Who would have thought that a game covered mainly in water would be such a good sandbox?

	Sea of Thieves is the ultimate storymaker. First, it tells a story of a game released to a mixed  reception, lacking in content but having this one very important ingredient – the solid foundation. Rare – the game's developers seized the opportunity and kept working on their title delivering the sandbox experience only a few other titles could match.

	Current day Sea of Thieves is overflowing with content, opening multiple different ways for players to have fun within the game. Light-hearted artstyle, solid graphics and great soundtrack enforce the pirate fantasy and the feeling of wonderous exploration.

	This is a PvEvP title. It's designed with some tedium in mind. Players have to manually carry and sell their treasures. All of that is done on purpose as it makes players susceptible to other crews attacks. Naval battles require skill as there is no power progression within the game. For this reason some players might be deterred from the title. Loosing your hard earned loot feels infuriating at times but it sneakily hooks player into the gameplay loop. For each stressful extraction, naval battle, ship chase the feeling of finally winning against other crews and then finally being able to sell everything you managed to plunder feels addictively satisfying.

	In Sea of Thieves no two runs are the same. The ingenious design of this title creates a perfect sandbox with tons of activities and then throws players into the mix. This is the Ultimate Storymaker as it creates the best, most memorable stories in gaming.

	I strongly recommend this game.

If you are interested in a full video review then check out my youtube channel: https://youtu.be/1f5sGPT5AxM

137142546.review:
I've played so much of this game. I remember the first moment of getting on a ship alone and sailing out. I didn't know what I was doing, and it was exhilarating. Sailing from island to island and doing the various quests is fun, and even just the sailing mechanics themselves and how they inspire a crew to work together (well... if you're solo on a sloop as I am the majority of the time). Tall Tales—though apparently not many people actually do them—provide a more curated experience. I think they're a bit obtuse sometimes and have to look up what to do, but they can be fun. The graphics are stunning, the amount there is to do in this game is wild, and the lore is deep.

------------------------------------

That said, I do not recommend this game. Far and away the things I remember the most about this game are when I've spent hours sailing from island to island trying to level up my emissary flag only to have a random brig come by while I'm not looking and sink me. Suddenly, all of my effort and real-life time have been wasted. Well, let me correct that. Not wasted. I gained a terrible experience. A casual solo sail thru the seas comes crashing to a halt and is replaced with loss, disappointment, and a reminder that people can be cruel and petty for no other reason than to achieve their own personal gain, with little to no regard for what that means to someone else.

I understand that PvP is part of the appeal of the game to some, but I do not believe that this game should cater only to that. I believe that there should be PvE-only options. A way to know that if I want to pick up the game for a casual time doing some treasure hunts, I can do that without having to constantly be anxious that someone's going to come ruin my day. The fact that the biggest reward in this game is, "I'm so happy no one came by and took my treasure," is not good. In motivational theory, personal satisfaction, and game design avoiding a bad outcome as your main motivator is not the only, or the healthiest, option.

What's more, while the community isn't inherently toxic, if you even think about speaking negatively about PvP, people say "well, just stop playing the game, then!" shaming you for wanting to not play PvP (this has personally happened to me). Even the devs have posted in the Steam discussion boards that their stance is definitive on this, they will not accommodate PvE only. If you even post about it in the threads, they say that they will moderate closely, remove those posts, and take action against repeat "offenders." It's disheartening, to me, that people can take such an exclusionary view on the world. The only way to do something is the way they want. If other people don't like it, too bad. Conversation over.

There are ways to implement PvP-only servers that do not detract from the existing PvPvE. It's like when Fortnite introduced permanent No-Build. It didn't stop people from being able to play the way they always loved, but it also opened up the door for so many other people to play a game which they wouldn't otherwise because of the prohibitive nature of its core gameplay. I find that a developer to say they will punish anyone for expressing a differing way they'd prefer to enjoy the game to be shameful and... actually as I say it, it's perfectly in line with their decision to encourage those negative interpersonal interactions in-game. That actually makes sense now.

I am currently playing through the Tall Tales with my brother (and god willing we do so without having to waste the 2 hours we have to play together each week by someone coming and sinking us), but once we have finished those, I will no longer play Sea of Thieves. I will actively be recommending people do not play it. I think a game that is designed specifically and singularly to encourage selfishness and a zero-sum play style—while the devs actively censor conversation around a PvE-only option to allow people who prefer other play styles enjoy their game—is not a game worth giving my time and energy to.

------------------------------------

tl;dr - game could be and is fun, but the developer's decision to not accommodate players who wish to have a casual, cooperative-only experience makes me not want to play this game. I play games to escape reality, not to be victim to other gamers on an anonymous power fantasy trying to succeed at the expense of others.

126464154.review:
This game is the best 'Pirate' game I've ever played! Lots & lots of Arrrr's, loot, gold, swashbuckling, battles, boats, swords, guns, cannons firing, and mayhem! But also sea shanties, grog drinking, relaxing & fishing, sailing, swimming, treasure finding, riddles, and so much more fun to be had! 
It will invoke many memories for you of all the real and fantasy pirate stories out there, including the 'Pirates Of The Caribbean' movie franchise, which are also included with a 'tall tale' story in this game. So you can go on and..."bring me that horizon"! ;)
SoT is a truly excellent game for getting together online with friends & family and having an awesome time! Or just going out solo all alone (nicknamed "hard mode", but possibly the best way to learn faster). I would also recommend watching "Phuzzybond" guides and others on YouTube to learn faster the ways to success in this very unique game world.

A Warning though, as I said, this game is very different from many others but in a good way...for pirates. For example, there is no safe zone in-game, you can be attacked (or meet new friends) at any time, and spawn killing is almost required sometimes...so don't take it personally if it's done to you. In this game, sometimes to sink a ship in battle you may have to board it and suppress (kill) the crew until you have looted or sunk the vessel. That means that you might have to do some spawn killing yourself sometimes or endure it. If you're not prepared for these game differences it can lead to getting a sour taste in the mouth for some new players.

Remember these beginner points to help:
- You own nothing until you cash it in, until then anyone can and may try to steal it from you and cash it in themselves! 
- You owe no one nothing! In other words, no one owes you a fight and you don't owe anyone else a fight...it's all up to you and not the other players what you decide to do (like say run, chase, fight, negotiate over mic). 
- This is a "PVPVE" game, not 'PvP' or 'PvE' but both, crashing together at any given time! These are not "bad" things if you expect them, in fact they make the game fun most of the time! It provides an element of danger & risk, paranoia, and excitement...not knowing if another boat might show up while you're selling your loot or doing whatever your up too. It makes you watch the horizon all the time, which is the developers intention. It's not supposed to be constant chaos or dead quiet but instead something 'unpredictable', and then when you've sold your loot successfully you'll get that warm feeling of accomplishment that doesn't come without the possibility of a challenge.
- Never trust a pirate! They're not bad people at all, tons of fun actually...but they are "Pirates", so never forget that. (Remember you're one too, maybe you'll be the one doing all the tricking?)

As of Season 8, there is even more than ever added into the game, and a new way to get fast PvP action if you want it. This is a great addition to SoT, as it makes it less likely PvE players will run into PvP diehards, but PvPers have a way to get their PvP fix faster too! Plus, it encourages and rewards PvE players for trying out some PvP without feeling forced or unready for it.

I could go on and on, there is so much more in this game that I haven't even mentioned yet, layers and layers to keep you busy for a long time! Plus, amazingly everyone is 'balanced and even' in this game! What I mean by that is, you can buy new paint-jobs and skins for your hull, cannons and ship wheels, new looks for your sword or guns, new clothing and costumes for your pirate character...but nothing changes the stats. All weapons and looks have no bonuses or stat changes. There is no "pay to win" going on here. So, a new player technically fires the same weapons that a long time veteran does, no advantages or disadvantages just skill level, practice, and luck....lots and lots of luck in this game! ;)

It's "your world" in SoT, so do whatever "you" like doing in it. Remember though, it's also the other pirates world too...and "you" are there in it! These things can collide, for better or worse, but that's what makes for amazing stories, unpredictable adventures, and maybe if you're lucky some new friends too! If you understand what you're getting into, it is such a truly amazing and rewarding game! Nothing else really like it. Try not to let any losses bring you down.

I honestly can't wait to see you all out there on the seas, 'Wind In Your Sails' my new pirate friends!

Most players haven't completed or even attempted any of the in-game events in fear of getting ganked by Reaper's; to which some would claim is an imperative feature for the events. I'm sure I'll sound like a broken record compared to other negative review's on this page, but I'd say keep your PvP mechanics the way they are, just give players the option to opt out.. 123513874.review:
Not worth playing unless you have friends or know people to crew with. Even then, take caution. The game is really, really fun, except for interacting with other players. The problem is twofold:

First, PvP. Unless you play a story adventure (which does not give you loot) you are inevitably going to fall victim to somebody who spends most of their hours sadistically sinking other players ships. Unless you're experienced in PvP, you're probably not going to be able to do much about this. All of the risk lies on you. It costs nothing for others to go out and attack another player and steal their loot. You will spend a couple hours doing voyages for an emissary and end up with nothing to show for it. But there's no logic to dictate what other people will do either. It would make sense to expect to be hunted when you have a large haul of treasure. I've also heard from people that just like a good ship fight. But that won't explain the other cases where you can be solo sailing and get ganked at your first stop when you're just collecting supplies. That's the type of interaction I mean when I say sadistic.

Second, matchmaking is really bad. There's no preferences, so you will just join random players, usually a new crew, and most of the time they will not communicate at all. It's an oddly common occurrence to join a crew where a silent player will decide to GO and set sail into a rock. Sometimes I do find players who communicate, use voice chat even, but many times they are only interested in PvP. It's hard to sail a ship without communication or a common goal, which is why it's better to at least play with people you know or play solo.

This is a really fun game, and it's only been getting better... but there's a severe barrier to entry and it's very discouraging to play when I end up wasting hours trying to find a crew or otherwise get sunk trying to play solo. PvPers just have too much power and too little risk.

136212588.review: This game has become one of my favorite games.

126506033.review:
Here are some of the things that are so annoying in the game.

Interface, ingame notifications come up for any small event, sometimes they're unnecessary, like when a cannon ball just hit you in the face, do I really need the game to lmk? This wouldn't be bad if the message box didn't cover very important parts of the screen, like the bottom where I need to check if a gun is loaded or not. most time in battle you get 10s of these useless reminders that won't allow you to play properly.


The game is unplayable without a crew of 4 friends because of it's PvP restrictive gameplay mechanics. Within my first playthrough (playing solo as non of my friends wanted to pay that price for a multiplayer only game, an attitude I wished I had after trying it out), I was attacked twice just as I spawned in the map, another two times inside an outpost/pirate harbour, and one time by a Kraken, again, just as I spawned in, and while playing ALONE. 


Solo and Duo players also get an additional disadvantage for how much they can carry and supply; since every player's inventory is limited, it takes solo players 20-30 minutes after each ship respawn to resupply. 

What makes this worse for solo/duo and new players, is that there is no sense of player matching, no player levels, no player ranking, not even matching the types of ships in the same server (out of 10s of times I was attacked, it was almost always tier 3 (4 player) ship. Only one ship was tier 1, and it had a crew of 2).

Another point, why is attacking in outposts allowed anyway? can't you make just one safe harbour in the entire map?! this doesn't make sense at all and makes the game very prohibitive for new players. It doesn't make sense neither for realism or gameplay.

what makes this even worse, is that in some battles, there is no flee option. Someone can force your hand into battle, and if you flee, your ship automatically sinks and you lose. so what are solo or duo players supposed to do when they are outgunned and outnumbered?! even worse, when they're anchored to sell their treasure boxes and getting new quests?!

Another element that doesn't make sense (in a pirating game) is that there is no point in boarding or stealing ships; since every crew's spawning point is their ship, if you steal a ship while the crew is away, or sneak and eliminate it's crew, they'd respawn within seconds on the same ship. not to mention that sword and gun play is very basic and clunky. So, looks like zero thought had been put into making it interesting to do anything other than sinking ships with cannons, esp if you had a bigger ship. They forced PvP into the game so much that much of the potential is lost; what's the point of adding musical instruments, pirate inns, treasure hunting, hunting and fishing....etc. when everything you spend hours on can be undone with a bunch of teen bullies who force the game into a dick competition by just roaming around sinking everyone.


It's not complicated to design a game with more thought on tactics and gameplay. Older games like AC4 Black Flag (which had PvP) and even the almost 20-year old Sid Meier's Pirates had gameplay mechanics that allowed you to out-manoeuvre a Man-o-War with a sloop or brigantine or use tactics to reduce a larger ship's crew before boarding...etc.

Basically, if you want to enjoy this and have fun winning and losing, you need a crew of 4, and play for the sole purpose of sinking other ships. EXCEPT, there was a game that did this better; BLACKWAKE from 2020, it allowed crews up to 13 plrs, had larger ships, had more ship types, boarding and sword play was way more fun. The only drawback is it lost its player base after a peak during covid lockdowns.

That being said, the sailing is quite fun, hits a balance between realistic ship sailing and game, and ship mechanics and physics are very good too. sometimes if felt good just to look after the ship after a storm/battle, or sail aimlessly in the ocean. Again, most game elements are lost to the toxic player base and toxic PvP, you cannot actually enjoy fishing, hunting, instruments, or sailing/exploring.

134875483.review:
Add about 200 more hours to what steams shows and you get my true playtime.

So how was my experiance? It's very much mixed, but the good parts only happened when played with a crew of 3 or 4 friends. Playing with just one friend was fun-fun-absolute dissapointment.
Why is that?
Well, for starters, there are A LOT of toxic as all hell PvPers. And as they usually play in duos, they are reluctant to attack 4 player ships. About half of my 2 player adventures ended because of that, and usually not because we couldn't fend them off, but because those people are horrible and you have no way of avoiding them. They don't care about your treasures, they don't care about picking up loot, all they care about is attacking you. They will keep respawning and comming after you, making even finishing game session really hard - you'd like to sell your stuff, right? too bad! you have to kill some trash PvPers 2 times to do that. All you can do to avoid them is scuttle ship and start over on new server.
Oh, and they will ususally also insult you on the voice chat.
Yes, you can mute them, but for that you'll probably need to hear them first. Or you can just turn off the chat entirely, but that kind of defeats the point of social aspect of the game.

There's a lot of mechanics that suggest you should be socialising with other crews, but in fact, you're NOT presented with any opportunity to do so. Letting random ships get close without bombarding them with cannon fire is straight up suicidal, and at that point any chance of peaceful talks and drinking grog together is lost.

Let's say, you want to finish your game session. So go to outpost, sell the loot, log off. Too bad! Someone is at the port, and you have to either get through them (which can be lenghty endeavor, or fast one that will make you feel like an absolute ass, as they probably just wanted to log off in peace as well, if you could sneak up on them and sink their ship). Or go to another outpost, which can easily take 15 minutes. And of course, it's also not a sure thing to work.

Also, do you dare go to the toilet? It's when most disasters struck. Mr. Murphy was right. And it's a big issue in a game where you want to have lengthy sessions.

Three of the above issues I have with the game coulld be easily solved by making outposts PvP free zones, so the players can interact with each other and finish the game or just take a breather. (I'm assuming they didn't implement that, as that was the case when I've last played, and the general direction and design philosophy developers took),

Few more issues:
- having someone as a sentry is critical - so in two player crews, one gets to have fun, while the other keeps the watch. Boring. Or you just inevitably get ambushed and loose all your accumulated stuff, even if it's none. You will not get spared.
- the game is perfect to play with kids, but it's not. Simple mechanics, graphic style and so on make it almost perfect for playing with kids. Forced PvP is not. They will get dominated, and as the game is balanced, it's borderline impossible to carry them through.
- as the developers announced, there will never be PvE only option - not an issue per se, but seems pretty important to mention

And just to clarify, I'm not saying all the PvPers in PvP game are toxic, just that there is a lot of the toxic kind, and as interactions with them tend to be easier to remember and have higher impact, it's overwhelming most of the time.

130293487.review:
Please do not buy this. You will regret it later down the line
If i was to describe the game in one line it would be; Novel at first, dull and lonely in the end

I've spent 100 hours now, and i majorly regret the purchase, even refunded it originally only to decide, i would give it a real try, now that i cant refund it, im sad i didnt keep the money. Not so much for the money itself but because of what this game offers

This game offers -zero- actual solo enjoyment, the people you find randomly either just leave, afk or act incredibly rude, and mean. If you dont have friends, this will not be a way to make some, rather a constant source of struggles and upsets by a horrible and abusive playerbase that just want to make others feel bad.

Theres some customization but you get like.. 10.000 gold in an hour if you're efficient ish and you need like.. a million, for anything nice, essentially anyway, the new captain thing is nice - but a lot of it is designed for players that play a lot, and the rest is just cash shop stuff

The solo ish missions and the "tall tales" which is like adventures you go on, are dull with little to not rewards other than some basic cosmetics, they arent that fun, and they are set in the same multiplayer ocean where others can interrupt, and stop and destroy your mission.

I meet some nice people from time to time, but thats the exception rather than the norm - and when things go south people turn toxic incredibly fast.

I can not un-recommend this enough. Go get a "totally legal" version that you can play on a custom solo server, or go play another game like Rust or something, that would have much more in actuality to do

The music is nice, but after 30 hours, the same 14 songs get rather dull to play on repeat - theres some random mini game like things to do, like fishing, which i guess is nice, albeit barely profitable in comparison and at the end of the day they are mostly tediom without true joy.

The meat and potato's in this game, is the people, and again, if thats what you come for, the combat? Its clunky, aim has some wierd custom controls you have to set up- the the guns dont really have reticules, or any sort of aim, which is fine once you learn, but for a new player can be upsetting - and pulling out your sword when you run out or an enemy comes close takes way too long, its like... Do-able, and ive won multiple fights against multiple opponents against me - but its eh AT BEST.

Ship combat? I mean its okay, albeit the solo sloop, one cannon just gets outmatched in every single way and gets out-run. If you are two people, youll end up wanting a brig for the extra cannon, theres up and downsides to everything, but ultimately, it just isnt a very nice experience, especially when you have to rely on other people and players. 

Over all? I hate it, its a waste of 80 gigabytes of space that you could install 5-6 better games with. 

Save your money, enjoy yourself with something that will truly feel rewarding and nice.. 
This has done nothing but give me upset from the first couple of hours, till now. 

I wish the best for you on your journey.

Would I recommend this game? The answer is a glaring "Maybe". 

Pros:
+ fun gameplay, chill with friends
+ lots of different PvE content
+ PvP can be fun

Cons:
- absolutely horrendous, non-existent ACCESSIBILITY options: no adjustable FoV over 90, no turning off head bobbing or motion blur. 
There's tons of posts all over the internet of people getting motion sick from SoT. Games with First Person perspective should do better nowadays!!

140847082.review:
(EDIT/UPDATE:  In the days after this review was posted, the SoT team made a public posting of their own about how they combat cheaters and have banned X number of accounts.
Now, several more hours in the game later, I return to say that the cheating issue hasn't changed from my perspective.  I'm still seeing players landing consistent pinpoint shots from incredible distances with cannons, I'm still seeing broken masts just suddenly POP back into place undamaged, I'm still seeing players "skip" across the water and pop up onto people's decks and crows nests without using ladders and lit powder kegs appearing on my ship deck after being dropped by players up in the sky.
The reality is that this game will never be free of cheaters.  The devs won't act unless it affects their bottom line and implementing anti-cheat cuts into their bottom line.)

Rampant cheaters are found in every facet of this game.  Whether you're queuing up for hourglass PvP or trying to finish a Tall Tale, you absolutely WILL encounter someone using some third-party tool to get an edge over you.  Reporting these cheaters is a needlessly demanding and almost absurd task, as every time I've tried to report blatant hacking Rare has required me to submit *VIDEO EVIDENCE* to them before they'll actually look into any reports of cheaters/hackers.  Nobody playing any game should be expected to fire up OBS and record every game session just so you can give the game devs what they want in a report.  Even then, it's still a 50/50 shot on whether or not they'll actually take appropriate action.  It's proven to be a waste of time. Heck, you may find yourself on the business end of a suspension yourself for wasting *their* time with enough reports submitted without video.

Rare's fervent unwillingness to properly address the issue of cheaters/hackers has really soured me on this game over the last nine months.  Even if you manage to get yourself a full crew that knows what they're doing there's just nothing you can really do to stop yourselves from being the on the receiving end of an aim bot or the sudden appearances of lit powder kegs on your vessel.  Leaving the game and signing back in, hoping for a server less full of this kind of thing, or turning the game off entirely are your only options.

tl;dr
Cheaters are extremely common and the devs don't care.
Your time is valuable so spend it playing something else.

140889225.review:
I've been playing this game for a bit on my friend's account and decided to buy it on sale, I wanted to share my experience so far.

The game is using microsoft xbox gamer panel, which didn't work. So I had to edit registry to fix it. Xbox offered me to change the name for free, I did. It never told me that it's going to actually use numbers in the game along with the nickname. Tried changing it again (now it's $10 for a pop) and it doesn't work. Figured out I need to use VPN for some reason and set it to US to buy it.

Constantly getting stuck on various loading messages and when buying cosmetics for a ship. According to google - those issues existed since the start of the game. Nothing works except alt+f4. 

Joined a group using xbox panel - called n-word repeatedly as soon as they heard my accent and told me I am some sort of "sand n-word", then kicked me.

Started doing adventure with Jack Sparrow. Went afk for a bit, came back, turns out game kicks you for inactivity after 10 minutes. Somehow it skipped the first part of the adventure completely and put me ahead on the next part. 

Started doing emissary quest, needed to go afk for a moment again, kicked for inactivity again, came back to find out that it completely deletes all progress and the quest itself. According to Google people been asking to change how it works for years. Coupled with constantly getting stuck on loading or buying - good luck finishing anything without constantly restarting.

This game is simultaneously one of the most inconvenient, bugged and apparently racist I have ever encountered so far, but also has interesting mechanics, pretty graphics, long quest chains and good music. 

Will update the review after playing more.

------------

More issues:

1) Bought same bundle twice by accident. No way to refund it. Due to the way bundles are redeemed, they are counted as in-game items and automated refund doesn't even see them separately. Now I have a bundle stuck in my Steam inventory forever. Steam support doesn't understand or care about the issue, game support sends you to Steam support.

2) Buying items in Emporium for real currency is disabled in my region, because prices in regional currency are cheaper than buying ancient coins. Game support doesn't admit or deny it, just thanks you for your concern.

3) Lots and lots of toxic, horrible players. Open microphones with swears and blasting terrible music; yelling children; people joining and stealing/crashing/burning your ship, then leaving; no way to report anyone, since they require VIDEO PROOF of everything. 

Overall - PvE aspect of this game is very good, adventures, tall tales, looting wrecks, doing underwater shrines with puzzles, killing npc mobs and ships... but when it comes to PvP aspect, it's not hardcore, it's not fun, it's just annoying and toxic. Losing hours of work to some try-hards chasing you through entire map, not being able to sell items fast (even with sovereign faction), constantly encountering toxic people with open mic's yelling obscenities or blasting weird **** in megaphones - it's all incredibly daunting. 

It's also telling that people are complaining about exactly the same things everywhere, all the time, but a minority (seems no more than 15-30%%) of people vehemently defend the PvP system so they can continue preying on new players, be toxic, trolling and self-actualizing by ruining the fun for everyone else. 

Dare I say - if this game had dedicated PvE and PvP servers, or PvP toggle - it would've been even more popular and interesting.

Sailing the open waters, digging for treasure, watching your hours long work get stolen  or sink to oblivion along with your ship. Ah, Sea of Thieves.
I love getting to navigate my sloop, fighting in sea forts, and hunting for megalodons.
The game is visually beautiful. The game play can be challenging and very fun.
The biggest and probably only negative to the game is the playerbase and PvP in general.
It's soul crushing to hunt for treasure for hours and then watch it get stolen or sink into the sea. If it was fair PvP it might be different, but because the game is easily hacked, it's discouraging. There are online subscriptions that allow players to use aimbot, boat detection (for normal boats, not just Reaper and Emissary), etc. If you keep that in mind and are always on your guard, it's a good game.

I think a PvE server would be cool. It could have a reduced reward amount. The game has so many cool features that it's a shame that the PvP turns so many away.

Until then, I sail alone in my sloop. My friends and family have given up on the game.
Even my wife has left me to sail the seas alone.

It's a lonely pirate's life for me.

129764169.review:
One of the best games I ever played. 
But there are some flaws:
1. BUGS - a seemingly endless amount of bugs, is really annoying especially if you lose your loot because of it (example: 
                 ship goes flying) - somehow Rare doesnt appear to be fixing many and just add more to the game
2. Toxicity - most players are nice but some of them arent. and like in every game a huge proportion of these people claims  to  be pro and better than you even when they are defeated :/
3. takes too long to find enemies with hourglass - ik some of you might be luckier than me but one time i waited 45mins and still no opponent was found (primetime east-coast on american servers) also bad matchmaking Edit: today i found matches after like 30secs so it can be much quicker
4. PVE - can get quite boring after 100/200 hours
5. you WILL get tilted sometimes...but remember you also upset other players ;)
PROs:
1. the pve aspect is great for newer players (but in my opinion getting better at pvp should be your goal ultimately)
2. you can play it solo (better have a bit of experience) but i highly recommend playing it with your friend/ open crew(can get messy) /find players on other  platforms to play with. It's one of the best coop-games i know because it actually involves coordination and searching solutions together
3. a lot of stuff to do - you have many different missions, world events, talltales, etc - but they can get repetitive once you realize only some of them are actually worth your time
4. amazing ocean animation - after 2 years I'm still amazed by them
5. pvp never gets boring if you can find opponents who dont just run away from you
6. it's open world - sail wherever you want (please dont sail into the red sea, that's the boundary of the map not an event and you will sink)
7. regular updates, seasons with a plunder pass (battle pass). great rank up system in-game with the different factions and their reputation you can level up, different achievements, and cosmetics to unlock.
8. almost everything you buy with irl money/gold wont give you an advantage, it's purely cosmetic (some cosmetics can give you a slight advantage) but you cant pay to win.
9. I'm not the biggest fan of alliances (unless i fight them) but maybe you are - you can make an alliance with other ships/players and you get a portion of the gold they make
tipp:
1. Watch guides (it'll take you too long to realize some game meachanics or sailing speed of different ship types,etc) your learning curve will go up massively

Buy the game - if you like one of the below:
- coop 
- open world
- games where you can grind for hours
- you like epic pvp
- the obvious one: you like boats and pirates

You have probably already watched a sea of thieves video/stream if you're down here in the reviews - if not, do so, it will get you the best impression of the game unless they are just fishing (watch the epic pvp battles)
For my part, if your're on the fence of buying this game i say DO IT - if a steam sale is coming up soon wait for it, rn the game is only 20 euros (-50%)  - it's defenitely worth it

132426264.review:
I recently installed Sea of Thieves because a friend of mine wanted to try it out, and I'm absolutely hooked.

It's a pirate sailing adventure game that ends up having a very deep, involved experience the more time you put into it. You spawn in on a beautiful sandy outpost island with a barely stocked ship, and you can just raise anchor and sail anywhere you want to go. If you find an island you can stop off to get more supplies, but often you'll be attacked by a creepy pirate skeleton and it's crew.

Player combat is simple and a little clunky, but once you learn the rhythm of sword swings or reloading the blunderbuss, it feels pretty natural. My favorite is just blasting skeletons into fragments. There are random quest hooks you can find in barrels, or buried in the ground, or dropped in Skeleton's Orders, and you can aimlessly roam the seas gathering treasures and playing sea shanties.

Occasionally you'll come across another player-sailed ship, spotted as a silhouette mast on the horizon. You can avoid them, or sail up and say hi, but often they will respond explosively once you're within cannon range. Naval battles are exciting; a mad balance between blasting holes in your opponent's hull while you furiously try to fix your own.

The best part of the game, however, is that the cost of loss is only relative to the amount of risk you take. If you try to play seriously, there are massive rewards for taking higher risks, but the loss on those runs are more sharply felt. If you just like sailing and selling a few chests when you pull into port, the game is very relaxing and rewarding as you unlock cooler cosmetics and better quests. Even losing a PvP fight or getting sunk in a naval battle can be a barely inconvenient deterrent if you manage your risks properly.

I am not a "hardcore" player and I'll more likely avoid aggressive players than try to take them down, but for a casual pirate simulator it's a great exploration game with a little spice of random cannon-related stress sprinkled in.

138228420.review:
A Voyage Worth Taking: Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition Review

Introduction:
Sea of Thieves has captured the hearts of pirate enthusiasts since its initial release, and with the release of the 2023 Edition, the game sets sail to new horizons. In this review, we delve into the unique aspects, improved features, and overall experience of Sea of Thieves in its latest iteration.

1. Setting Sail into Adventure:
Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition welcomes players into a beautifully crafted open world that feels more alive than ever before. The vast oceans, vibrant islands, and dynamic weather systems immerse players in a breathtakingly realistic pirate experience. The attention to detail in the visuals and the captivating sound design create a truly atmospheric setting.

2. Cooperative Gameplay:
One of the standout features of Sea of Thieves is its cooperative gameplay. With the 2023 Edition, Rare has further refined the mechanics, making it easier than ever to form crews and embark on thrilling adventures with friends. The seamless integration of multiplayer elements and the ability to communicate effectively within the game enhance the cooperative experience and encourage teamwork.

3. Diverse Quests and Objectives:
Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition introduces a wide range of quests and objectives, ensuring that players always have something exciting to pursue. From treasure hunts to epic battles against mythical creatures, each quest feels unique and offers a different challenge. The addition of new locations and narrative-driven quests further enriches the gameplay, providing a deeper sense of progression and purpose.

4. Deep Progression System:
The progression system in Sea of Thieves has received significant improvements in the 2023 Edition. Players can now customize their pirate's appearance, unlock new ship cosmetics, and earn exclusive rewards through a variety of in-game activities. The sense of accomplishment gained from progressing through the ranks and acquiring rare items adds depth and longevity to the gameplay experience.

5. Enhanced PvP Mechanics:
For those seeking a more competitive edge, Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition introduces enhanced PvP mechanics that elevate the intensity of player encounters. From ship battles to engaging in sword fights, the improved combat system offers a thrilling and skill-based experience. The addition of new weapons and tactics provides a fresh layer of strategy, making each encounter a test of wits and skill.

6. Community Engagement and Content Updates:
Rare has shown commendable dedication to engaging with the Sea of Thieves community and delivering regular content updates. The 2023 Edition continues this trend, promising a steady stream of new features, events, and expansions. The developers' commitment to listening to player feedback and incorporating community suggestions ensures that the game remains relevant and exciting over time.

7. Cross-Platform Play:
Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition embraces cross-platform play, enabling players on different platforms to join forces and set sail together. This inclusive approach not only expands the player base but also fosters a sense of unity among the gaming community. The seamless integration between PC, Xbox, and other platforms is a testament to Rare's dedication to accessibility and player convenience.

Conclusion:
Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition solidifies its position as the definitive pirate adventure game. With its stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and continuous content updates, it offers an unparalleled experience for both solo players and crews of friends. Whether you're exploring uncharted waters, battling rival pirates, or uncovering hidden treasures, Sea of Thieves 2023 Edition delivers a thrilling and unforgettable voyage. Get ready to raise the anchor, set sail, and embrace the pirate life like never before!

135893002.review: Sea of Thieves is a great game if you enjoy sailing for hours on end with nothing to do but admire the water and occasionally get attacked by a giant shark. The game is full of exciting features, such as digging up chests that all look the same, fighting skeletons that all act the same, and delivering cargo that all breaks the same. You can also customize your ship and your character with a variety of cosmetics that are totally worth the grind. And don't forget the thrilling PvP combat, where you can either get sunk by a crew of veterans who have nothing better to do than grief new players, or chase a solo sloop for an hour only to find out they have nothing valuable on board. Sea of Thieves is truly a masterpiece of boredom and frustration, and I highly recommend it to anyone who has too much free time and too little self-respect.

126810325.review:
I don't know where to start praising this game.

Yes it has it's faults at times. People will always complain. do not listen to those, try it out for yourself since you can cheaply get it on game pass if you have that. Though the steam version has some benefits like exclusive Fullscreen and such I cant remember that though.

However back to the game. You will get into PVP, although now you have an opt in system arena system you can still and will still be attact. That is the nature of the game. But all player encounters are different. aspacially if you use voice in game and are a bit witty. 

The gold and treasure you find on your adventures are not yours until you sold them. And its not about the gold, its about the glory. The epic fights! I remember my first victory as a solo slooper against a mighty galleon. The more you do the PVP the better you get at it. 

You will have the occasional toxic people yes but best you ignore those. If a fight is unwinnable, just start a new game. you'll not loose much in the long run.

Play it with friends and have fun exploring.
Don't watch how to complete a quest or tall tale (story missions) just figure it out yourself. 

The community is great and helpful. I have had plenty of encounters where I noticed the crew I fought was new (tell tale signs, anchor down sails down etc.) I will stop and help them on their way.

This world is your oyster and you can do with it what you want. there is no set way of playing. 
Just the open sea.

I have 1.8k hours on steam and 1k hours on MS store (yes i bought the game twice) 
I would play it every second of the day if I could.

123844204.review:
Surprisingly shallow for being in season 7 of development. Does the bare minimum you'd expect for a pirate game. A massive game with barely anything to do, and poor motivation to do it.

Unsurprisingly, most of the map consists of an ocean, but for some reason the game does not offer that much to do while sailing. Directing the ship does not take that much effort, so you are left to either play an extremely simple fishing minigame, stare at food while it cooks, or play one of the dozen or so songs that you'll get tired of in an hour. None of which are that productive or engaging.

The game features repetitive quests of predetermined objectives ad infinitum. Combat has very few options, and feels extremely floaty - guns are slow and have no kick to them alongside enemies barely reacting to attacks, and sword swings have no weight while only featuring at most 3 moves. Swing, Block, and Big Swing. Most combat encounters also have no stakes to them. Death has no penalty against any non-player, non-ship NPC, besides a brief wait time. You can just keep throwing yourself at whatever until you win. The only possibly highlight would be ship battles with a crew, in which a team must coordinate between steering, combat, and fixing the ship. These can be slightly engaging. Then, gathering treasures and rewards is a tedious process of finding the most efficient way to drag everything you've earned back to your ship, one item at a time (maybe 3 if you have a spare chest). After the resources have been gathered you must repeat the process at the outposts to sell it.

That is also hoping that you are not hunted down by other players for your loot. Playing single player makes you an easy enough target, but regardless of your crew count, you can be attacked by players of varying skill, and should you be unlucky you can have all of your work plundered, leaving you with nothing but a few hours of completely wasted time. 

All of this effort is to be able to afford pretty much only cosmetics. They all kind of blend together as generic pirate gear, with all the best and most unique gear and additions being locked behind premium currencies, or they require a very long period of grinding. There is very little reward or sense of growth given for completing the same-y quests.

And possibly worst of all is the extremely slow development of the game itself. Half of each addition is just cosmetics, but the developers are also slow to dish out quality of life additions, or even stuff you'd expect in a game like this. The most recent update featured the ability to buy and name your boat, which seems like it should have been a given. It also featured the ability to sell loot to a single individual rather than each vendor respectfully, which relieves only a bit of the tedious loading and unloading of treasure. All this, 7 seasons in.

This is just an extremely shallow game with very little reward for tedious gameplay, a constant threat of other players ruining your day, and far too slow development. I find very little of this game actually engaging, and would only possibly recommend it with friends. Even then, it is asking for $20+ for a grindfest that still implements premium currencies. It is unworthy of your money.

144564028.review:
It's a real shame that I have to give this game a negative review, considering it's actually extremely charming and fun when you can manage to do the content. Key word there is 'manage'. 

I really want to play this game, I want to discover cool islands, sail the seas, and unearth all the whimsical secrets of the world. But I can't, because every time I hop on to play, I inevitably end up being grieved by a large crew in a galleon, or blown up by hackers spawning  explosive barrels onto my measly two-person sloop. I've literally been chased out of bounds by a four-person crew, I had no loot or anything for them to gain. They just did so because they could. when I asked them to leave me alone, as I was just trying to play the game, they responded "we are too". Which speaks for itself. 

On Rare's website, they market the game as follows: "Sea of Thieves offers the ultimate pirate experience, a sandbox world packed to the seams with sailing and exploring, battling and plundering, riddle solving and treasure hunting." The game does have all this, yes, but you'll likely never get to experience much of it, the community make sure of this. There is a story mode, but to put it bluntly, it's just okay.  

If you're a casual gamer, have a full-time job, are trying to play solo, or all of the above, this game is not for you. Playing simply doesn't feel worth the hassle. 

EDIT- As a last ditch effort to play this game, I decided to give it one more go. I went in with the intention to try and avoid players. It took 3 minutes of being on the open water on the way to my destination to be trailed by a brigantine. The chase lasted about 15 minutes, they were always too far behind to start combat. Finally I gave in as I knew they weren't going to leave me alone, so, I docked at the nearest outpost, disembarked my sloop, found a nice high up location at the outpost to watch the crew of neon blue pirates rapid fire cannons at my anchored ship until it sunk into the ocean. The finale of this session was me sitting there motionless as they ran up to me to finish the job, I couldn't be bothered to fight back. This was when I hit alt+f4 and just uninstalled the game.

Rust, but in the ocean. If that's your thing carry on.

I've tried it on and off since release. Rare has added plenty of content, and overall the game appears to be in a healthy state. The cosmetic-only progression is a smart format for a game of this type and it's generally an even playing field. However, the community is what you'd expect in an always-on PvP game. People will chase you across the map to sink you-- even if you have nothing on you. 5 out of 6 encounters today were shoot-on-sight, initiated by them, all ending in teenagers hurling slurs as my crew's (worthless) bananas and planks drifted into the depths. In about 5 hours only one ship actually VOIPed and interacted. As I logged off for the day I gave some remaining supplies to a nearby crew, who shot at my empty Sloop and stabbed me as I emoted.

"That's the game!", which is absolutely true, but frankly there are more worthy ways to spend your time than fulfilling Braydon and Kayden's power fantasies. In my imagination there's this romantic idea of tense encounters and cheeky escapes, where alliances fail and opportunists strike. Reality is a vast skill gap that I just don't have the commitment to bridge, and an off-putting player base.

This is the inevitable fate of games like this. The juice ain't worth the squeeze.

123809715.review:
I love this game to death, the atmosphere, soundtrack, audio and art design, the naval combat mechanics and the lovely adventures.

However the extremely buggy hand to hand combat means that any of the forced PvP encounters will inevitably end with one or more hostile players silently boarding your vessel, and killing everyone on it with one shot. The skill gap between players who know how to abuse the hand to hand system, and those who don't, is utterly vast, and only dozens of hours of training in this, by far least interesting part of the game, will prevent you from being constantly ganked while trying to have fun with the game's hundreds of hours of enjoyable content.

In its current state I can't recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a pirate adventure game, as the predatory players have been consistently forcing all other types of player out of the game. When I played the game at launch, we would have a player versus player encounter maybe once every ten hours, the rest of the time we would either sail by other crews harmlessly, or exchange treasure and music over fun talk of our adventures. These days I can maybe finish a two hour session 20 percent of the time without being sunk somewhere along the way, usually just after leaving port initially.

I hope the developers disincentivise random hostility before all the players are gone.

130154380.review:
Sea of Thieves is a casual PvE game where other players are allowed to roll up on you after you've collected a moderate amount of loot, kill you, spawn camp you on your ship while you load back in with a black screen, sink your ship, take all of your loot, and you have no recourse other than to alt+F4 because you either don't have the time of ability to get it back.

This was the one game my wife and I could have put a lot of hours and maybe some money into together, but the PvP really rots the entire experience.

The majority of the updates and content are all PvE focused, the idea that this ever was a PvP-oriented game is insane. In no other PvP game can you go without ever fighting other players and accomplish all of your goals and log off feeling satisfied. Thats called a PvE game ladies and gentlemen, the addition of PvP is literally just giving other players the ability to grief, and to argue otherwise is honestly just embarrassing.

The common argument is "PvE servers would never work" and every time I come across it I can't imagine we're playing the same game, because every core loop of the game is PvE, you quite literally are NEVER required to engage in PvP. Even the PvP faction in the game is just masquerading as the best PvE faction as they accept all loot and apply the gold/rep multiplier to all of that loot, loot that doesn't require any PvP to acquire. Unlike the other factions that only accept loot they're interested in, and so when you give the loot they don't want to the factions that do want them, you don't get the bonus loot.

125809453.review:
A once awesome game you could play with your friends in a relative relaxed way with limited worries of being repeatedly killed by experience PVP players. Now, the devs have sailed the game into a more or less pure PVP experience with experienced players dominating the servers.

The original games appeal was that it was a game where you could explore, puzzle solve and loot in a great open world. It had manageable and entertaining NPC enemies, and a low risk of running into PVP scenarios which you had a fair chance of fending off or evading.

Now if you see them on the horizon, you are up a certain creek with out a paddle.

The obvious answer to this issue is sadly being ignored (have a PVP and a PVe server). Something that seems to be for the benefit of one player base at expense of another. 

The game as it is now, I would never have bought or recommended to friends.

137832720.review:
Ahoy mateys, after spending a whopping 170 hours playing Sea of Thieves, I can say without a doubt that this game is a real treasure! It's like a pirate's dream come true, with all the grog-drinking, treasure-hunting, and ship-battling you could ever want.

But let's be real, it's not all smooth sailing on the high seas. You'll encounter plenty of Krakens, megalodons, and other sea monsters along the way, not to mention the occasional cannonball to the face from enemy pirate ships. And don't even get me started on the dreaded "skeleton fortresses" that will test your skills and bravery like never before.

But fear not, me hearties, for the rewards of playing Sea of Thieves are well worth the risks. There's nothing quite like the thrill of discovering buried treasure on a deserted island, or successfully fending off a rival pirate crew to claim the ultimate prize. And let's not forget the hilarious hijinks that can ensue when you and your friends get a little too much grog in your systems.

Overall, Sea of Thieves is a game that will keep you entertained for hours on end, whether you're sailing solo or with a crew of fellow pirates. So if you're looking for a swashbuckling adventure on the high seas, then set sail for the world of Sea of Thieves and prepare for a wild ride. And remember, always keep one eye on the horizon and a hand on your sword! Arrr!

147527934.review:
Sea of Thieves is the most frustrating game I have ever played, and I’ve played it a lot. While I only have 300 hours of gameplay on steam I played it for far more time while it was exclusively on the microsoft store which I have no doubt equates to around 1000 hours in total.

This means I am currently level 30 in Athena fortune, level 75 in gold hoarders, level 75 in order of souls, and level 75 merchants alliance.

So yeah I have played the game a fair amount and know every aspect of it like the back of my hand.

What is good

So let us start off with the good, because yes there is good stuff in this game, and it is at times fun to play.

Sailing is fun, the mechanics are pretty good, fishing is fun because its mechanics were well designed, world events are fun, from skeleton forts to skeleton fleets. If you are bored, doing a world event is enjoyable, the game is very beautiful, additionally ship to ship combat is enjoyable.

Right now lets start on the very long list of what is wrong with this game. I was going to start with a lack of tutorial but eventually long after launch Rare added a tutorial, this triple AAA game released without a proper and functioning tutorial.

The game is slowly dying

This game from top to bottom is just badly designed, and as a result a lot of the time it just isn’t fun. Don’t get me wrong I have had literally hundreds of hours of fun in this game, I’ve also had hundreds of hours of mundane boring, completely pointless grinding. Sea Of Thieves is lucky to get more than 20,000 average players on steam every day, a pitifully low number.

And even if you be very generous and double or triple those figures to 60000 players to include both PC and xbox, that's still pretty low considering on its steam page, rare proudly proclaims that 15 million people have played SOT, which is no doubt largely down to SOT being on the xbox/pc game pass, but I digress, it really puts in perspective just how dull SOT gameplay is when 15 million people have played the game and yet just 20000 people on steam stuck with it.

Rares refusal to acknowledge virtually all of the completely fair criticism of this game

I remember when this game first came out and it was riddled with bugs. I'll be honest it didn’t actually bother me that much. What did bother me was the complete lack of repeatable and enjoyable gameplay, the entire questing system was based off RNG for reasons Rare never properly explained, the updates came thick and fast for a while, every single week. Sounds good right? Well the problem was that they were pumping out that many updates that they were adding as many bugs every week as they were fixing.

But most problematic is the complete disconnect between what Rare thought SOT was and what the community knew SOT was, a hot mess. I remember laughing to my friends about how people on reddit were complaining and complaining and complaining about problems with the game and every single week all we got from Rare was Joe Neate smiling at the camera assuring everything was fine, and that all would be well.

Meaningful progression is non existent, gold and XP are worthless

Rare in its boundless wisdom decided from the outset that every player regardless of their level should get a fair playing field whenever they fight. Now here's the thing rare, not only is removing meaningful forms of progression obnoxiously lazy video game design but it also makes any gold and XP in the game worthless, think about it logically, if you can’t use gold, to buy a faster ship, a better sword, a stronger crew, or a better hull, if you can only use gold to buy cosmetics, the gold thus has literally no value to you as a player, none.

The same can be said for levelling, outside of unlocking certain missions, there is literally no purpose to levelling guilds; it gives you nothing in game, no advantage. So congratulations Rare. You used the thinly veiled excuse of every player having a fair fight against one another to justify lazy video game design, and in the process made acquiring gold and levelling utterly devoid of any purpose.

Battle Royale Removed

SOT gameplay consists of either adventure, a pirates life, or a maiden voyage, oh and there also used to be a battle royal mode, but after no doubt spending 1000s of man hours on developing that game mode to jump on the battle royal hype train they then removed it because not enough people played it. As someone who didn’t really play the battle royal game mode I’d say this is a really stupid idea, the player than enjoyed playing this game may have been a minority but a lot of people really, REALLY enjoyed this gamemode, for example it was very popular among streamers there was no logical reason to remove it.

So yeah ignoring the battle royal mode that Rare no doubt spent tens of thousands if not hundreds of thousands of pounds developing and then scrapped, lets focus on adventure.

Matchmaking is abysmal

Matchmaking is terrible, five years after launch the only options available to you are two options: play with friends or play with randoms.

There's no option for you to join your friends when there ship is full, which is almost always the case because the max crew size is just four, yep people thats it, hope you don’t have a many friends, rare could allow you join the same server as your friends and start on a different ship but that would allow alliance servers the people cry out, well as gold and XP in the game are worthless why would this matter.

There's no option as a new player to join the ship of an experienced crew to learn how to play the game, there's no option as an experienced player to join a new player crew and teach them how to play, these are very easy fixes to do, but rare is lazy and after five years the matchmaking still sucks.

The basic gameplay loop of SOT is not in my opinion fun, the main reason is a combination of a complete lack of objectives for players to sink their teeth into, needlessly grindy and lacking in depth gameplay which isn’t fun, and also even now after all this time there is just not that much to do.

Lack of clear objectives

When you spawn into the game you start in the pub and then it's up to you. No objectives in sight, and the reason this really hampers gameplay is because of the bad matchmaking system, remember it's just play with friends or play with randoms, so if you create a crew of randoms and you want to achieve an objective there's no easy way to tell they to do that, do not bring up the pirate wheel, it's a badly designed janky cluttered mess. When you compare it to a game like league of legends which also has an objective wheel that takes less than half a second to tell every player on your team what you want to do, and where you want to go, it puts the joke of a wheel system that Rare created to shame.

138861311.review:
I pre-ordered this game way back when. Played it for hours and hours and hours when it first came out, back when there were only three factions and the only event was the skeleton fort. Eventually moved on because there was nothing left to achieve in the game at the time. Picked up the 2023 edition in the Steam Summer Sale for the exclusive cosmetics and for easier matchmaking with friends who have the game through Steam (and because the Microsoft Store sucks, but I digress).

I hate what this game has become. It's gone from being a very simple game with little content to more content than anyone could hope to achieve in a lifetime. Gone are the days when being Pirate Legend meant something. Now it's practically just the intro to the game. But the biggest issue with this game is that [i]you can't actually complete any of its content anymore[/i] because no matter what you do--even if you don't raise an emissary flag (which makes you a more lucrative target for PvPers), even if you're doing Tall Tales (the PvE questline), even if you're just f***ing fishing--some randoms will jump you for a fight, and now you're stuck PvPing for an indefinite amount of time. And the biggest issue with PvP is that unless there's a [i]substantial[/i] skill difference between you and your opponent in either direction, it basically ends up being a stalemate lasting over an hour in which neither of you can sink the other. And since the vast majority of players (myself included) are frankly just mediocre at PvP, that ends up being pretty much every time. And don't come at me with "git gud" bulls***; some of us are f***ing casuals who just wanna enjoy some treasure-hunting PvE with friends. Besides, if any of you were actually good, you'd think somebody would have actually managed to sink me by now instead of just wasting everyone's time as described.

Not to mention, you have to spend multiple hours in this game every session to make any progress at all, because it takes that long to actually gather a substantial amount of loot and painstakingly sell it item-by-item. And that's [i]if[/i] you get lucky enough to be able to play for more than an hour at a time without getting roped into a PvP stalemate.

This game is a massive, frustrating time sink in which it feels nearly impossible to actually [i]achieve[/i] anything. Don't waste your time unless your [i]only[/i] goal is to d*** around with friends, and even then, expect to spend most of it sailing around in circles with some other dunces, both of you whiffing your cannon shots and failing boarding attempts until you finally decide it isn't even worth bothering anymore. Sunk Cost Fallacy: The Game.

146365297.review:
I love this game, i love it to death and enjoy playing it with my partner more than anything. However, i cannot recommend this game to a new or returning player because of the agonizingly high skill floor. Even if you think you're the best PVPer in the whole wide world, they will eat an entire magazine of blunderbuss shots yet kill you in one. Sisyphean cannot even begin to describe the experience of playing this game.

TL:DR good game, most toxic community i've ever seen. rare please im begging you just add private servers or a dedicated PvP zone so the sweats can sweat and the normal people can have their nice pirate game alone.

I bought this a few years ago and I have come back to it several times since. Initially I was always sceptical about the zero progression and there only being cosmetic items, but honestly I think that's what makes it special. You're always on a level playing field.

Then the Combo of the PVP, sloops with 2 can take down galleys with 4 players because they can out-manuvre. The music and general replayablity means no two fort of fortunes is going to go down the same. 

Then when all the PVP subsides you can create little alliances and feel even more badass. 

My only downside on this game is the occasional cheater, but they are so infrequent they've only ruined 2 play sessions in about 60 hours.

and best of all, lots of achievements to keep you playing and to keep the variety up too

135155525.review:
For a pvp centered game there is a serious lack of pvp rebalances and pvp changes. 

It's a shared world experience, this way you can have infinite possibilities when meeting people.
Sadly the community takes that "infinite" and turns it into either "Too paranoid to trust the other" or "Shoot on sight without ever exchanging a word with the other" for a game where you can be social and talk/have adventures with complete strangers, literally just sit down and drink with people while a huge crowd gathers around and has fun together,
Sadly this encounters are pretty rare, i would say 5% of all the encounters. The other 95% of the encounters will range between the silent killers that don't even talk and just treat the game as if it was competative, to kids who just learned a couple slurs so they use it in this game while fighting you.(Don't worry some adults also swear all the same and put the blame on you even if they happen to lose the battle that they started.)

The combat is the worst offender tbh, if the game was more centered around ships i'm pretty sure a lot of people would enjoy pvp more. But the combat right now is just a shitty fortnite rip off. You jump around with guns to have the adventage over people, eat underwater/shoot underwater/throw grenades underwater/light a fuse underwater, That's also because some veterans figured out that it's easier to win if you don't allow the other crew to play. So this is the main strategy every encounter will revolve around. You wanted to enjoy maintaining a ship during a fierce battle? You have to sit by the ladder and watch because the same person will try to get onboard and cause mayhem. (which would lead to your crew being unable to fight the opposing ship.) 

The non pvp side of the game is pretty relaxing. You can literally just log on with 3 friends and sail around doing nothing. It's a really good game to just talk in and enjoy the scenery. We did do this a bunch in the past, just sailing and chatting.
Not even doing events, Maybe a little fishing. 

But if you wish to do content then there is plenty to do even without pvp. Lots of story missions, Riddles, encounters. 

The game is good, the community isn't.

141783857.review:
The game is absolutely towards angry PVP teenagers with a 5-6 group.

If you're solo, you are going to die. Repeatedly. Because you have to, sail, fix, shoot, kill other players, all by yourself and all at the same time which is obviously impossible. So get a mission that gives absolutely no rewards and sail for like 45 minutes across the map to die 2 to 3 times in a row to a group of 6 players that chase you the entire time to kill for no reason at all (remember, no rewards in the game whatsoever besides skins) so that you after re-spawn in a very far away island to sail for another 45 minutes to get killed again.
You play PVE to get killed in undesirable PVP for no rewards at all. nice.

But, if you have a crew to sail a big ship than you can absolutely bully other players for no rewards at all, just for the sake of being an ass. If you could play in an PVE with no other players this game would improve significantly. Oh and meaningful rewards besides skins and more skins.

135433188.review: If you want a game loaded with an unnecessary amount of barely balanced mechanics shoved onto ship to ship combat that essentially makes it a boring drag of just who has more shots to spam from afar. This is your game, came back to it after a long hiatus expecting it to still be interesting but the pvp has gotten to such a dull uninteresting mess and in the case of on foot combat 90% just spam bombs cause they take 0 effort and risk. While it could be interesting they still manage to blunder it and just leave a sad sack of downright boring pvp despite a weird focus on the pvp with how much mechanics they add that clearly lean into the pvp side. Captaincy being a big one with how you can just buy loads of supplies (be it normal or through glitches) to the point you can just spam fire without aiming cause you have 1k rounds ready to go. Overall, if you want a neat pirate game and some adventures? It probably isn't worth your time this far into its life cycle as Rare just have no good direction to take the game and can't decide what they even want it to be any more. The peaceful life route is always an option but not a very doable one with how many seek the game for the pvp side despite it's extreme lackluster. You can still get some good stories out of it, but only at a steep discount at most would I recommend it even then if you at least have some friends to play with.

146460830.review:
Sea of Thieves - це неймовірно захоплююча і весела гра в жанрі піратської пригоди, яка принесла відомому жанрові свіжість та оригінальність. Вона дозволяє вам відправитися в морські пригоди разом з друзями або командою, де ви можете стати справжнім піратом, досліджувати безкраї океани, шукати скарби і боротися з іншими гравцями.

Однією з визначних особливостей Sea of Thieves є його відкритий світ, який дійсно вражає своєю красою та атмосферністю. Гра пропонує гравцям безмежні можливості для дослідження і пригод в казковому піратському світі, де кожен острів і водяне простори мають свої унікальні секрети і завдання.

Морські битви і бойові дії в грі також дуже захоплюючі. Ви можете керувати своїм кораблем, стріляти з гармат і підбивати супротивників в епічних морських битвах. Водночас комунікація і співпраця з вашою командою додають грі велику стратегічну складову.

Гра активно підтримується розробниками, і вона регулярно отримує нові оновлення, які додають багато нового контенту, завдань та можливостей. Спільнота гравців Sea of Thieves також дуже активна, і це створює чудову атмосферу спільноти і взаємодопомоги.

Анімація та графіка у грі виглядають неймовірно, додаючи грі художньої цінності. Звуковий дизайн, включаючи музику та звуки моря, допомагають поглибити іммерсію.

Узагалі, Sea of Thieves - це надзвичайно весела та захоплююча гра, яка вам несумнівано сподобається, якщо ви шукаєте піратські пригоди та можливість грати разом з друзями. Ця гра призначена для того, щоб розважати та вразити своєю красою та оригінальністю, і вона точно заслуговує на увагу геймерів.
