147007305.review:
I picked this game up because some of my friends play it. I'm not super in love with it, but the ship sailing and treasure hunting feels very nice to play, and the short questing system and the zany, cartoonish world made it enjoyable as a sort of party game. I put it down again because the PvP was non-optional and had very high skill caps - it seems to be good, deep PvP, but I couldn't enjoy the game as a casual experience with my friends unless we either accepted getting randomly shit on all the time by other people who were much better and having all our stuff stolen, or engaging deeply and sinking a great deal of time and effort into improving to a passable level. Neither option appealed to me, so I left.

Recently, PvE servers were announced. It isn't the way the developers ever intended their game to be played, and they really meant that - for nearly ten years they've actively silenced all discussion on the subject here and on their forums elsewhere. But they've finally relented, and found the humility to help people enjoy the game they made in a way that better suits them, and that is commendable. 

As a result, I can now recommend Sea of Thieves as a lighthearted social game. It's great to play with friends, fight sea monsters, get swarmed by 939484 skeletons, and the sailing and ship travel mechanics feel incredible.

135359517.review: This is genuinely one of the most toxic games I've played in a long time. I don't think it necessarily has to do with the developers themselves or the actual game in general, but the toxicity I've become acquainted with is far deadlier than any maritime disaster. The Sea of Thieves must genuinely be cursed, all the seas seem to breed is heartbreak, anger, and disappointment. If you think Sea of Thieves is something you'd genuinely have fun and stick with for a while, don't be afraid to buy the game. But otherwise, take warning land-lubbers! The game itself and most players are extremely unfriendly towards new players. If you read any other negative review you'll get a general gist of of how unforgiving the game and its players are towards newer players or smaller ships. There's some highly experienced players on the high seas and very rarely will they show any form of guilt or remorse as they regularly send newer players to Davy Jones's locker. Hey, I guess their only love really is the sea. People will legitimately just sit outside of objectives waiting eternally for other ships to complete them and then sink their ships for loot. Why be an asshole and sink a new player's ship in a situation like this? It takes a new player longer to do objectives because they're newer; more loot could be acquired by the aggressor in a much faster time if they didn't sit waiting. The only reason I can think of is that they genuinely enjoy ruining the small amount of progress new players make and then justify it with the minimal amounts of loot they might collect from their sunken remains. I can only conclude that most Sea of Thieves players are not actually people, but are instead Tardigrades. It's the most logical conclusion given how they can thrive and survive for so long in such a toxic environment while retrieving so little nourishment.  Technically all of the collectibles and loot only allow you to buy cosmetics, but it's basically the only sense of progression in the game. It genuinely feels wrong to constantly rob that small sense of progress from new players. This may actually be a silver lining, as I wouldn't put it past the players in this game to use hard-to-grind loot as a way to endlessly pummel newer ships even further. The game allows you to propose alliances with other ships, but this doesn't prevent allies from attacking you or stealing your loot. You gain 100% of the gold on items you sell in an alliances and allies gain 50% of the 100% you gain. It's not split between you both, you get the full price while all allies gain a "duplicated" 50% of what you earn. Alliances sound like a cool concept on paper with the potential for betrayal on the high seas or a long alliance paying off when you go to turn your loot in, but in reality it just allows people to backstab you on a dime and sink your ship with the first strike. People will genuinely attack your ship in an alliance for no reason, even if it's not for the 50% more they could have from turning loot in themselves. This one time I completed some fortress event with some folks in an alliance and took all of the loot back to THEIR ship. Our ships got separated for a bit of time during an attack from an enemy ship. When we regrouped we sat peacefully for a while until the enemy ship returned. Our allies ended up returning the favor by shooting MY crew's ship out of the blue and then sailed away to fight the enemy ship. I couldn't even retaliate it was so quick. I didn't fight back because I thought somehow it might have been the enemy ship firing until I saw where the cannonballs were actually coming from. My crew talked with theirs and we were all getting along well while we fought waves of skeletons for nearly two hours before. I couldn't believe they had done it, or even more, why. I decided to wait a little while in case they turned our loot in and did some fishing and exploring for an hour or two. I never saw their ship sink on the map, but I can't be sure if they survived the encounter alone with the enemy ship. Even if they did, they never turned it in. My crew left without ever seeing that 50% that would have jump started us in terms of progression. People will also pretend to be friendly while your ship is attacked by megalodons and other creatures. They will legitimately start a conversation with you as they pass or say hello and then loop back around after you finish the fight just to sink you and take your loot. Heartless. What ever happened to the sailor's motto of Faith, Courage, Service true, with Honor, Over Honor, Over All? You basically HAVE to play aggressively in this game to avoid being backstabbed by an ally or to get the first strike on a potential threat. It creates such a brew of toxicity I'm surprised the seas don't glow green like the Chicago River on Saint Patrick's day.If you've made it this far I hope you've enjoyed reading. Maybe you'll er more towards caution when thinking about or actually sailing the seas. I'm sure a lot of new players give up easily seeing how much of a cesspit the nearly unavoidable PVP scene is in Sea of Thieves. I totally understand that the game is themed around being a pirate which involves looting and ship combat, but that doesn't make it right to pick on new and defenseless players just because you can. Sinking their ship before they can even put up a fight is not going to teach them anything and is only going to kill off the general playerbase in the long run. A sea is not like a marsh or a body of still sitting water. It's constantly moving and always has new and old waters running through it.

131952281.review:
I have mixed feelings about this game. I both undoubtedly adore this game and absolutely hate it. I don't compare pros or cons often in a review, but for this. It's needed, so let's start with the good.

The good in this game is it's very addicting and fun. I have sunk hours and hours into the game without even realizing it, and it has so many things you can do. Your playtime could be 400 hours to 2,000, maybe more if you really wanted to do everything, and that's insane just thinking about it. The graphics are beautiful. Just taking in the small moments without fighting or being too focused on anything is peaceful and makes you realize how beautiful the game is. And on a personal note, for someone who had Pirate101 as one of their main childhood games, this brought back a lot of pleasant memories.

Now the bad. This game is incredibly grindy. Now that's good in some cases because, it makes you keep playing the game for a very long time. But to a certain extent, it is ridiculous how you have to spend an hour, maybe longer, just to make your progress bar go up two to four inches in a faction. And I already talked about how much playtime could be put into Sea of Thieves, and that's great. The bad part about that is how this game is a huge time consumer. If you want to play a little bit of Sea of Thieves, you'd need more than two hours just to make progress, more additional hours depending on what you're doing. And the worst part about this game is the players, toxic players. I know it is very luck dependent in this game with what kind of people you will run into. But out of my entire time playing this game. There have been so many hateful, petty, and narcissistic players that it has caused me to quit the game once. It doesn't matter what you're doing. You could be doing a Tall Tale, which is a story-driven quest, you could be peacefully fishing with no treasure on your boat. You could be doing nothing! And the players will not care and kill you out of their own enjoyment. You could be saying that it's a pirate game and you aren't supposed to be good, and that's true. But people take it way too seriously and act way too hateful which ruins the game for me in some cases. I hate to list so many explanations, but people need to know.

Sea of Thieves is more than a video game. It's your adventure where you create your own path, you choose your quests, you determine your sides, and you form your story. After all of this, Sea of Thieves is a game worth playing. As harsh as it can be, it's also beautiful. Even as bad as the cons are that I listed, the game itself makes it worth playing in the end no matter what you face on the seas.

144183783.review:
[b][h1][u]TLDR:[/u][/h1][/b]Sea of ​​Thieves (aka Sea of Cheaters) is what I would call a missed masterpiece, I really wish I could recommend this game but no matter how hard I try, I can't do it. 
[hr][/hr][b][h1][u]My conclusions:[/u][/h1][/b]This game can be terrifyingly fun and deeply frustrating at the same time.
I first played this game when it came out in the now distant 2018 thanks to the €1 Gamepass so I can see it with the eyes of a person who knows what SoT was at the time and knows what SoT is today.

Let me start by saying that I don't criticize the idea of ​​fighting and sinking other player's ships. 
It's perfect for those who like competition and those who like to snatch the loot from others.
However I don't approve how the game doesn't respect that part of players who have no interest in competing and just want to continue their journey with serenity.
I always laughed at the uselessness of the advice given on the Ferryman's ship once you died, whose message can be perfectly summarized with: "Sick of being sunk by others? SUNK YOURSELF". Wow, really comforting.
Initially I didn't mind PvP at all because, simply, there weren't many broken mechanics and strategies like now, also thanks to the fact that people didn't aim only to tryhard and bug abuse/cheat/exploit the entire time.

I think I speak for everyone when I say that what was so captivating about SoT were the stunning environments, the sense of novelty and naval combat, to this day we still have no games comparable to SoT or worthy rivals.
Is it a fun game? Yes definitely.
But I suggest you pay close attention to what you are about to buy and what you are going to get into.

Bad PvP and community issues aside, this game requires insane amounts of hours to both loot, level up and earn some gold.
The first 20/50 hours are pure entertainment, if you haven't spoiled anything, the sense of discovery and adventure that you will experience on every journey will be unmatched, especially if played with some friends, even played as a solo has its charm.
Once you become an expert sailor you will begin to understand the real mechanics of the game and only then you will begin to really understand what SoT is like and get an idea about the game itself.

New payers and the ones who haven't already done everything in the game a minimum of 999 times will be forced to cope because there is no lobby system and most likely will be in the same lobbies with tryhards whose life revolves entirely around this game and bug abusing, exploiting and cheating.
Trust me: trying to catch up with these 3000+ PvP hours players is nearly impossible if you don't want to invest a minimum of 5+ hours per day playing SoT. 

I won't dwell on the scandals Rare has been involved in. (unjustified bans, unmotivated defenses of Streamers etc, etc)
Below I list some of the pros and cons I encountered both now and when I played SoT years ago.

[b][u]PROS[/u][/b]
[list][*]The game, just like any other multiplayer around, is extremely fun to play with friends. 

[*]Regarding PvE I got nothing to say; compared to the past they have made great strides by adding a lot of stuff to do, exploration is certainly not lacking.

[*]The overall mechanics of exploration are probably the best thing about the game: being able to sail, find hidden treasures, do quests, missions, events, raids, main stories and so on.

[*]The settings and the care with which the map is made are simply spectacular.
The sea, the day/night cycle, the sky, the stars, the aurora borealis, the atmospheric changes... it's all amazing, really. 

[*]Personally, I have always really liked the fact that the ship requires real management and that its efficiency also changes based on the capacity of the people on board, thus creating a unique and inimitable synergy between the members of the crew.
[/list]

[b][u]CONS[/u][/b]
[list][*]It's a big time sink.

[*]The tutorial is incomplete and barely explains the basics, not at all preparing players for what really awaits them during their adventure across the seas of SoT.

[*]The optimization, the netcode and the hitreg has only gotten worse over the years and the devs have never fixed it, just like the rampant problem of cheaters and bug abusers.

[*]The game is scripted in such a way that as soon as you have some loot on the ship, megalodons, krakens, storms and whatnot start spawning all and only around your ship.

[*]Personally I find that the ballistics of the cannons has gotten much worse over the years, it seems to be shooting 999kg cannonballs and always having to make absurd calculations to hit even at a distance of 50 meters.

[*]The game doesn't have a way to "defend" new players from beasts with 3000+ hours on their back, so good luck minding your business and trying to learn the ropes step by step because there will be almost zero opponents of your similiar skill level resulting in a useless/frustrating experience most of the times.

[*]The game is poisoned by a subset of chronically online players, who will exploit the game in every way possible to sink you, which they don't always do just to get your treasure. 
They just do it because they want you to know that they're better than you since they play this game 18 hours a day and are using the latest strategies.

[*]There's no need to try to sweeten the pill, like 90% of multiplayer games the biggest negative side of SoT is the community for countless reasons:
Endless toxicity, extreme and unjustified tryharding by people who, if they don't bully/insult others heavily, have no way of curing the "small pp" syndrome they suffer from.

[*]Grinding, grinding and more grinding.
It all costs too much, it's a constant grind even to buy a pair of pants, and having to do some missions three to five times to get a skin is just ridiculous, it's definitely the wrong way to extend the longevity of a videogame.
Also because after a while it gets repetitive despite the content that the game offers since, whether you like it or not, the things to do are always the same so even leveling up your companies becomes a sort of job.

[*]Although you already have a small group of friends to play with (therefore having already overcome the first major obstacle that the game puts in front of you) the skill gap between new and old players is too wide, creating gatekeeping like on [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/304390/FOR_HONOR/]For Honor[/url] where if you are a new player for the first 300/400 hours (minimum) you have to get bludgeoned in the teeth then, perhaps, you'll start to understand something assuming your crew is willing to waste all this time to be able to "have fun".
In this game there is no middle ground: either you are a new player/casual player or a tryhard who has been playing religiously since day one and did nothing but PvP 24/7.

[*]A [b]HUGE[/b] flaw of this title is the fact that the so-called "solo players" will have an awful experience in the vast majority of content that the game has to offer.
Maneuvering the ship, sailing, exploring, PvE components but above all the PvP part are terribly disadvantageous for lonely sea dogs or for people who want to spend a couple of hours making a more casual and relaxing game session... you are "forced" to have other people to fully enjoy the game with, and this is something I never liked.
If you don't already have a group of friends with the same goals as yours (be it PvP or something else) you are 
constrained to go around the various Discord servers and socialize/group with complete strangers just to be able to spend a couple of hours profitably and even if you are willing to do that, the vast majority of what people are looking for nowadays is straight pvp and you better be experienced right off the bat or your not getting invited to play. 
[/list]

[u]My components:[/u]
RTX 3060TI 8GB
I5-9600K 3.70Ghz
16 GB RAM DDR4 3000mhz

137598009.review:
[h1]This is borderline do not recommend.[/h1]
Full price - No. On Sale - Yes, but consider:

Initially this game is amazing. Digging up treasure, fighting hordes of enemies, sailing your boat, levelling up factions rep, hunting or defending yourself from other players. With friends its a great game. Although others complain about the community and pvp, it can be annoying when on a quest but it is what keeps the game exciting. Especially when you and your friends are on a galleon being attacked by two sloops and a brigantine, its hectic, chaotic, but exciting. Trying to board the other players ships, taking on water, stressing over dwindling supplies after 1+ engagement, then finally sinking them only to be hunted by them again and finally be sunk. It's part of the game and can stop it from being stale.

[b]The problem is the repetitive nature and loosing that initial charm of the game.[/b]

All quests can be summed up as follows: [u]Fetch quest.[/u]
Order of Souls - Go here kill enemy horde/ fleet, collect loot, return.
Gold Horders - Go to this island, collect pieces of map/ treasure, find next island/tomb, loot, return.
Tall Tales - Follow these clues, find this spot, collect treasure, done, return.
Merchants - Take merchandise to island, sell, buy some more, repeat. 
Reapers - Attack and loot everything and anyone, return.

[b]Cosmetics:[/b] They are a grind to get, having to loot 100 tombs for cosmetics is ridiculous but a good bragging point. Otherwise there is MTX.

[b]Problem with AI:[/b] Realistically mobs are stale. Most have very similar attack patterns and somewhat brain dead. Fortresses can be solo'd with ease. Mobs offer little to no challenge, even when they vastly outnumber you. The game does offer 'raid bosses' but they're basically a sponge.
On the water there's sirens again little to no threat, sharks, megs that just have different skins and the kraken (tbf kraken is fun).

[b]Playing Solo:[/b] When you start you'll have a fun and almost zen experience: Sailing the seas, adjusting sails, exploring the horizon. But It can quickly become boring. If your in the wind heading to a destination there isnt much to do other than play an instrument or drink some grog. Pvp solo can be a nightmare esp when they're a brig or galleon attacking you, but if you enjoy the challenge you'll have a good time (it can actually ease the boredom). It is definitely a "Fun with friends game."

[b]Finally Community:[/b] Although I didn't mind a game of cat and mouse with the Reapers as a gold horder or the PVP aspect, other friends with me found it infuriating. Some players can be blood thirsty and chase you for hours on end and even after sinking them will try hunting you for the rest of your session. It can be good in adding a tense layer in your gameplay session, but what other friends noted is true: When your trying to mind your own business and just wanting to chill and do quests it was just wasting time. 
People have often complained about the community being offensive and racist, they're on there much like any server, but if they poked fun at me for having an accent I could just laugh it off. But some people will have an issue with this, so be aware. On the flip side there are some decent people on there as well, all first encounters normally are tense. But afterwards can be pretty chill, drinking and playing instruments, forming temp truces to sink a pvp ships with The Chest... Then either forming an alliance or sinking each other later on.

If the dev's add more content and variety. Especially with missions, and mobs this will be a solid recommend. But its been out since 2018, and content comes at a snails pace.

134820956.review:
The game I never knew I needed until I got plunged head-first into it.

Sea of Thieves was my first experience with an Open World Sandbox sort of game, and I remember starting it utterly lost and confused. It wasn't easy for the first 100 hours, and the friends I tried to rope in with me all dropped off quickly. It took some wonderful experiences queuing with strangers to unlock what I love about this game. Interactions with other players will always be unique and fun. Sometimes you'll find yourself struggling to stay afloat in a stressful, heart-pumping, naval battle, and then fishing peacefully off your boat in the next session. Sure, there are issues. The lack of anti-cheat makes experiences with hackers a pain and a half. Laggy servers cause a lot of pain: from hit registration not functioning to being stuck in menus you have to kill your fellow players to get out of, with the worst making the game physically unplayable. I've heard complaints from other people, and I have my gripes with the communities toxicity, but none of that has stopped me from playing. Then again, my idea of progress is much different than what the game advertises. Gold, glory, heart-hammering pvpve, and cool cosmetics are nifty, but I'm the type of player who enjoys looking up at the stars and lending a hand to new players.

The payoff of each session and the experiences I go through really do outweigh the negatives Sea of Thieves has, and with the Season 9 update, the seas have never been so lively and chaotic. Cheers to the days on the sea ahead!

Title: Sea of Thieves - A Swashbuckling Adventure on the High Seas

Sea of Thieves, developed by Rare and published by Xbox Game Studios, offers an unforgettable and whimsical pirate experience that has captured the hearts of adventurers and buccaneers alike. As an enthusiast of open-world games and cooperative multiplayer, I'm delighted to share my review of this one-of-a-kind pirate odyssey.

Gameplay (4.5/5):
Sea of Thieves stands out for its unique approach to cooperative multiplayer. Players form crews, each member taking on specific roles on a pirate ship. Whether you're steering the vessel, hoisting the sails, or manning the cannons, teamwork is essential for navigating the treacherous waters and engaging in thrilling ship-to-ship combat.

The open-world exploration is equally captivating. The game's whimsical art style and picturesque islands make for an inviting and immersive setting. Whether you're searching for buried treasure, solving riddles, or battling formidable skeleton crews, every voyage is an opportunity for adventure and discovery.

Cooperative Multiplayer (5/5):
The heart of Sea of Thieves lies in its cooperative multiplayer gameplay. Sailing with a crew of friends or even with strangers is an absolute delight. Communication and coordination are key to success, and the game encourages players to work together in creative and humorous ways.

From the camaraderie of manning a galleon to the chaos of repelling a skeleton assault on an island, the shared experiences with your crewmates are what truly make the game shine. Whether you're sharing tales of your conquests or embarking on epic voyages, the social aspect of Sea of Thieves is a testament to its charm.

Visuals and Sound (4/5):
Sea of Thieves features a vibrant and colorful art style that sets it apart from the gritty realism of many other pirate-themed games. The world is filled with lush islands, sparkling waters, and charming character designs. While the game may not boast the most realistic graphics, its visual style is a perfect fit for its whimsical tone.

The sound design is top-notch, from the creaking of your ship to the roaring of cannons during naval battles. The dynamic and atmospheric musical score adds to the sense of adventure, crescendoing as you engage in epic battles or serenading you as you explore the tranquil waters.

Content Updates and Progression (4/5):
Rare has committed to providing regular content updates to keep the game fresh. These updates introduce new quests, challenges, and cosmetics, ensuring that there's always something new to strive for. The game's progression system allows players to unlock cosmetic items to personalize their pirate's appearance.

While the game has come a long way since its initial release, some players may still find the progression system lacking in depth. However, the frequent content additions and events help mitigate this issue.

Conclusion (4.5/5):
Sea of Thieves is a swashbuckling adventure that excels in delivering a unique cooperative multiplayer experience. Its emphasis on camaraderie, exploration, and whimsical pirate antics make it an exceptional game for those seeking memorable adventures on the high seas. Whether you're sailing with a crew of friends or joining a group of like-minded pirates, Sea of Thieves offers an enchanting world where the journey is just as important as the treasure. It's a must-play title for anyone yearning to embrace their inner pirate and set sail for thrilling escapades on the open ocean.

125905216.review:
It goes without saying this game is beautiful. I can sit on the deck of a ship or shore of the sea and just take in the moment and just lose myself in it's presentation.

But let's be real - this game's experience is not going to be for everybody. Because at the heart, this is a game were we are all pirates. And that means stealing, killing, swindling, and double-crossing. There is no PvP on and off switch, even with the new opt-in on-demand PvP they've released. People are always going to be out to screw you over. And not everybody is into that and it's okay.

Me? I think the game would lose a lot if I lost that feel of always having to watch over my shoulder. And those funny moments with friendly players would mean so much less. Besides - I appreciate a good thief who can ghost my loot off my deck. When I realize somebody nicked a bit of my treasure without me noticing, it always makes me laugh and I raise a mug of grog in their honor as that's the kind of Pirate I hope to be.

With all that said, what carries this game for me more than anything is the soundtrack. Because let me tell you, I don't care how many different times they remix "Warpath" to thematically fit the boss fight I'm in, that track always manages to pump me up and get me ready to fight. Hell, I sometimes think I sub-consciously let myself die just to reset the track and I can hear that epic first minute of it over and over again. When that track plays, something takes hold of me and I just go "all in", no matter what's happening around me. 

That track reaches that is left of the warrior soul in me and ignites my fighting spirit like no other. And for that, I will always remember this game long after it's dead.

143820057.review:
I really want to like Sea of Thieves. I really do. It's a game with an amazing feel and atmosphere - I absolutely love the dynamic of crewing a ship with your friends against rival ships and sailing the seas looking for treasure and plunder. However, I feel like the philosophy and vision of the game is at odds with itself. 

On one end, the game expects you to devote long periods of time to solving riddles and puzzles to complete tasks and quests, while also making it extremely easy for other players to swoop in and destroy all that progress at a whim. In these many cases of PvP, you are always the one with everything to lose (your hard-earned treasure and progress) and, in my experience, it's not rare to end up in hours-long chases to even try to get away from other players. The game's devs have continually stated that the current state of affairs is in line with their vision for the game, despite continual calls from the community to add restrictions to PvP.

In the end, this game has become a joyless chore that doesn't seem to be worthy investment of time that it asks for and I wouldn't recommend it in the current state of its multiplayer.

128525308.review:
7h in and I'm seeing a bit of a problem. Was constantly asked to play this game and eventually got it as a present, so I relented. I expected very little and was still disappointed.

1) It's hard to tell whether you're playing with other players at all. We had no contact with any one for hours until suddenly our ship was stolen by another player who literally came out of nowhere (I know they were flown in via cannon). Fighting him proved problematic because the basic combat system lifted almost straight from Pre-1.9 Minecraft meant that there was no effective way of dispatching of a single trespasser, since we were out of bullets. Our ship got scuttled and we never saw them again. Last I heard from them was a "gg" and I didn't get a chance to return the gesture.

2) The game's weather system was designed specifically as an anti-fun mechanic, as lighting can strike a player at random at any time they aren't under a roof. It happens seemingly at random so your best bet seems to just hide and wait. So when the ONE time both of us got struck at the same time, the game decided we were clearly "struggling" on our island loot run and scuttled our ship and sent us to a new island. By the time we got back and and found where our loot was, the items started despawning and we lost some of it. Absolutely infuriating, and absolutely unfair to us.

3) It became painfully obvious quickly that this game doesn't care about any kind of vertical growth. Most of the things I could spend my gains of was cosmetics, most of which appeared to come in sets and was intended to be worn as a costume. This made earning money feel pretty meaningless.

4) Combat is pretty bare-bones. A 3 swing combo with a sword or five shots with any of 3 different types of firearms. Not exactly inspiring, and certainly not ringing of any real swashbuckling feel. Most of our fights against AI just boiled down to stepping into deeper water, shoot at the enemy, and win without a struggle. Some enemies made very little sense in how the worked and were not very fun to fight at all.

5) Player interactions seemed interesting at first, but the only encounters we had were kill on sight or both parties immediately avoiding each other. As a result, every safe harbour was a dead wasteland of NPCs offering services to sailors who would never see their shores. It felt like playing an abandoned MMO.

6) The inventory system was scientifically engineered to be the worst possible inventory system conceivable. No weight limit, but a strict limit on how many of each item you can carry. Food being the worst restricted -- especially since the food items heals for different amounts. This meant that a lot of the time looting islands was a matter of emptying out the inventory before going on shore and hope you take as little damage as possible. And while there were special loot crates to help carry certain items, that just goes to show how bad it really is. Just give us carry weight or limited inventory slots, pick one or the other.

7) The world is empty. Most of the time, the game is very quiet and most voyages are devoid of any real adversity off land. Aside from a random kraken encounter, most of the action was on land, against skeletons and ghosts. At least some NPC pirates/traders in the sea as shown in the tutorial would spice it up. Maybe they exist? But I certainly didn't see any.

8) The puzzles. What on Earth is going on with these treasure puzzles? So many of these treasure hunts had us reusing the same landmarks over and over again for different treasure scrolls to get loot. And the progress is shared between players. In an effort to expedite this slog, we started spreading out over the island and solving clues that related to our side exclusively, meaning most of the time I only saw my crewmates when we were on the ship. While efficient, it was hardly immersive.

Anyway, while I can say I had fun for most of the time I played, it was by and large only because I played it with someone I like and knew more about the game than me. I would never recommend this to a new player who didn't have a veteran to lean on going in. I may play this some more and check out some content I've yet to touch, but I don't see myself being a long-time player.

141668981.review:
Well after reaching Pirate Legend and Athena's fortune Champion titles,
I'm finally able to make a review of this game, I hope it will help you decide if this game is worth it! I'll probably update this review the further I play. For now I'll be talkin about the Adventure mode :)

Pros :
-Cool graphics and simulation of a pirate life.
-It's a game where you either get addicted or hate it in the first hours.
-Funnier with friends or randoms, but you'll learn so much faster in solo trust me.
-Satisfying sensation when you sink ennemies boats and grab their loot.
-Good game if you want to chill and kill time (but sometimes it can be stressful especially if you have a lot of loots and you're getting focused by a reaper or red flag emissaries).
-Active developer team (monthly updates, quick reactivity on problems in-game through their tweeter, so I would recommend to follow them there to not miss a thing and to always be aware of what's happening).

Cons:
-Intensive grind.
-Boring after a while.
-Lack of content eventhough it was way worse back when it came out in 2018.
-FPS optimization is a joke on islands (At full ultra I go from 120fps to 55 fps on big islands).
-PVP mechanic is old and boring (idk maybe they need to add some new guns or mechanics).
-Bugs after new updates are not even a surprise anymore.
-Servers issues is normal and the community is used to it (so an advice would be to never do an event the day it comes out because you probably won't receive your loot's coins, XP and achievements).
-Some events are only visible on their website and not in-game so sometimes you can miss them (Just stop it, we are lazy and hate to go through google to see our ♥♥♥ in-game event progression, just put it in game already ffs it's 2020).

Overall the game has a lot of problems but I still love the concept it does represent otherwise I wouldn't have reach one of the highest titles you can earn and I hope this game will continue to get the support it deserves. I haven't played such a great game in a while, so if you like intensive farming, bugs, coop and pvp but also the big map you're in the right place. We'll be waiting for you on the ocean :)

PS: If you're a veteran please help new players and don't bully them, that's what I do and I would have loved to be helped too when I started, so please do so they will always remember you, thanks fellow Legends.




Edit1: So after 3 months, the game is still awesome, probably one of the best open world in multiplayer that I've played in a while. Nothing better but to fish with friends during late nights.




Edit2: They finally added an Even tab in-game! Anyway I've been playing Arena, joined a competitive team and reached Legendary Sea Dog. So the Arena mode is way different from the actual game (adventure). It also have its pros and cons so here we go :

For the positive aspects :
- Helps you improve cannon shots
- Helps you improve your weapon accuracy
- TDM (Team deathmatch) is a lot of fun! It's like the endgame community event in the Arena
- You can make friends in this mode
- Since the last Arena patch, there's only one chest now and it's way better than before

Some negative aspects :
- Hitregs (When you hit players usually with weapons and you have the hitmarker but the server didn't register the damage, so sometimes you'll need to hit 3-4 time the player before he dies, and sometimes you may think they're cheater)
- Lobby waiting time : because the Arena mode is not the main mode, the playerbase is not that big here, so you might wait 10-30min in the worst case...
- Server region merge : Yeah well sometimes there's no server in EU (in my exemple) at certain hours and I usually get matched with NA players and I have an average of 200-250ms
- FPS optimization (Even on High-End PC you'll probably struggle to maintain a stable 144fps

Edit3:
They removed their own game mode called Arena. I don't know if it would now be an interesting game for pirate that love to pvp...
Quite a sad day for Sea of Thieves...

139392080.review:
A beautiful and unique game full of adventures but with the typical flaws of pvp and its toxic community.

I play SoT before the first season launched and return every now and then. It's a really adventurous game, filled with hours of fun, stuff you can archive, a lot to explore, good storylines and quests, events, riddles, fishing etc. Amazing game to play with friends and experience fun and wild stuff or (sometimes) to just relax and enjoy the whole setting of being a pirate.

The cons:
Sadly, as mentioned before... Sea of Thieves suffers a lot from its PvEvP concept in my eyes. Over the years i had enough encounters, which made me avoid playing it for a longer period, even deinstalling. It can get very frustrating, if you arent on the strong side of PvP skills and finding your joy rather in making friends and helping others, instead of stealing and srewing another player overf. My encounters with most PvP-Players so far, were more than disrespectful and highly toxic. From spawncamping, people laughing at you over voice, wild insults especially towards female gamers, getting ganked in a world events (like kraken, what is already enough struggle but makes you an easy target), people chasing you for literally hours over the sea and so on. I have the feeling, since they shut down the arena, it gotten even worse. If you go on reddit, you see people literally writing, that they play this game only to ruin someones day. To steal and win over someone, because "its sea of thives not sea of friends" after all. Many people don't even care about doing the PvE content and only feast on the people who do it, but aren't skilled enough to get their stuff back quick and safely.
Just as many others, I wish there would be some way to make it more PvE friendly, since all the stories and world events are mostly PvE based. There is nothing more frustrating, than spending hours in this game, just to get invaded by some pvp pros and losing literally everything you did since you visited an outpost last. The constant fear as someone who isn't really comfortable with the clonky pvp system of shotgun and animation cancles, that dominates the pvp interactions, being robbed and losing everything i did the past hour is really frustrating and taking a lot of fun away. Even after watching guide over guide about pvp tricks, im sadly still a noob. I probably would have less of an problem with the whole pvp, if it would just be shooting canons at each others, but sadly 90% of the pvp people shoot themselves on your ship, anchor you, kill you in less than a second while using the thinnest character model to be hard to hit and then spawncamp you until they sank your ship. 
I really wish there would be a system that allows you to decide if you want to do pvp or pve. Like a "warmode" you can turn on and get way more rewards for everything you do on the seas. More gold. More exp. More rep. So its appealing to people. High Risk. High Rewards. And for the people who dont want to pvp, they can peacefully enjoy the pirate life without getting screwed over and over, even if it takes way longer without the pvp mode. But sadly so far rare doesn't really plan on doing anything like this afaik.
Not gonna lie, if there would be another fun pirate game, i could play with my friends and just enjoy the world and PvE content, i would have left this game long ago. Sadly its the only one of its kind, so you stick by the toxic pvp people or forget about having a piratecrew with your friends.
Next to the pvp aspect another "small" flaw is the character creation for some players. You can't really create your own pirate and need to decide between randomly generated ones. Most of them look really ugly, but you can spend hours on rerolling until you find some better looking one.
And i want to mention, that a few of my friends, weren't able to play this game, since it caused motion sickness for them. So if you are weak on that spot, this might not be the right game for you.

The pros:
But ending on a lighter note. Just as you find a lot of toxic people in this game, you can also find a lot of friendly and fun fellow pirates aswell. The game gives you the option to form an alliance with other ships (which gives you about 50% of everything the ships in your alliance sell (way more profitable than pvp but people cant feel superior)). If you don't have anyone to play with, you can also join the official discord and get into a group with others and plan on doing certain content. I met some really nice people through this.
The graphics are still pretty damn fine and the water is AMAZING. The sailing itself is very fun, (when you aren't against the wind for once lol). 
There are many things to do. You can farm gold, reputation, archivements & cosmetics (as in outfits, hair, beards, tattoos, weapons, ship and so on). There are several stories to play through, very well written and entertaining, even emotional. You always have something to do, like fishing, exloring, solving riddles and much more. The random world events are great and  very exciting, especially canon fights are insanely fun!
The game also has amazing soundtracks! A great atmosphere all in all.
One of the biggest pros about the game is that it keeps getting updated and improved, even after all this years. The Devs taking amazingly good care of the game. The ingame purchases are cosmetics only. The battlepass is always amazing and so generous. One of the few real chad-battlepasses in all of the games i play/have played, where you get something every level even without the cash version. 
Even if i have many shitty memories and frustrating encounters in this game, i keep coming back to it, because if you aren't getting completely clapped it is really a masterpiece in my eyes. Like i said. One of a kind.

138940557.review:
Eh, it's alright. 


Not my cup of tea though, it's an alright casual adventure game for you and your friends but it takes a lot of time to get anything done which kind of makes it a "play this all day" kind of game instead of a "wind down for the night" kind of game.

I think it would be really neat if they did a world overhaul and added a lot more varied biomes, maybe some more horror elements like Subnautica has. I think you could do a lot with a pirate game in terms of fantastical art and inspired designed. For instance a mimic enemy would be super cool, maybe a skeleton octopus? I don't know how that would work but it'd look really cool. This game really isn't tied down to historical piracy, instead its more of a fantastical setting so there shouldn't be any limit on creativity here.

Uhhhh the combat's a little dull, again it's very casual, and it feels designed by committee to be as lackluster as possible (mostly talking PVE here, not that other thing where you get hit and instinctively cram five pineapples down your throat to negate all coming damage.). I think if they added like...some snazzy mordhau style combat it'd be really fun, maybe even some whack ass guns like pepperbox revolvers, volley guns, all that. I think it'd be really nice if they made it so you could upgrade your ship and it would have an actual gameplay effect, it could be permanent and locked to a certain amount of slots to your ship, or upgrades you can mount as you go in a single session (ex: a ram, canon sights, armor plates, cool stuff like that.).

Music's great, some fun classics and also original music in there. Story's okay, but it could get way weirder and it'd be a good time. Most of the grand voyages I've played have been kind of dull, also questing is uh...yikes.

Questin is uh...kinda why this game is not for me, I get flashbacks to modern WoW. Like, we did a voyage for order of souls where it was a bunch of bounties that were on various different islands. Getting to each island takes a little bit, and you sit on them and fight wave after wave of skeletons, with some really annoying special subtypes spawning (metal) and some just neglectable ones (the nature guys with da leaves), and you kill these hordes to get to the...named skeletons, and kill them, and collect their skulls. Because of how stock the combat is this quest isn't really that fun. Uhhhm, then there's the gold hoarder equivalent where you...sail to a bunch of different islands using a magical compass, go on the islands, and dig up portions of a treasure map belonging to a specific island, which...yeah that's as fun as it sounds. It's not super intriguing it's just a chore to do. Finally, the third of these quests is the shipwreck cargo recovery quest where you try to sus out where a shipwreck is to retrieve its loot, in theory it's cool but in practice your friends'll read through the quest and just do it themselves leading to you just sitting on a boat being a chore-boy and having orders barked at you. Most the other quests are kind of iterations on this sort of thing unless it's a legendary voyage.

Most of the time I played this game I got really bored and agitated that I wasted that much time on a game I didn't enjoy that much. I mostly wrote this because I just didn't want to think about this game anymore and finally just get my thoughts on it out.

So, it's a good game if you're not me, and you're fine with a game that's kind of lackluster in depth (funny because it's set in the sea). Also despite being kinda shallow it takes up 100 gigabytes on my computer, which uh yeah that knocks it down a few points.

132735546.review:
Literally played 5 hours straight and beat one mission, I feel I have a long journey ahead of me! So much stuff can happen, so I'll describe my first experience, as someone who went in blind :)
So, my friends wanted to bring me on a "Guilded Athena Voyage", so I tagged along. We fought a few skeleton ships, easy enough, fought off a kraken while being attacked by a player sloop and skeleton sloop, not so easy, and dug up a lot of treasure using the detailed maps of the islands. There were riddles that we had to solve, such as playing an instrument in a certain spot to reveal the next riddle. On all of the islands there are different enemies with different strategies, such as normal skeletons who you can just kill with any of the 4 weapons, golden skeletons who you should get wet so they "rust" and take more damage, shadow skeletons who you have to shine your lantern on to damage, ghosts, and sea creatures. Oh, and be careful with a skeleton holding a barrel. I'd back up if I were you.
The players aren't all bad either, for example we got attacked by a sloop while under siege from the kraken, but we also had a nice time with a random player on an island that we both happened to be at. We wished him well at the end, after all of us got everything we needed and killed a bunch of skeletons, and then sailed away.

129588624.review:
Nicotine is a naturally produced alkaloid in the nightshade family of plants (most predominantly in tobacco and Duboisia hopwoodii) and is widely used recreationally as a stimulant and anxiolytic. As a pharmaceutical drug, it is used for smoking cessation to relieve withdrawal symptoms.[8][5][9][10] Nicotine acts as a receptor agonist at most nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs), except at two nicotinic receptor subunits (nAChRα9 and nAChRα10) where it acts as a receptor antagonist.
Nicotine constitutes approximately 0.6–3.0% of the dry weight of tobacco. Nicotine is also present at ppb-concentrations in edible plants in the family Solanaceae, including potatoes, tomatoes, and eggplants, though sources disagree on whether this has any biological significance to human consumers. It functions as an antiherbivore toxin; consequently, nicotine was widely used as an insecticide in the past,] and neonicotinoids (structurally similar to nicotine), such as imidacloprid, are some of the most effective and widely used insecticides.

132766635.review:
seems like it might be a good game, and probably is if you don't have a job, many redditors to play with, and is all you do all day. combat is clunky and entirely co-op oriented. if you're playing solo, you're in for a really bad time. sure, you could spend hundreds of hours "getting good" trying to solo sloop, but there is little room for improvement when either every other player is a seasoned veteran at solo-ing, so good they sink in semi instantly, or theyre a child who doesnt know how to play the game, neither of which are particularly good to improve your pvp skills. what? dont like pvp? well good news! theres single player content, except its boring, easy, and very tedious. it is gta online levels of grind with no benefit besides some cosmetics (some of which are locked behind hundreds of hours of pvp grind, and ancient coins, which are essentially this games v-bucks). if youre just getting into this for pvp, youre also going to have a bad time because hitbox detection in this game is easily some of the worst ive ever seen in a video game, and its consistently bad. sometimes even indicating that you hit them but no damage or knockback, seemingly all while the other players hit every one of their shots and switch through their items on a dime. speaking of other players, there are alot of hackers. some of them will teleport to your ship and spawn kill you, others use aimbot and directly hit you with CANNONS. 
if you want a good pvp game, go play fortnite or any souls like. if you want a "good" grindy game, go play runescape, or literally any rpg. if you want a good combination, well good luck finding one. gta online was the first example of why combining these 2 style of games isnt very fun, and this game sadly follows its steps. it has a lot of potential, has good graphics, cool art style and theme, i mean, pirates are bad ass, but that hardly excuses the bad, and often frustratingly slow gameplay. if you have a group of friends who already play the game ALOT, this might be a good game for you, but if youre just a gamer trying to chill out during the weekend after work, dont get this. it takes more time than i can describe to get anywhere, or to even improve. and this isnt just "skill issues" this is serious problems with net code and overall gameplay designs. i consider myself at least somewhat good at pvp games, i play alot of fortnite, darksouls, elden ring, splatoon, but none of those have been as much as a problematic experience as this one. this just isnt any fun for a solo player.

124009890.review:
This is the most frustrating game I have ever played. What I wanted was ship battles. What I got was endless boarding parties that drop your anchor. Where are the ship battles?

The PvE can be fun. The wife, kid, and I enjoy doing a few fortresses to gain some gold and supplies. What I enjoy about the game is what the game offers the least of and that is  the ship battles. 

We got in 3 ship battles with skeleton ships today. The 1st was vs a sloop and we killed it easily and got the loot. The second was vs a sloop and a storm suddenly arose basically ending that fight. The 3rd was vs a galleon. The fight starts off enjoyable and then the fog appears. That added some tense moments of the galleon appearing out of no where which was fun and immersive. Then came the Meg. We sink the galleon and then have to sail off to escape the Meg. This day was probably the most fun that we have had even though it felt like the game was putting endless blocks in our path to obtaining loot.

A normal day goes more like, hit 3 forts and hit an outpost to sell the loot. Reaper ship appears out of no where and isnt on the map and sinks you while your docked and running back to the ship. I am not sure why people find this part of the game enjoyable. Who enjoys taking 15 to 20 mins to run loot back and forth. Talk about monotonous. Id prefer that ships engage you before you reach port and actually have, you know, a ship battle. This game encourages you to avoid ship battles and look for easy prey which is mostly boring.

While I do enjoy the ship battles, everything else feels like a time sink put in place to expose you. I dont want to unload goods for 20 mins. That isnt game play. Personally I would prefer semi protected outposts that defend docked ships. You want to gank people, do it on the open sea or at a fortress or world event or anywhere thats not an outpost. Also, less loot thats worth more. Turning in 20 items take forever. Especially the skulls and trinkets. Its so slow that I mostly just leave those items where I found them. Id rather turn in 10 items and save the 10 minutes so I can go back to sailing...

As a side note, my son plays on a steam deck docked at 1080p with a keyboard and it plays well. The only issue that we have is that it shows controller buttons.

Shrug...

146821412.review:
Sea of Thieves is a crewing game about treasure and sailing.  The treasure's value is likely worthless and the sailing mechanics aren't real but serviceable.  Oh and you can play 1-player but can't achieve anything doing that.

I really want to like this game.  The theme is fun.  The graphics are basic but have some real beauty at times.  But the game play kind of sucks.  Or rather, anything but sailing around sucks and there's little to be gained just sailing around and anything you gain has a decent likelihood of getting lost in combat against players.  The combat itself unbalanced & janky against human players and slow & boring against the AI.  There's treasure to be gained at all corners of the map but worthwhile treasure is, at best, super obscure -- looking up guides is necessary.  And since gaining the treasure "legitimately" is so time consuming and risky, it makes PVP the strategy that is lowest risk and highest reward.  Which is where the primarily problem with the game -- the combat -- comes up.  It's really a pity too because some of the locales you can go to appear interesting -- ultimately barren or behind some lock -- but visually interesting.

146076229.review:
SOT can be a fun game. It's the only one I've managed to play so far that gives you the feeling of being a pirate. But it unfortunately suffers from not only being an online only game, but your only option of playing is a multiplayer. It does give the game a tense feeling whenever you see a silhouette of a ship in the distance and it doesn't have the lights of a skeleton ship. But that's because any time you see a player ship, they're either doing their own thing, or they're just there to fight you and NOTHING ELSE. I at the time of making this don't plan to go back in, but my last playthrough involved joining an alliance with 2 ships, going to the fort of fortune, and having a blast. And then a random sloop blew up some barrels we had, sunk our ship, and we lost ALL of our loot and our emissary level. This was my first time reaching emissary level 5.

Without an option for a private server or a true solo play, I personally can't enjoy this game anymore. This game is exclusively risk reward and it's almost never reward, unless you some minor voyages, and even then you'll be harassed by players AND AI. It's irritating sailing to an outpost and you get pattered by a skeleton galleon as a one person sloop, managing to get away, and now you're being chased by a skeleton sloop AND a Megaledon, only to be stopped by a Kraken right after and the Meg is still swimming around you. I JUST WANT GOLD, BUT I CAN'T WHEN THERE'S MORE ENEMIES AROUND ME THAN CANNONS I CAN PHYSICALLY USE!!

If you want to be some pirates with your friends, go ahead, but if you want a peaceful game, don't even bother.

Update: I have heard about them adding private servers. But since it will be putting a cap on leveling up to 50, then it's not good enough for me. I'm already level 53 in Gold Hoarders, the only faction I care about. So I'm still not playing this crap.

143125534.review:
Be warned.  This game is incredibly dangerous for burning your time.  Between the plethora of things you can do, the exciting tedium of captaining the ships, and the long journey through the daring seas.  You will find yourself playing for handful hours at a time.  

The pace of the game is rather slow and exhausting, but it benefits the game feel a lot.  There is simply so much to do.  It gives you time to chat, look at treasure maps and plan your routes, fish, play some songs and look around for random world events.  A Simple voyage to track down the whereabouts of a captain's shipment, turns into hours of side looting to stack as much of a payout as possible.

If I have 1 gripe, it's that pvp can be very exhausting.  Especially for newer players.  What was an incredibly cool interaction initially, became sour with how resilient a group can be.  As long as players are paying attention to the repairs of their ship, it can be incredibly difficult to sink another player's ship.  So pvp matches between two players can take literal hours.  Plural.  That stays that way until you realize that naval combat is more balanced towards putting pressure on the enemy, to then open them to being boarded, killed, and thus finally sunk.  pvp on foot is a little stale as it is balanced towards who can one shot the other person first.  You will just have to play to learn all the tricks and tools you can use.  It's just annoying how pvp can take a long time, and players can force that on you by chasing you endlessly.

142987574.review:
⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

Ahoy there, fellow pirates! If you're looking for an exhilarating, swashbuckling adventure on the high seas, look no further than Sea of Thieves. Rare's masterpiece is a game that has captured my heart and imagination since its launch, and it continues to impress with each new update and expansion.

Sea of Thieves offers a unique and immersive pirate experience that no other game can match. From the moment you set sail on your majestic ship, you'll be enchanted by the stunning water and weather effects, which bring the open world to life in a way that feels both realistic and fantastical. The attention to detail in the game is truly commendable, and you'll find yourself lost in its beauty and charm.

What truly sets Sea of Thieves apart is its emphasis on cooperation and camaraderie. While you can sail solo, the game truly shines when you team up with a crew of your fellow scallywags. Whether you're steering the ship, adjusting the sails, or manning the cannons during a heated sea battle, the feeling of unity and shared objectives is unparalleled. It's a bonding experience like no other, and you'll create unforgettable memories as you face storms, sea monsters, and rival pirate crews together.

The freedom to explore the vast open world is liberating. There are countless islands to discover, each with its own secrets, puzzles, and buried treasures waiting to be unearthed. The thrill of stumbling upon a sunken shipwreck, solving a riddle to find buried loot, or battling an undead horde in a cursed cave is an adrenaline rush that never gets old.

However, be prepared to face other pirates who might not be as friendly as your own crew. PvP encounters can be intense and nerve-wracking, but they add a layer of unpredictability and excitement to the game. Trust me, there's no greater satisfaction than outmaneuvering your adversaries in a thrilling sea skirmish.

The developers have done an excellent job of supporting the game post-launch, constantly introducing fresh content and meaningful updates. From new trading companies and commendations to the addition of majestic sea creatures, the evolving world of Sea of Thieves keeps players coming back for more.

Of course, no game is without its flaws, but the overall experience of Sea of Thieves far outweighs any minor shortcomings. The community is generally friendly and welcoming, and if you ever need a helping hand, you'll find plenty of pirates willing to lend one.

Fair winds and following seas, me hearties! 🏴‍☠️

142745776.review:
The game's graphics are beautifully rendered, bringing to life a vivid and colorful pirate world that feels like it's straight out of a storybook. The attention to detail in the environments, from sandy beaches to stormy waters and lush tropical islands, creates an immersive experience that captivates players from the moment they step aboard their ship.

The heart of Sea of Thieves lies in its cooperative multiplayer mechanics. Players can team up with friends or strangers to crew a pirate ship, each taking on distinct roles such as steering, navigating, manning the cannons, or repairing the ship. This teamwork aspect fosters a strong sense of camaraderie and adventure, as players must communicate and coordinate their actions to navigate treacherous waters, face off against deadly skeleton hordes, or outmaneuver rival pirate crews in exciting ship-to-ship battles.

Moreover, the game's sandbox nature allows for emergent gameplay, ensuring that no two adventures are ever the same. As players explore the vast open world, they encounter unpredictable events, like chasing down a legendary sea monster, stumbling upon hidden treasure maps, or unraveling mysterious riddles to uncover buried loot. This unpredictability adds a sense of excitement and unpredictability to every session.

Sea of Thieves also embraces a "play your way" philosophy, granting players the freedom to pursue various objectives at their own pace. Whether you prefer engaging in combat, hunting for treasure, or simply enjoying the thrill of exploration, the game accommodates different playstyles, making it appealing to a wide range of gamers.

In summary, Sea of Thieves is a captivating and visually stunning multiplayer experience that transports players into a swashbuckling world of piracy and adventure. Its cooperative gameplay mechanics, beautiful art style, and open-world exploration make it an enjoyable and immersive gaming experience. So, if you're ready to raise the anchor, hoist the sails, and embark on an unforgettable pirate escapade, Sea of Thieves is undoubtedly a game worth diving into.

142689821.review:
Have 600+ hours including the version from Microsoft Store. A lot of that is solo slooping and some solo brigging.

This game has taught me a lot about loss and how to lose while keeping a good attitude. Used to get pretty upset when I would get sunk, but learned how to defend my loot and scout the horizon for potential threats. I don't sink as often and when I do I take mental notes and figure out what mistakes I made so I can improve for the next session. Nothing better than turning in loot that someone tried to steal from you. Noticed some of these experiences have carried over to my personal life and allowed me to go for opportunities I probably wouldn't have before. Risk vs reward is a core mechanic present every minute of gameplay.

Truly a unique game, something really special that gives an experience that I haven't really found in other games. It's what keeps me coming back.

142221107.review:
TLDR: The game is extremely well made, with stunning visual effects and a lot of content ranging from PvP, Tall Tales (Storyline), PvE, and mechanics. The main downside for some people is that the game heavily relies on PvP, which, in my opinion, makes the game better.


~ Storyline ~

The game itself is based on doing voyages and/or battling other crews for their loot. This means there is no real storyline in the base game but rather in "Tall Tales", which are a separate part of the game where you complete missions to unlock exclusive rewards. With this in mind, you don't have to go through the storyline, but it's rather a fun thing to do on the side of normal gameplay.


~ Difficulty ~

Sea of Thieves is a game that heavily relies on PvP but also some PvE; this means that there will be a big skill gap between the players who tend to fight other crews and the PvE enthusiasts. I know this will annoy some people, but in my opinion, the game is made for pirate interactions: stealing, fighting, etc. Some may say that it's not kind to steal someone's loot, but in the end, that is what the game is all about.


~ Graphics ~

The game has stunning visuals, sound effects, and creatures. Sea of Thieves has a very good art style because it fits perfectly into being a pirate while also not being too realistic to not look like a game. Since the game has so many details, the storage space required is a lot more than for many other games, which brings me to my next point: PC requirements.


~ Requirements ~

As mentioned in the graphics section, the game requires quite a lot of processing. This means that you will need a pretty good PC to run it. You can find the exact requirements on the store page under "System Requirements".

TLDR: 
-SA servers are terrible when it comes to connection and community overall (toxicity is not punishible, racism is a normal ocurrence). 

-Cheaters all over the place with no way of reporting them for actually cheating. 

-Solo experience is terrible and not worth "getting gud at it" is just a tedious experience with little reward, just to lose everything with 1 single mistake.

 

Review from a South American player...
 -Sadly... when it comes to playing in South America you have to play in brazilian servers... which are the WORSE! ping is terrible... and the stability of brazilians has always been terrible... NO my internet is not dogshit, I have played with friends in NA and ping stability is chef's kiss.

 I am CRYING for a server selector so I can play in NA servers by my own... but nop... Rare doesn't want you doing that. Reason as to why I'm asking for a server selector is because since the south american player base is so small... brazilian players always team up with themselves... if they find out you are not brazilian or you don't speak portuguese they IMMEDIATELY target you. For the record I don't mean "target you" as in going against you in PvP but they would shout racial slurs 24/7 until you sink or decide to scuttle your ship. According to their logic I should kill myself for not being brazilian like????? and you can't even report this... The only report options you have are for "insulting named ships/pet/player names"...

 I take it as if Rare doesn't care about toxicity in their game whatsoever, YES! you can mute... but that doesn't mean they are not insulting others or you.

 I am posting this review after 200 hours (mostly of me solo slooping) and this terrible experience has happened to me more than 90% of the time that I wanna play the game. AGAIN I am not complaining about losing fights as a solo slooper, I am complaining how the devs allow this type of behaviour with no punishment whatsoever.

 Friendly reminder that this game is rated PEGI 12...

 Now for the times that I've had the wonderful opportunity to play on NA servers, it has been a blast, the game just works completely different!. I now that NA has toxicity problems as well... but since SA has a smaller player base... yeah... is just terrible dude...

- NOW! the cheating problem... HOLY MOLY is UNREAL the ammount of people that cheat in this game, specially PvP Hourglass... from teleporting to walls to fixed cannon aim to even being immortal... and boy O BOY! you cannot report this... of course... Now... I thought that MAYBE you can report this in the forums with video evidence but nop... posting about it is actually forbidden in their forums LIKE WHAT?! so... people can just cheat and be the most racist peaces of shit with NO REPERCUSSIONS! wow... just amazing...

 I'm honestly scared to see how cheating can escalate to the point where they can mess with your PC, I'm begging we don't reach that point but still...

 -Solo slooping experience... is... terrible!, the game punishes you for being a solo player... even if you are really but REALLY! good at it... is not worth it... the ammount of effort you have to put for a small reward is unreal... is just tedious work... even if you don't wanna engage in PvP is gonna be a miserable experience...

 If for some reason... you still decide to play this game alone... good luck friend... that's all I can say...

 -Playing with friends or people you know, sure! is actually really fun with friends the only thing that is just not fun at all... sweatlords... basically people who have NEVER stopped playing the game and that for some reason take the game too seriously... but other than that you are set to enjoy the game and what it has to offer.

 Keep in mind that the game doesn't have a system that puts you with/against people that has like a close "skill level" to yours so... yeah... you are gonna find that no life player just farming casuals all day long. This not only applies to normal adventure mode but for PvP hourglass as well... which... is weird since hourglass is supposed to be THE place if you wanna engage in PvP but I'm telling you... farming hourglass PvP is... not fun, is not casual friendly, for some reason people are REALLY competitive about it... and no... there is not even like a leaderboard for wins or something like that...

 Reason as to why I'm posting this review in english is to raise awareness to a bigger population of people, sorry If my grammar or use of the language is terrible but as you may have noticed english is not my main language. Sorry for such a big wall of text but I just cannot comprehend how a game is rated for such a young audience and not being safe at all... you are basically paying money to feel bad about yourself and just feel miserable, while people just hack like there is no tomorrow while being really toxic...

 Thanks for reading (to those who actually did) and stay safe!

141861198.review:
Until you start grasping "the point" of the game it can be quite frustrating for many reasons. So as a relatively new player myself, my best advice is to simply play it to have fun. Do not focus too much on your failures. You will have a lot of them. Just learn from them and see them as part of the adventure. And if a situation becomes too heated or stressful, simply set sail and get the hell out of there. You might not get away, but you owe no one anything in this game, and if a situation isn't fun, just leave it behind and go do something you enjoy instead.

There are no real ways to progress in the game beyond cosmetics. That's both a pro and a con for the game. A pro since it means all players are on the same level. A con since the game lacks any sort of character progression towards getting better equipment or skills. There is none of that. So it relies entirely on the sense of wonder and adventure. But know that it is REALLY good at that stuff. So you will have plenty of fun stuff to do simply by playing, learning, playing and learning.

You will meet other players who look like mean bastards. But at the end of the day they carry the same weapons and cannons as you do. The difference is experience. So you will probably get beaten up by some of these guys. Other guys might just leave you alone. There seems to be some sort of unwritten pirate code among the more experienced players, but they are completely voluntary. I'm still learning about that stuff.

One thing I have to note is the insanely creative ways this game is designed. I won't spoil anything, but you will happen upon some really cool stuff that takes place all around you. The world feels very much alive. And it is pretty much the perfect pirate experience. And the looks of the game and the music and audio is absolutely brilliant. It's just perfect in my opinion. Running around with that fat loot sounds just right.

I'm glad I only just started playing the game in 2023. There is much more content nowadays than at release. And it really helps that feeling of adventure that there are soooo, soooo many things to do. Adventure is always just around the corner!

UPD: Go play Skull and Bones

In summary, this pirate adventure game is a mixed bag of treasures and challenges. Its immersive world, regular updates, and focus on teamwork make it a thrilling choice for players looking for a unique multiplayer experience. However, the steep learning curve, text-heavy story, and required constant online presence may discourage some. It's a voyage not for the faint-hearted but rewarding for those ready to face the high seas of challenge. If you're up for an authentic pirate adventure, don't shy away from setting sail with this one!

140832106.review:
Having spent a considerable amount of time in the immersive, pirate-infested world of Sea of Thieves, both on and outside of Steam, I can safely say that it's a seafaring journey worth embarking on. Rare has created a game that balances the tranquillity of sailing across beautifully rendered oceans with the high-stakes thrill of pirate combat, all while weaving in threads of exploration and discovery.

Sea of Thieves offers an open-world multiplayer experience set within a beautifully crafted seafaring universe. You can sail solo or assemble a crew of friends to navigate your ship, search for treasure, and engage in combat with other players or the game's variety of NPC enemies. This sandbox-style gameplay gives you the freedom to live out your pirate dreams on your terms.

One of the game's most commendable aspects is its naval mechanics. Sailing is not just a mode of transport but a fully-fledged part of the game. The attention to detail in handling your ship, from raising and lowering sails to angling them for optimal wind catch, navigating using your compass and map, and patching up your ship when it takes damage, all contribute to an incredibly immersive seafaring experience.

The game’s combat, both naval and on foot, is intense and rewarding. Whether you’re firing cannons at an enemy galleon, or engaged in swordplay and gunfire on a sandy beach, the combat in Sea of Thieves is always exciting. It might seem straightforward at first, but there's depth to it, especially during the larger battles where strategy and communication with your crew can mean the difference between victory and a trip to the Ferry of the Damned.

The graphics and art style of Sea of Thieves is another high point. The game is visually stunning, boasting a unique, painterly art style that perfectly captures the romantic allure of the high seas and the lush, mysterious appeal of unexplored islands. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle also deserve a mention, as they significantly contribute to the game’s atmosphere. Sailing under a starlit sky or in the middle of a storm is a sight to behold.

As for sound design, the game does an excellent job of immersing you in its world. The ambient sounds of the ocean, the creaking of your ship, the distant roar of a cannon, all add to the overall immersion. The shanties you can play with your crew are a delightful touch that adds to the camaraderie and fun of the game.

The game's questing system, represented by voyages and tall tales, provides a wide array of objectives for you to pursue. Whether it’s treasure hunting, bounty hunting, or cargo delivery, the voyages offer varied gameplay. The Tall Tales, on the other hand, serve as the game's main storyline quests. They're filled with puzzle-solving, exploration, and exciting lore about the Sea of Thieves world.

One area where Sea of Thieves may polarize players is its lack of a traditional progression system. While you can acquire cosmetic items and reputations, there are no upgrades to your abilities or stats. This ensures an even playing field where skill and strategy reign supreme, but it might not appeal to those who prefer a more tangible sense of character progression.

Lastly, the social interaction in Sea of Thieves is something to highlight. The game fosters a strong sense of camaraderie when played with friends and even encourages interaction with other player crews. However, be prepared for possible encounters with less friendly pirates.

In conclusion, Sea of Thieves is a rich, immersive, and beautifully crafted game that captures the spirit of piratical adventure. It is a game that doesn’t just allow you to play as a pirate - it truly makes you feel like one. Despite its minor drawbacks, its breathtaking world, exhilarating combat, in-depth sailing mechanics, and fun multiplayer interactions make it a game I wholeheartedly recommend.
