140809069.review:
Ahoy, fellow adventurers! If you're seeking a game that immerses you in a vast world of piracy, treasures, and endless excitement, then look no further than Sea of Thieves. Rare's masterpiece has undoubtedly carved a place in my heart with its boundless content, diverse gameplay options, and exhilarating encounters. Allow me to share my experiences and highlights, including the thrilling boss battles with the Kraken, Megalodons, and Skeleton ships, which have left me awaiting the addition of the Hydra, possibly foreshadowed with not only the Sea Serpent Ship Set but also the Fates of Fortune ship set.

One of the most striking aspects of Sea of Thieves is the sheer amount of content it offers. From the moment you set sail on your trusty vessel, the world unfolds before you like an open canvas, inviting you to embark on your own pirate tale. Whether you choose to set off solo, form a crew with friends, or join forces with other players in shared adventures, the possibilities are endless. The game accommodates various play styles, ensuring that every pirate can find their niche and create unforgettable memories. 

The small boss fights in Sea of Thieves are a true testament to the game's thrilling nature. The encounters with the Kraken, Megalodons, and Skeleton ships provide pulse-pounding moments, bringing a welcome dose of intensity to the already captivating gameplay. Each battle is a unique and immersive experience, requiring teamwork, strategy, and quick reflexes to emerge victorious. The adrenaline rush as you face off against these formidable foes is simply unmatched. They can be a bit of an annoyance when you are just sailing around normally, but they do add excitement to a possibly empty session of nothing but sailing. The way they interact with a PvP battles also adds onto said system.

That being said, the desire for even grander boss fights is undeniable. Imagine setting sail to confront a fearsome creature like the Hydra, with its multiple heads emerging from the depths of the sea. The anticipation of such encounters would undoubtedly add another layer of excitement to an already incredible game. It is my hope that future updates or expansions will introduce new mythical creatures or colossal threats to test our mettle as pirates.

In addition to the thrilling encounters, Sea of Thieves offers a plethora of activities to engage in during your adventures. From hunting for buried treasure to engaging in high-stakes naval battles, from uncovering hidden lore to partaking in daring raids, there is no shortage of things to do. The game rewards exploration and curiosity, encouraging players to stray off the beaten path and discover hidden gems that await in the vast open world.

Sea of Thieves offers an exhilarating PvP experience that adds an extra layer of excitement and unpredictability to the already immersive pirate world. The game's PvP encounters are nothing short of thrilling, as you never know when you might encounter rival crews on the high seas or engage in intense skirmishes on remote islands. The freedom to choose your playstyle, whether it's adopting a cunning approach or embracing an all-out assault, creates an ever-evolving dynamic that keeps players on their toes.

What makes Sea of Thieves' PvP truly exceptional is the perfect balance between risk and reward. Every encounter with another crew presents an opportunity for intense battles and strategic maneuvers. Whether you're engaged in ship-to-ship combat, fighting over precious loot, or engaging in thrilling boarding actions, the rush of adrenaline is palpable. The game's mechanics, including cannon fire, swordplay, and the use of firearms, are finely tuned to create satisfying and skill-based combat interactions. It's a PvP experience that rewards teamwork, clever tactics, and quick reflexes, providing an exhilarating sense of accomplishment with every hard-fought victory.

In conclusion, Sea of Thieves is a triumph in the world of pirate-themed gaming. Its abundance of content, diverse gameplay options, and thrilling encounters are a testament to Rare's dedication to delivering an unforgettable experience. While we eagerly await the addition of content like The Legend of Monkey Island, there's no denying that this game is a treasure trove of adventure waiting to be explored. So gather your crew, hoist the anchor, and set sail for a world of endless possibilities. Yo-ho-ho!

140763745.review:
A Swashbuckling Adventure Awaits: Sea of Thieves Review

Ahoy, matey! If you're searching for an unforgettable nautical adventure that will leave you breathless and craving for more, look no further than Sea of Thieves. This captivating masterpiece developed by Rare has transformed the gaming landscape, immersing players in a vast, beautiful, and treacherous pirate world like no other. As a seasoned seafarer or a landlubber looking for thrilling escapades, Sea of Thieves delivers an experience that will truly steal your heart.

One of the most striking aspects of Sea of Thieves is its stunning visual presentation. The art style is a feast for the eyes, with vibrant colors, breathtaking sunsets, and mesmerizing water effects that make every voyage feel like a living painting. Whether you're sailing through calm seas or braving fierce storms, the attention to detail is impeccable, creating an atmosphere that is both awe-inspiring and immersive.

But Sea of Thieves isn't just about breathtaking visuals; it's about the spirit of adventure. As you embark on your pirate journey, you're given the freedom to explore an expansive open world, filled with secrets, hidden treasures, and mythical creatures. Whether you choose to sail alone or assemble a crew of friends, the possibilities are endless. The cooperative gameplay mechanics foster teamwork and communication, making each voyage a unique and exhilarating experience.

The heart and soul of Sea of Thieves lie in its emergent storytelling. The game does not hold your hand or lead you through a linear narrative. Instead, it allows players to create their own tales of plunder and discovery. From encountering hostile pirate crews to unearthing buried treasure or engaging in intense naval battles, every moment in Sea of Thieves is an opportunity for adventure and unpredictable encounters. The sense of anticipation and excitement is palpable, as you never know what lies beyond the horizon.

The progression system in Sea of Thieves strikes a perfect balance between skill and achievement. As you complete quests, defeat adversaries, and uncover hidden secrets, you earn reputation and unlock new cosmetic items, ship upgrades, and commendations. This sense of progression rewards both dedication and skill, encouraging players to push their limits and become legendary pirates.

Rare has also shown exceptional dedication to post-launch support, consistently delivering meaningful updates and expansions that enhance the game's depth and variety. From the introduction of new regions, quests, and enemy types to seasonal events and quality-of-life improvements, the developers continue to breathe new life into the game, ensuring that the Sea of Thieves community always has something exciting on the horizon.

Sea of Thieves is more than just a game; it's an invitation to embark on an unforgettable journey of piracy, camaraderie, and exploration. It's a testament to the power of shared adventures and the boundless creativity that emerges when players are given the freedom to chart their own course. So, gather your crew, hoist the anchor, and set sail for the Sea of Thieves. Your destiny as a legendary pirate awaits!

Reviewer's Note: Sea of Thieves has truly set a new standard for immersive multiplayer experiences. Its ability to foster cooperation, emergent storytelling, and thrilling gameplay makes it an essential addition to any pirate enthusiast's collection. With its constant updates and passionate developer support, Sea of Thieves continues to evolve, making it a treasure trove of joy and excitement for players around the world.

138994241.review:
If you are looking for a review on Sea of Thieves you have come to the wrong place but, I can tell you how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

138073729.review:
If you are looking for a review on Sea of Thieves you have come to the wrong place but, I can tell you how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

138030224.review:
[i]Edit post-"Safer Seas" announcement[/i]

So, I uninstalled this shortly after writing that last review, which I think was in like May of 2023. At that time, I made this thing walk my NVMe's plank for two reasons: 1. the PVP and II: the fact that it's still 90 god damn gb. I wanna talk about the first thing, tho much noise has been made of the PVP experience in SoT already and there's not much useful that yet another casual Tall Talesman could add to this.

The last time I played this game, my ship got sunk while moored off of Thieves' Haven. Major crime, right, 3-month noob sinking an unmanned ship isn't big shakes; for the guy who sunk me, tho, it seemed to be free therapy. And what followed that was... I don't even know how to describe it, behavior that one would never see in any other game (except for possibly the aforementioned Rust, but even then?) Like, if it just stopped at basic slurs, one could just chalk it up to typical small dick hijinks and leave it at that. But yeah, it was incomprehensible stuff (and he really only called me something once, with the epithets not getting much worse than "retard.") Thing is, I left that game silently after that, not quite sure if my last outing in Sea of Thieves was shared with a potential fucking school shooter. It was weird and haunting.

So sack up, bitch, right? Quit being a pussy and go get another boat and quit ruining the experience for the rest of the sweats! "It's called of Sea of Thieves and not Sea of Friends," you might be thinking to yourself, when you're not wondering what uncovered boobies actually look like. Yeah see, here's the thing: I have a friend who doesn't let his kid play TF2 because of an experience he had where he was told to murder himself; to me, who's been part of the notoriously "toxic" TF2 community since W was in office, this is just another round on Dustbowl. But he'll let his kid play SoT without supervision, and has done so since he was 9 years old? 8?

To call the Sea of Thieves player base "toxic" is to undermine the potency of arsenic, but the ESRB lists this game as OK for Teens. It is not. Which means it certainly isn't OK for younger children.

The reaction to the "Safer Seas" update is more than telling in this regard: PvP players calling Hunter's Call and PvE players the "actually toxic ones," accusations of Rare "killing the game by splitting the players" and, most ironically - yet predictably - PvP diehards balking at the idea of having to engage with [i]only other PvPers on an open server.[/i]

So why is this still a thumbs up? Good question, and I hope this serves for a good answer: Sea of Thieves is a good game what's only negative quality is its own cannibalistic player base. Rare can make all the claims to amends that it wants to, but that's a cultural problem no amount of chat filters and server segregation could ever fix.

[i]Original re-edited edit[/i]

Absolutely couldn't stand it the first time I played - at worst, Rust but with cartoon pirates and 3 guns. Bad luck led me to experiencing Sea of Thieves' "at worst" right off the bat [i](edit, Sept 2023 - lol so young, so innocent)[/i]. Why no, Captain, I do not like anal; not without proper introductions, anyway.

Played it years later with actual people, amounting to a completely different experience; and then I learned to solo, which elevated the whole affair to sublime. How? Couldn't tell you, unless you were also one of those weirdos that got off on just aimlessly sailing in Wind Waker. IYKYK.

There's good shit here, but you should start with some good people to find it.

138008971.review:
Sea of Thieves is a unique and immersive multiplayer pirate adventure game that offers a fun and engaging gameplay experience. The game takes players on a journey across the seas, where they can explore a vast open-world, uncover hidden treasures, and battle against other pirate crews.

One of the standout features of Sea of Thieves is its open-world gameplay. The game allows players to sail their own ship, explore islands, and interact with other players in a fully-realized world. The game's mechanics are easy to pick up, but mastering them requires skill and strategy, making the game challenging and rewarding for players of all skill levels.

Sea of Thieves' multiplayer mode is where the game truly shines. The game allows players to team up with friends and battle against other players in epic ship-to-ship battles. The game's cooperative gameplay mechanics ensure that teamwork is essential for success, which adds a lot of depth and strategy to the gameplay.

Visually, Sea of Thieves is stunning, with a colorful and vibrant art style that is both immersive and enjoyable to look at. The game's sound design is equally impressive, with a dynamic soundtrack and realistic sound effects that add to the overall atmosphere of the game.

Overall, Sea of Thieves is a fantastic pirate adventure game that offers a fun and engaging gameplay experience. The game's open-world gameplay, cooperative multiplayer mode, and stunning visuals make it a must-play for anyone who enjoys adventure games. If you're looking for a game that will transport you to a world of high seas and adventure, then Sea of Thieves is definitely worth checking out.

Ahoy there, matey! I've been sailing the seven seas in Sea of Thieves, and let me tell ya, it's been a wild ride. I've battled sea monsters, dug up treasure, and even had a dance-off with a skeleton pirate (spoiler alert: I won).

The graphics are stunning, and the sound effects make you feel like you're actually on a creaky old pirate ship. But the real highlight for me has been the hilarious shenanigans that ensue when you play with a group of friends.

We once spent an entire hour trying to launch ourselves out of a cannon onto an enemy ship, only to end up crashing into a rock and sinking our own vessel. It was a disaster, but we were all laughing so hard we didn't even care.

So if you're looking for a fun, lighthearted adventure on the high seas, Sea of Thieves is definitely worth checking out. And who knows, maybe you'll even become a legendary pirate like me (or at least get some sweet Steam points for your review). Yo ho ho and a bottle of rum!

137724495.review:
Sea of Thieves is a unique game that provides players with the ultimate pirate experience. While the game may have its faults, it has a charm that makes it a worthwhile addition to any gamer's library.

One of the standout features of the game is the ability to buy your own ship. This wasn't always an option, and it's a great motivator for players to grind for cash and earn their own vessel. Owning your own boat makes a real difference to the way you play, and adds a sense of ownership to the game that's hard to beat.

However, one thing that could be improved is the combat system. While the game does offer the option to fight in 1v1 battles using the hourglass, it's not the same as engaging in normal battles on the open sea. Too often (in open sea), other crews will start to run away, leading to a frustrating half-hour of chasing them around with little opportunity to engage. Some crews even resort to playing dirty, with one member jumping in the water to anchor and kill you repeatedly, without ever engaging in cannon battles. It's not exactly fun, and feels like a waste of time for everyone involved.

Another problem is the option to run away and destroy your boat at the end of the map. It's disappointing to engage in a fight, only to have the opposing crew destroy their ship at the edge of the map, taking all their loot with them. While they may lose their loot, you're left with nothing, making it a frustrating experience. It's a shame to see this happening so often, with crews destroying their ship just to prevent others from getting their loot.

Despite these issues, Sea of Thieves is a game that captures the essence of being a pirate. The graphics are fantastic, with sailing under the northern lights or just before nightfall providing a breathtaking experience. The story, however, could use a bit more effort. There's a lot of potential for more in-depth storytelling, and it feels like a missed opportunity.

To improve the game, it would be great to see PVE zones where crews can't kill you, giving new players a chance to have a better experience. Rather than gamers asking for a private server for people to play on, this would be a great start. It would also be useful to have a countdown for being in battle, to stop other crews from baiting you into combat just to flee into PVE zones at the last minute.

Overall, Sea of Thieves is a fun game that's worth checking out. While there are some sour apples in the community, there are also plenty of nice and chill players who make the game enjoyable. If you're new to the game, I would still recommend giving it a try, despite its flaws.

137344147.review:
Great *IDEA* of a game. In my opinion, the game has some potential but lacks in the basic multiplayer features department. The ability to have a server selection or a list of players currently in the server is missing. The game has three types of players: The hackers, The try-hards and the newbies. The problem with this, unlike in other multiplayer games, is that if you're new to the game, a level 1000 4 person galleon can and will destroy your sloop in seconds and steal all your hard earned loot. I was expecting to have some skill based servers but there is no such thing! 

Even worse, the game desperately needs PvE or at least some private lobbies or even skill based lobbies. But no, instead the devs decided to announce that they give no f's about PvE and they have black-listed any and all posts about the PvE situation. Reddit has also been affected. With any posts titled with "cheating" or "PvE" or "toxic community" simply being removed by the moderators. This is fueling the sweats and the cheaters ways of doing things. The steam discussions have also been censored to black-list any "PvE" mentions.

Now, to the topic of the toxic community... Any mention of this is also censored. What I did notice, is that while the community is the worst I have ever encountered, nobody seems to be saying anything about it. You can fact check this yourself, look it up, reddit, steam discussions, f'ing twitter. No mention of any toxicity. And if there is some mention, it is likely not viewed by many people, as somehow, the mods and admins censor these kinds of posts.

I realize that this is a MP game and that the thrill about it is the constant feel of danger, but damn is the cheating rampant. From instantly destroying your masts, to cannonball aimbot, to auto repair of ship hulls, to one-shot any guns, to even boarding out of thin air. How can a MP game not have any anti-cheat or reporting system??? It's dumbfounding that the game has progressed this far.

This is my two cents on the game and the community. Do not buy this game unless you are intent on PvP and getting your ship sunk a lot. If you do buy it, good luck.

Also, small addition to the review, I tried posting on Reddit about the horrible things I mentioned earlier. The post was uploaded, immediately removed, and then the account was banned from the server. No warning, no nothing. Straight ban, with no way to appeal or report the mods. This is getting out of hand. i hope somebody does something about this because this is unnaceptable amounts of censorship for no purpose.

136185833.review:
Before I bought this on steam, I used to play on the Windows Version and even earlier on xbox under the username AquaStingray346. I was so early that I remember when the ship's grog barrel had a limit.

I still remember my first time playing Sea of Thieves. I must have been thirteen at the time, and I didn't realise that I was accepted into the Alpha program until the very last day I could play. My parents were out that night, so I convinced my sister to let me stay up until midnight so I could play. I had a blast just sailing around and digging up treasure on my own. When the betas came around, I remember playing them from the second I got back to school to the second I went to bed. When the game finally came out, a time where closed crews didn't exist and where forts took 3 hours to respawn, I remember I went fort hopping with random people I found on looking for group. I remember when the megalodon event happened which required 5 separate people to summon, and so for the first time I saw crews working together, with 5+ ships all huddled round shark bait cove. I remember making friends from those looking for group posts, and eventually joining a community called the BRN where I sailed daily, and met so many great people. I have years worth of great memories of people from just this game alone. Sadly, as I burned out and stopped playing, and the years went by I lost contact with most of those I used to play with, but I will forever be grateful to Sea of Thieves for everything it has done for me. It has sparked my love for multiplayer games which led me to joining a dark rp community, a great foxhole community and later on an amazing Project Winter community, many of who are still my friends to this day.

This doesn't mean to say that this game doesn't have problems, it actually has so many and I will never stop complaining about them, but if you are looking for an amazing multiplayer game, hop in and do some pvp. The pve gets old fast, and so do the quests, so start sailing and fight and I promise, you will get some great memories too!

135378378.review: Sea of Thieves is an exciting adventure game about pirates that I have been playing for 154 hours and I can't get enough of it. This game offers countless opportunities for pirate life, from searching for treasures to battles with other ships.[hr][/hr]One of the biggest advantages of the game is its graphics. The ocean looks amazing, and the design of the ships allows you to enjoy every detail. But the gameplay is the main focus of the game. In Sea of Thieves, every member of the team plays an important role, and good cooperation can be crucial in battles with other ships or in the search for treasures.[hr][/hr]The game also has various missions that can be completed in single player or together with friends. These missions provide opportunities for character development, obtaining new items, and experiencing new adventures. Additionally, the weather conditions play a significant role in the game, making each game unique.[hr][/hr]Overall, Sea of Thieves is a great game for those who love pirate adventures and sharing them with friends. The game has numerous opportunities for character and pirate team development. And as a player, I can say that the 154 hours spent in Sea of Thieves were incredibly exciting and unforgettable.

135145698.review:
Met a player called Hater Sebastian who used racist slang, insulted myself and my friends, and proceeded to hide on our ship for hours just to get blasted out of existence with one shot from a blunderbuss, accomplishing absolutely nothing.

10/10 game, blunderbuss is goated with the swaws.

To give a more serious review though, the game itself is great. The ocean's utterly gorgeous, and sailing can be pretty peaceful. There's no real limit to the silliness and chaos you can get up to, except where other players are concerned. The PvP system as it stands at the time I'm posting this is 50 shades of terrible, and it always has been. That's added to how utterly toxic and outright miserable most of the player base seems to be - I've been playing this game for years and I can count on one hand the number of truly friendly encounters I've had in game. Most players shoot on sight and are only out to ruin your day, they don't care if you have loot aboard, and always ignore alliance offers. Considering we're playing a pirate game centered around finding loot & making as much bank as possible, that seems mighty idiotic. There needs to be more in place to balance things out, as the game is tipped heavily in favor of the more toxic play styles. I'd honestly give the game a solid 8/10, because it's not the game that's bad. It's the community that's an absolute dumpster fire.

I know it won't happen, given Rare seems to exclusively cater to the PvP crowd, but PvE servers would be lovely to see. It'd allow for a more laid back, relaxing sailing experience, less stressful and all around more enjoyable for those looking for a less intensive session, and for those who like to listen to Audiobooks and the like while they play. I'd even take it if they established it with only 50% of the usual rewards for PvE encounters, I'd just like to have the option to sail without the risk of a bunch of troglodytes attacking everyone on sight just for the hell of it.

You can do adventures solo and with people, and still enjoy the game, though I recommend players to play with friends. Yes, this game based of cosmetics, but the point of them is self-expression. You can flex on people with skins, and that's the whole point, people start to respect you (or the opposite). I would recommend this game for people who not only want to have fun, but for those who want to evolve in gaming community (from being a pacifist to learning new ways of gaming).

133407686.review:
To start off, this could be heavily biased as I am a big fan of the Golden Age of Piracy and the Age of Sail in general. This is game is really good. The sailing system is simplistic enough to make it enjoyable, but also somewhat realistic when it comes to how waves and winds affect your vessel. The story's good overall, the gameplay loop is also fun, though some factions can be more boring than others (looking at you, Merchant Alliance, personally I don't have a problem with sailing in a circle around the map and paying attention to demands and supply, but it can be boring for most I think).

Now, a warning. There's a lot of "pirate" pirates out there. A lot of people come into this game expecting to be an adventuring rogue. Which is fine, by the way, and I do that too. However, you HAVE to be able to fend off other players if they decide to attack, which eventually someone will. This involves a bit of "Generational Trauma" as well, as a lot of these currently 'Toxic Reapers' were once the victims of last generation's 'Toxic Reapers'. I guess it kind of is by design by the Devs. To be honest this game is best played with a friend, I think.

There are "Alliance Servers" where they all work together to farm gold and such, but as a lot of players say about these servers, you don't really learn how to stand up for yourself that way. Unlike some other players, I don't regard Alliance players as lesser, it's simply their way of finding enjoyment in this game, and that's totally fine. Too much rules and regulations for my liking though, some of these servers.

I have some hope for future addition to the game; bounty systems, more factions, privateering and so on. Hopefully these things get added in the seasons to come.

Fair wind and calm seas to whoever choose to sail the Sea of Thieves.

132504826.review:
If you're interested in sailing around the world with friends, I guess it's fun. 

Unfortunately, If you're into PvP, the new "arena" mode is infested with hackers, A majority of matches involve hackers: either people beaming you under the ocean, using "ship restore" commands to instantly raise their masts or hilarious amounts of speedhacking. If you doubt me, just google "Sea of Thieves hacks". You'll be surprised. Or maybe you won't, but meh. 

The cheaters used to be less of a problem in the beginning of the game, but it's gotten worse. Consistently one in three matches is a hacker, it's almost unplayable. Adding onto this are the horrible matchmaking times (~often well over 45 minutes), hitreg and a plethora of other issues turn what is at its core a fun PvPvE experience into an almost unplayable mess.

Don't buy if you're interested in PvP, at least until they fix a few of the issues plaguing the game; most importantly, the cheaters.

132495184.review:
Sea of Thieves is a thrilling, immersive experience that transports players to a fantastical world filled with treasure, adventure, and danger. From the moment you set foot on your first pirate ship, you'll be transported to a world of high seas battles, dangerous creatures, and daring adventures. The game's stunning graphics and immersive sound design create an incredibly realistic and detailed world, making it feel as if you're actually setting sail on the open sea.

One of the game's greatest strengths is its multiplayer gameplay. Whether you're playing with friends or with players from around the world, the game's social elements are an integral part of the experience. Sailing the seas with a crew of friends is an absolute blast, and the game's co-op mechanics ensure that everyone has a role to play and is able to contribute to the success of your voyages.

However, the game is not without its flaws. The game's progression system can feel grindy at times, and there is a lack of direction for players who are new to the game. But despite these drawbacks, the game's overall charm, beauty and excitement make it an enjoyable experience.

In conclusion, Sea of Thieves is a must-play for fans of pirate games and anyone looking for a unique and exciting multiplayer experience. Its immersive world, stunning graphics, and social gameplay make it one of the most engaging games available on the market today. If you're looking for a pirate adventure that will keep you coming back for more, then set sail with Sea of Thieves!

132158044.review:
[i] Can Steam add a "meh" or "sort of" option? [/i]
[hr][/hr]
First things first, this game is a Sandbox. You 100% make your own fun sailing around (most likely with friends because the solo experience in this game is less than ideal) doing whatever fits your fancy, be it showing off your new PirateFashion(TM), doing voyages, Tall Tales, the Hourglass of Fate (or fighting without it, both are viable), or role-playing, the fun in SoT comes from the interactions with other players. If that isn't your cup of grog, you will NOT like this game.
But NO ONE can deny that the atmosphere is so unique. The artstyle (which may take some getting used to for some), the GLORIOUS music (can you tell I like the music?), the different regions (except the Wilds, eff that place), the slight ambient music (again, the music), the different fashion designs and player expression, it all blends together beautifully. So while SoT definitely has it's shortcomings and the... pretty bad advertising of what this game actually is, chances are, if you've stuck around for a year or something, you're sticking with it to the end. And with any sandbox game, you make your own fun.

Cheers, pirate.

130852178.review:
A good game, but highly unstable.

Let's start with the good. The gameplay loop is pretty simple. Load up your ship and your crew, pick an emissary, sail to your objectives, turn in for money. Rinse and repeat ad nauseam. The teamwork is fun when you get an experienced crew, and the combat feels "beefy". the weapons feel like they have some real weight to them, and they have a high skill ceiling. Finding loot is easy, but keeping it away from other players is the hard part.

Now for the negatives. The biggest issue is with stability. I had to drop my graphics to minimum to avoid constant crashes. The networking is terrible, and I've never seen my ping below triple digits for any significant period. The voice chat, which is arguably the most important feature in such a fast-paced, team-oriented game, is riddled with bugs that make it unusable. My mic sounds fine over discord and when I test it, but in game it sounds like I am under water. My friend's mic was fine one day, and stopped working entirely the next day despite hearing each other clearly over discord.

Overall it's a fun game, and being able to play cross-platform is nice. However, I expected much more from a software company with such legendary status as Rareware. This feels like a pre-release late beta that still needs polish, not a full-fledged game ready for launch. It's a lot of fun that needs a lot of work.

6.5/10

129686268.review:
[Subjective Opinion]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics with their slightly cartoon-like touch but
still very very good looking are really stunning.
Especially in clear weather, the colour of the water is a
beautiful cyan-turquoise. The same goes for the night
sky. The enemies with their various models and
representations are also a real eye-catcher.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The story is long and definitely captivating. Playing it
with freinds is definitely fun and offers more than 40
hours of gameplay (personal record). However, there
are also some extra quests that can extend the fun a
lot.
According to "howlongtobeat.com" you can even get
up to 680 hours of play if you complete ALL the
quests.

[h3]Multiplayer[/h3]
Whether alone, together with friends or with complete
strangers, Sea of Thieves definitely offers a lot of fun
and with the multiplayer the whole thing comes to a
whole other level. Exciting ship battles with friends
against other players, or various missions and forts, the
game offers what it promises, if not even more.

[h4]Conclusion[/h4]
Personally, I would recommend this game to anyone
who is interested in seafaring, cool, long and gripping
storylines and lots of fun.

129439716.review:
The only bad thing I have to say about this game is that it has some potential to be more than it is.
As a veteran of PvP survival games, this sometimes feels a bit casual, but, make no mistake, the PvP is intense and gratifying.
The PvE content can get a bit repetitive pretty fast if you have a lot of free time on your hands, but generally speaking, by the time it feels repetitive, they are likely to release a content update.

One important thing - This game as a solo is hard mode. Playing with a crew is almost a must.

129418157.review:
Much like other open-world multiplayer games, it will have it's share of bugs, hacks, and cheats that you will rarely see, but much of the game is an absolute blast when I play with my friends, be it one or three of them, and we have hours of fun doing merchant runs, hoarder vaults, or just dicking about doing anything we really want. Even sometimes screwing around and doing "reverse reaper" fun, like boarding someone else's docked ship with a loaded supply crate and just leaving it on their capstan, because fun is fun, and as long as you are having it, the game is a great experience. Sure, sometimes you end up outplayed, sunk, and have to start over, but often times (especially recently with the 2022 winter sale happening) players who are either new and still learning, or just looking to have fun. It is nice to spend a little time and teach them the ropes and some more advanced tactics, and then see them put it into practice. Not even 24 hours back, our crew found a brand new (under 1 hour) player who was looting barrels on an island without a supply crate, he didn't know any better. We gave him an empty, showed him how to stock it, and even dropped a spare supply loaded with cannonballs before leaving him on his way while we do more captain voyages for rep building. Is this always going to happen? No. But when it does, it reminds you that games are worth playing, because not everyone is out to kill you all the time. Stay sailing, my brothers and sisters on the sea, because there is plunder a plenty for us all, and sharing in the experience is just that - an experience.

TL;DR version - I would recommend this game if you like open world and you are willing to learn new things from defeat, rather than get upset you don't get instant gratification, but if that is your style, then this may not be the game for you.

~ Tama (PewPewMFers ingame, captain of The Oily Herringbone, and The Flying Sardine)

129280112.review:
The game is super fun I’ve been playing since release and you can see how much time and passion the devs have, all new “dlc” in the game is free and treated like a regular update, people say it gets old but most of those reviewers haven’t played recently. They’ve added story based quests known as tall tales and recently have started a second story in the tall tales. There is also extensive lore.  You can fish or hunt animals, kill the Kraken, fight skeleton ships, or kill the Megalodon. You can explore regions such as the shores of plenty a caribbean like place, the wilds a more stormy and darker version of the shores of plenty, the ancient isles a old region of the map with extensive lore and huge islands, the devil’s roar- a fiery tempered place full of volcanoes and earthquakes, and finally if you do the last tall tale you can have access to the lucrative shores of gold the biggest island in the game with huge chunks of lore and a lush environment filled with deadly traps, a skeleton lore known as the GOLD HOARDER a wicked skeleton held together by gold and lust for riches, and as the mighty pirate lore would say A GREAT BIG PILE OF TREASURE! There are also pets in the game but those cost money or if you play the game for a while skeletons might show up that carry this elusive currency known as ancient coins which buy you pets. If pvp is what you want head over to the arena where you and other ships compete for treasure and get into constant battles. They’ve also added a tutorial known as maiden voyage for new players which (if the search hard enough and do some challenges) can give you some gold doubloons(used to buy from the bilge rats) and some ship cosmetics. There are also fun challenges in the game giving by the bilge rats who are wild and carefree like sit in thrones made of bones, shoot skeletons carrying gunpowder, find Easter eggs, and carry chests of rage. So a fun game that has recently had huge leaps in terms of content honestly would suggest everyone pay the devs obviously have a huge passion for this.

Underrated gem from Xbox 

8/10

Review at 15.8 hours:

Great game. Sailing is fun, Combat is fun. Voyages are more fun by yourself, but world events and PVP is better with friends. But either way it is an amazing game to play with your friends. 8/10 Would recomend.

Review at 167.8 hours:

Amazing game. Compared to everything else, voyages are not very fun by yourself or with friends. However combat is still very fun. World events are fun to do by yourself or with friends. PVP is hard, annoying, and just not fun when you start playing. However when you accept the fact that PVP is an essential part of the game, it gets very fun and exciting. Hourglass PVP introduced in season 8 is a great way to get better at it. I'm by no means good at PVP but i have gotten way better at it and I no longer run from every ship I see. 

In short, great game. Buy it if you like pirates and playing with friends, you will have a lot of fun.

8.5/10 Would recommend

127591464.review:
A game that's actually relaxing and has something for everyone, from PvE, to PvP, to puzzles and story, to simply...fishing.
It delivers in ways you can only understand once you actually play it. It's not at all a niche pirate game. You would enjoy it too.

Graphics and gameplay are amazing, community is great, and the work the devs put in is definitely noticeable. Every update they bring something cool that fills a different fantasy. Keep up the good work, devs!

Game is not P2W and will never be, as stated by Rare. But, cosmetics are a thing, but in no way do they give you the upper hand. They're just very good looking. 

The only downside might be that it's slightly grindy, but that is if you wish to be a completionist. You never run out of things to do in Sea of Thieves.

10/10 game.

126592928.review:
Very solid game, very beautiful world, enjoyable sailing mechanics, puzzle solving, and world events.

Unfortunately, if you want to make progress, you either have to be intensely focused on pvp, or you will suffer for your crimes of wanting to have fun. This includes leaving people to sit on the boat and keep an eye out for other players, forced to do nothing while everyone else has fun and enjoys the content, because the moment you leave to join them, you will get attacked, and sunk before you can get back to the ship. The "excitement" that comes out of the constant risk of being attacked by other players quickly turns to stress and anxiety when you realize any attempts to avoid pvp will result in you just sailing aimlessly for hours while ships chase you. Because pvp players will chase you for literally hours just to attack you, whether there's loot or not. No one wants to spend hours collecting things just to have them all stolen last minute by someone who logged on 10 minutes ago and decided to choose violence.

The game exists in a bad spot right now, and while there will surely be tons of people saying "Git gud" or "That's just part of the game, don't whine about it", these are generally the people who have thousands of hours in the game and are far more experienced than you. The reason they say this is because without you there for them to attack and downright harass, they have to go against actually competent crews, and then they have a risk of losing, and they dislike that. The PVP players get rewards for sinking PVE players, and stealing their shit, but the PVE players get nothing from sinking PVP players, who just loaded their ship up with materials for fighting and no loot. This is the imbalance in Sea of Thieves. The reason the devs won't add PVE or private servers is because all the people who do content and enjoy the game casually will go to them, and no longer have to worry about the assholes griefing them to no end. When they do this, the PVP players will have no one to play with but each other, and when they aren't able to pubstomp every solo slooper they come across, they'll get bored and stop playing.

The game is heavily advertised as "living your best pirate life" and experiencing adventure, finding treasure, fighting battles on the sea, yadda yadda, but what they don't describe to you is the paranoia that comes with just existing in this game. It's advertised as PvPvE, mixing both, and the devs will say "Oh, but if we take away the pvp, then you won't have the fascinating feeling of wonder about that ship on the horizon! Will they be friendly? Will they be hostile? You'll never know until you get close to them and find out!"

I'll save you the trouble. They're hostile. We've had literally one ship that didn't immediately bombard us while we were doing an event, and after talking with them, we learned they were pretty much in the same boat. They wanted to play the events, but were tired of pvp jagoffs ruining their good time. This is not a PvPvE game. This is a PVP game, and anyone who says otherwise is lying to get you to play it so they can take your shit. 

If you wanna do an event, you can, but the moment you're done with it, that reaper galleon is gonna come out from the nearby isle, destroy you, and take all your things, because they don't want to play the game, they just want to get the rewards. What's that, you took the time to fight a whole fort of skeletons and beat the boss, and you just wanna have your rewards for a grueling session of combat? That sucks, because the athena's chest in there is too valuable for literally anyone to give up, so you'll likely be sunk before you even get the vault open.

There will of course be people arguing against this review. "If you don't wanna fight the person chasing you, scuttle and go to a different server." "Git gud, and then you won't have to run" "It's just part of the experience, don't whine so much"

As I said, these are the people who have played for far longer, and have no qualms about finding a fresh faced little slooper, all excited and ready to go on his adventure on the sea of thieves, sinking him, and shouting at him over the mic that he needs to go kill himself for being a trash person and a trash player. These are not the kind of people you want to pander to, because they are the kind that will kill the community for the game, slowly but surely, until no one remains, and the game that had decent potential to it, dies with it.

I cannot recommend Sea of Thieves until the devs finally add a safe area for PVE players to just enjoy the game, because no one wants to have to go treasure hunting and be constantly looking around like a paranoid lunatic to make sure they aren't about to have their ship sunk while they're solving a puzzle. Do better, Rare.

A very fun game with a cartoonish pirate theme. The community is mostly friendly (although the bad apples of the community can be pretty toxic 💀), and with the new Season, finding other players to fight has never been easier (since the time of Arena mode anyways)!

This game is probably the most unique pirate game you'll find, featuring different types of content, however this game is targeted toward a adventuring type of Audience, and if you don't enjoy the PvE content at all, then you probably won't find much fun in this game... with the exception of the new Hourglass mechanic, allowing you to PvP matchmake.

The staff for Rare are extremely helpful, and easy-going! Or at least, their Community Managers are, haven't met the devs in a casual setting since they're not in the Discord.

Potassium heals everything, and you can also shoot yourself out of a cannon. ;)

10/10

Lots of fun, especially with friends.

Game world is amazing and getting even better with each update, but there are a few things that could be improved.

If combat design doesn't bother you, the game is really worth getting into but again, only with friends.

Happy sailing!

125596255.review:
Sailing from point A to point B may as well be a loading screen, however you can't treat it like one because you have to both maintain sail angle and ship heading and watch for other player's ships. If you don't have good wind, you'll be waiting a long time for your boat to make the trip, and boy it's boring.
You also shouldn't care about your loot or you aren't gonna have a good time. Almost every play session ends with by being sunk and losing the past couple hours worth of stuff. (unless you sell after every little mission, which means more sailing back and forth, which is both boring and very time consuming)
The player base is unbelievably toxic (expect to be taunted by the crew that sank you in your messages fairly often, or invited to a party to be cussed out)  You will see some racist pet names, and hear some slurs on the ferry, sometimes through the megaphone too.
If before you give up on the game, by some miracle, you get good enough on your own to be able defend yourself, and you haven't grown a brain tumor from all the malignant trash talk, you'll start to care more about loot and unlocking cosmetics, and as a result your experience will get worse and worse overtime. (you WILL be sunk with loot, and more and more HOURS will be spent with NOTHING to show for it) 
Or you won't and you'll stick with default skins, in which case there's no reason to keep playing unless you have friends who play, you like to RP, or you're REALLY into pvp.  
Overall, it is not a bad game, I've had my fair share of fun times with friends and (rarely) randoms, but the general toxicity and the ease with which you can lose hours of progress make it a no unless you have a strong guide and a solid mental state.

125463651.review:
[b] Have been playing for quite a while, as you can see, and can say this game is really fun and definitely worth the money if you can get it for 25 euros or less. Even better if you have friends to start playing with. [/b]

The water physics is astounding; the graphics is simple, yet great and detailed; everything that happens for the first time is fun and startling, such as your first random PVE encounter or your first storm; it has a lot of PVE and PVP as well, making it perfect for everyone; new updates every few months always add something to do or to unlock and if you look at the developers' plan, there still is a lot of content that will be added in the future; also, there is a story, a lore, which i cannot tell you about simply because there are so many things you can do in the game that i didn't even finish the second chapter yet (I spent 400+ hours just fooling around with my friends)!

Sometimes you might get a bug while logging in or loading something which is caused by a sync issue between your Steam account and the Microsoft one (you need it to play the game), but you can easily fix that with the guides on Rare website. 

That said, about the gameplay: the game itself is fairly easy on beginners as long as you don't encounter some sweaty PVP lords, and even if you meet them in the server, you can still start a new adventure and have fun again. You don't necessarily need to be competitive.
However, there are some bugs, but they are those kind of bugs that can give you and your friends a good laugh when they happen. SoT is a bit grindy if you aim to unlock all achievements, can't lie about that, but that's definitely not needed to enjoy the game as you own every piece of equipment since the start. Every unlockable is just for looks. It might get a bit repetitive in the long run, but after not playing it for a while, you will certainly miss it and will want to sail again.
It's an awesome game to play with friends, but you can play it alone and still have a lot of fun, in my opinion. Maybe you can even get to make some friends along the way. It might be a bit tricky at first but it will still be really enjoyable and once you master the art of the "solo sloop" you will get everyone's respect (surely mine) and your name will mean fear in all the Sea of ​​Thieves.

Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. 124449003.review:
The thrill of experiencing the life of a pirate at sea couldn't come any better than this game. 
This game has overwhelming amount of content and things to do for a group of friends, or a couple too.
If you're unsure of getting this game, please read on as these are the stuff I wish I knew earlier.

Players can enjoy this game solo but if you need a crew. you can join a public one or have someone join you, So you don't have to travel alone, if you do want to go by yourself,  You can do so privately anyway. But the real fun is when the adventure is shared with others.  

At the start, you begin in the world at one of the many outposts to visit. Here you meet factions that have certain themes around making gold in the game. Gold hoarders are classic pirates we see in media stereotypes, Get a treasure map, search for gold and loot and bring it back to get your reward. Order of a Souls are a group dedicated to the PvE section of the game, Slaying skeletons, taking down spectral pirate ships and hunting down evil ghouls and there is also the Merchant Alliance, which is all about travelling across the seas making deliveries to certain npcs, just gotta be careful with dealing with the good. Bring it in best condition to maintain the best income.  And then if you want to live truly like a pirate, You join the Reapers Bones. A group of pirates who hunt down anyone and everyone, even themselves and make profit in the taking down of other ships at sea and their loot. 

If thats not your thing, thats fine. You can simply go where ever the sails take you or where ever you want and explore the world. There are over 70+ Locations to visit and there is so much to discover, Any loot you find? Take it back and sell it to make gold. The gold you use in the game can be used to purchase cosmetics for your self, your boat and even all your equipment
. There is currently no "Buy to win" items so everything is purely cosmetic. However, if you can't be bother doing all the grinding? You can purchase coins with real money to buy unique cosmetics that help you stand out from others. But it needs to be mentioned that there are some cosmetics that you simply cannot buy, you have to earn them. 

Grinding is enjoyable and it doesn't have to be such a grind either. There's special commitments you can make to factions where you become an emissary and during this time, you raise a flag on your boat stating to others you are working for this faction. The benefits of this is all context related items and jobs for the faction grant you extra gold. The more work you do under the flag, the more bonuses you get. Great to commit to if you have a hour or two free and want to have a big impact in the game. Catch is, The more stuff you have on your ship, the more you have to lose! So make sure if you're going to do this, make sure you sell what you find and know when enough is enough, otherwise some nasty reapers are going to visit you and take full advantage of your hard work. Its a classic risk vs reward and fortune only favours the brave!

If you want something with a bit of structure and backstory? There's a section know as Tall Tales, these missions are a selection of stories that you and others can play to earn some gold as well as uncover the stories in sea of thieves. You will travel around the world and visit many locations as well as engage in various puzzles and riddles too. These are great with friends and they sometimes feel a bit like the old school 90s games which as you all know, I really love. 

Unfortunately, the game does have a good handful of bad eggs, some players will straight up go out of their way to give you grief, destroy your ship for no reason other than their own entertainment. Trolls some would say, but you are always able to fight back and there's so many ways to fight enemies that you and your crew will most likely work something out when it occurs, You win some, you lose some. In a game full of pirates and a sea of thieves, You know what you're signing up for. So be prepared. 

But the best part of this game? The moments and stories it creates for you to share with your friends and keep forever in your memories. 

Every. Time. You play...  

Because , Yes the seas can be cruel with trolls, monsters of the deep and unfortunate weather conditions but when you meet friendly players who are happy form an alliance and share loot, sit and have a chat about anything while fishing or get totally drunk in a tavern and play shanties while throwing up on each other. These moments of fun and glory is what will stay with you when you finish. For all the horrible moments that can occur, you will easily outweigh them with the great moments this game consistently creates 

Sunrises on clear weather, finding that epic treasure in a vault, laughing with randoms on the server, Catching a trophy fish, Slaying that Kraken, Revenge on a reapers faction, showing off your new clothes, Cooking a shark to perfection, playing the entire 1812 overture with cannons. What have I missed? I'm not sure but in this game. You will create your own. 

Do what you want cause a pirate is free and you can feel that in Sea of thieves. The complete package of a Pirate PvPvE
I've currently got 110+ Hours and I cant wait to throw in more.  Craziest thing was I had this game in my library at the end of 2021 and never touched it. Boy, do I regret not playing this earlier.

123934317.review:
Really awesome game, perfect for co-op groups of 2-4. It definitely takes some practice to get good and master all of the ship movement and the combat mechanics. The main sense of progression comes from your crew developing better strategies and mastering the combat. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
PvP ship combat is the best part of the game, by far. Which is a good sign for a pirate game. The game caters to PvP and PvE players although PvE seems to get a lot more love from the updates. Unfortunately they removed the Arena without providing any sort of alternative. My pitch for a good replacement is to let players pick the 'density' of their server. High density servers (more player ships) would get a loot multiplier but obviously come with higher risks. 

As it stands, players are thrown onto a pretty big map with 3-4 other player ships. There are several mechanics you can use to find other players but it is pretty common for other players to flee (which is fine, part of the game) meaning that it can take time to find an engaging PvP fight. For PvP inclined players expect to spend a lot of time chasing and a lot of time sinking ships not paying attention. But when you do find another ship looking for a fight, it's worth it. Fighting another skilled crew ship-to-ship is one of the best, most exciting co-op experiences you'll find. I just wish it happened more often.

Land combat is pretty rough. The movement is fine, the weapons are okay, but they are missing some obvious QoL things that make many of the land-based boss fights tedious. The biggest issue is that there are bosses that take 2-3 players 15+ minutes to kill and there is absolutely no progress indicator. No health bar, no visible damage to the boss, etc.

[b]Progression[/b]
The progression is lacking. I understand not wanting to give ships with 100+ hours some massive advantage over new players but it seems like there is a lot of middle ground between that and what they have which is basically just cosmetic progression. That being said, their cosmetics (esp. the premium ones) are beautiful. Their art department is fantastic. 

[b]Graphics[/b]
Game looks amazing. The graphics are really really good, the water looks incredible. It is pretty well optimized, I was getting a steady 50-60 frames running a 6-year old RX 560 and even with the graphics settings turned down the game looks great.

After playing for over 1,000 hours, i can say that this is another one of the best games I've ever played. the graphics, environment, mechanics, and story are great and its very fun to play with friends when you have a couple hours to kill. you also have a lot of choice when it comes to what you want to do out there. weather you want to duke it out and steal people's treasure, or peacefully fish for hours on end, there is a little something for everyone in this game, and i would recommend this game to anyone who loves adventure. However, there are some things you should know if you are considering buying this game:
1. this is a very PVP-focused game. you will get sunk, killed, and get your loot stolen sometimes. so don't be discouraged if these things happen to you.
2. Always anticipate a fight. you shouldn't think that everyone is going to be friends with you and recruit you into their alliance, but you shouldn't think that people are going to hunt you down to the ends of the map either. Put simply, be wary of your surroundings and others in them. you never know who you're going to face on the seas.

142323297.review:
This is one of those instances I wish I could post a neutral review. But, alas, my view of the game skews more negative than positive. So here we are.

It's a tricky thing to articulate. As to why I feel more negative. Is Sea of Thieves a good game? Arguably, yes. But if you are like me, it's one of those games that flips constantly between being the best experience of your day, or the worst. And the reason for that, is other people.

Before I get into any of this, because I know already there'll be people getting their feathers ruffled and preparing a slew of "It's Sea of Thieves, no Sea of Friends". Look over the store page. Look at the trailers. Look at ALL the promotional material for the game. How much of it is focused on PvP? The two minute trailer that plays automatically on steam as of (18/07/2023) has three 1-2 second clips of ships vaguely firing on one another. The entire rest of the trailer is dedicated to voyages, quests, and crossover content. You see the Gold Hoarder themselves, skeletons, megalodons, and so on. But you don't see PvP.

How is this relevant? You might ask? Because I feel like I have been miss-sold on the game. I was promised a fun pirate adventure, I saw battles against skeletons and krakens, raiding temples and vaults for treasure, having fun with friends. I was not informed, however, that all of this would be interrupted frequently, by the large number of players that would spend their time spawn-camping your ship and screaming racial epithets.

Sea of Thieves, to me, doesn't create the fun, adventurous atmosphere I would associate with a game set to the theme of the Gold Age of Piracy. It creates an atmosphere of constant stress. And this atmosphere promotes a "Shoot first, ask later" type of paranoia between all players. I've sailed the seas for just shy of two hundred hours. And in that time. I've had maybe one, or two positive encounters with another crew. This, in Rare's mind, makes all the other negative instances worth enduring. The idea of chasing those elusive and surprising moments where another crew raises a mug rather than a rifle. I don't think this is worth the cost.

Rare has no intention of allowing people to customise how they play. It's a "You play by our rules or not at all" mindset. You are required to engage with open PvP. And if another player decides they're going to attack you. There's nothing you can do about it beyond either fight, or quit. I tend to opt for the latter, myself. I'm only here to fight skeletons and dig up treasure with my buddies. Not scrape against the emaciated PvP Lords that have forgotten what sunlight is during their 48 hour binge session, chugging Mountain Dew like a fish in water.

If you can tolerate all of the above, there's a fun game in here. Buried beneath the sludge of toxicity. If you don't mind spending a few hours digging up treasure, only to lose all of it through a chance encounter with an extremely experienced player, you might find some fun. I for one can mostly look past it all. But that's because I never particularly cared for the loot. I play for the fun of sailing. If, however, you're the type to get too attached to your loot, or absolutely hate the idea of your time being wasted in any capacity what-so-ever, then give this game a hard pass.

EDIT (21/07/2023)

I see this argument floating around a lot, on the forums, on the subreddit, and in the comments of this review. So let me address it.

People often say that without forced PvP loot would have "no meaning". This is daft. Loot is already "meaningless" because it can only be used for cosmetic items. All handing in loot does for you, is give you a little bit of permanence between sessions. (The only thing that doesn't get reset when you log out, is your currency and reputation). But this "meaninglessness" doesn't make it not worth doing. Otherwise I'd not have invested near 200 hours in the game.

And it's not like you can ONLY lose loot to other players. If you're not stocked well, you can still sink to PvE encounters, most likely losing all of your goodies.

129575839.review:
An interesting game that is forced to walk to plank with bad hit registration, not to mention an array of bugs and exploits that are in heavy rotation in normal encounters. Players pick from an assortment of uggo pirates to control as they crew ships and scour islands with an assortment of tools and activities seemingly dumped right out of an abandonware "pirate survival" game, with the same degree of detail you'd expect from a 2-6 person dev team in constant "omg uni finals brb" flux. 

Every pirate tends to be a quantum object in a superposition state of both "here" and "not here" when you aim just about any projectile at them. These have been "known issues" for five years; one of the recent fix ideas was "hitscan weapons" but it doesn't seem like that every rolled out. It is only every manageable when the server you're on has a low population (which is tied to ships, up to 5 per server, with 1-4 crew per ship). I am starting to think that not addressing it is on purpose, as [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] is cross platform, and without the miasma of Schrödinger's hit registration it would be likely that playing with a controller would simply be Eye of Reach fodder. 

Other bugs, like sword lung jump, also regularly get upgraded to "features" since they don't fix them. However, to find out about it, you either have to have someone tell you or have it used against you, since it's not a touted in-game mechanic. Honestly, it feels like some sort of weird ass [i]Battletech[/i] or [i]Warhammer 40K[/i] situation where some generation of devs is trying to service something they did not create and have no idea how to improve.

Ship control and ship-to-ship combat is fun, but it's not like I haven't played [i]Guns of Icarus[/i] before. The ship systems themselves are fine, and repairing the ship definitely works as core bedrock for crewing a ship that takes hits. The main difference from similar games is that there's combat on foot, which is absolutely woeful, seemingly locked in the limbo of mid-2000's game design and in execution. It's almost like having a stable connection is a detriment. The upside is that combat is such a joke you can't really feel like you won or lost... aside from your time, that is. It's hard to be invested in a coinflip sim. The distractions outside combat are scant. Digging up chests trades it's adventurous feel for a bureaucratic "these aren't worth doing" fairly quickly, and otherwise highlights for interacting with the environment boil down to looting containers for things to repair, rearm or heal yourself with. With the fighting itself being joyless, the fun boils down to the equivalent of MMO players that stand in one of the game's capital cities all day: emotes and playing insturments. There is less "game" in [i]Sea of Thieves[/i], both in "ship-to-ship" and "hand-to-hand", than [i]Star Citizen[/i]. Let that sink in.

The main form of "progression" is earning gold by collecting treasure. It's sole purpose is to buy cosmetics. If you don't give a shit how you look, or are satisfied already, there's no purpose. I'm not sure how people can care about their ship sinking when that's all there is to it, especially when there's a cash shop (Pirate Emporium) to buy stuff from. The game purports that it's free to explore, but it's mostly empty without engaging in a bunch of quests to slap skeletons that are also subject to hit reg. My brain stem is unfortunately competently saddled with some additional matter; I stopped playing [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] after realizing that the only thing that made it enjoyable at that point was thinking about other things while playing. 

Can be fun with friends, but what isn't, honestly? The main takeaway is that there's things that are [b]*more*[/b] fun to play, especially if you have friends. The large boss fights are cool, but after the first one you realize there's mostly just PvP left, and if you're looking for that there's more engaging full-loot PvP choices where the loot is more interesting than just refilling your cannons/health. PvP typically boils down to the horrendous on-foot combat. 

It definitely is one of those "could be" games, if progression wasn't just quests/pillaging to buy... cosmetics, the end-game of which is just opening your wallet a second time.

143453549.review:
Rating: 1/10

this is an absolute disaster of a game that manages to be not just bad, but a complete waste of time and money. From the very first moment, it becomes painfully evident that the developers either ran out of ideas or simply didn't care about creating an engaging experience for players.

The most glaring flaw in Repetitive Wasteland is its unimaginable repetitiveness. The game's mechanics are so shallow and one-dimensional that it feels like you're stuck in an endless loop of mind-numbing tasks. Whether you're fighting generic enemies, solving predictable puzzles, or completing monotonous fetch quests, it all boils down to mindless button-mashing without any sense of progression or challenge.

Furthermore, the lack of variety in the game's environments is truly disappointing. You'll be endlessly subjected to the same bland and uninspired landscapes, making you wonder if the developers even bothered to put any effort into level design. Exploring the world feels like a chore, and the desire to uncover hidden secrets quickly fades away when it becomes apparent that there's nothing worth discovering.

The story, if one can even call it that, is a disjointed mess. There's no compelling narrative to drive the gameplay forward, and the characters are as shallow as a puddle after a drizzle. The dialogue is cringe-worthy and adds nothing to the overall experience. It's almost as if the developers attempted to mimic a captivating plot but only managed to produce a laughable imitation.

Graphically, the game is a mixed bag. While some character models and environments might look decent at first glance, the overall presentation lacks polish and feels dated. Poor optimization leads to frame rate drops and bugs that further detract from any enjoyment that could potentially be salvaged.

The audio design is equally subpar, with repetitive sound effects and a forgettable soundtrack that only add to the tedium. It's clear that little effort went into creating an immersive audio experience, leaving players feeling disconnected from the game's world.

In conclusion, Repetitive Wasteland is an absolute disaster that fails on almost every level. Its relentless monotony, lack of originality, and absence of any meaningful storytelling or engaging gameplay make it a complete waste of time and money. There are countless other games out there that deserve your attention, and this one should be avoided at all costs. Save yourself the agony and steer clear of this repetitive nightmare.

133622568.review:
Not being able to opt out of PVP is stupid.

"But it's a game about pirates" is a half-assed, bull**** excuse. It was bull**** when it was trotted out by Blizzard to justify non-consensual PVP in Diablo 2 ("but it's a role-playing game! some people are just role playing as a-holes!") and it's bull**** now.

It's poor game design - it's an entire gameplay mechanic in conflict with the other gameplay mechanics of cooperative PVE quests. Why would you design a game like this? Why would you make all sorts or fun quests and sailing and treasure hunting and fighting ghost ships, and deliberately add in "and other players can and will come in and ruin your fun at any moment"?

You've deliberately designed a game where players are encouraged to prevent other players from experiencing the rest of your game. What was the point in investing all that time and money in creating it, when you also want to prevent players from experiencing it because some other players kill them? Madness!

Extremely frustrating, because the cooperative PVE questing and ship sailing and combat and whatnot are all fun! And there's no bull**** levelling up, you start with all the tools you'll ever have access to, you're just questing for fun and cool outfits. I really love that!

But the game is, really, basically just griefing or getting griefed.

Folks, "but it's pirates!" is a bloody stupid justification when it's also about following treasure maps, getting rescued by mermaids, and fighting ghosties and walking skeletons. It's a fantasy, a fiction. We're not raiding merchant shipping in the Caribbean, here. Ironically, we're not actually doing any piracy here at all.

Anyway, regardless of whether you justify it or not, it's simply not a fun game experience.

140686007.review:
tl;dr: You got my money once, Rare. Well done. It won't happen again.

Every time someone asks me about this game, I regret that I can't recommend it.

I loved playing this with friends back in 2020. The sounds of water crashing against the hull during a storm. Wood creaking and the tension of the rope in your hand as you turn the sails to catch the wind. Playing sea shanties with your mates while you keep an eye on the horizon. Even the bugs were typically more funny than annoying because at the end of the day we were having a good time.

Sea of Thieves is at its best an immersive open world for you and your friends to enjoy and create memories together. That was until we got fed up with being constantly killed and spawn camped by other players. Over and over. The fun was lost in the frustration and we all quit playing. I kept the game in the back of my mind, though. I was hopeful that at some point the devs would listen to the large part of the community who were asking for some sort of PVE mode. One day we would be able to return.

Years later I come back to check on the situation only to find that threads on their official forums which try to discuss the possibility of PVE/Private servers are immediately locked by the moderators. Ask for a higher FOV setting? The thread is locked and you are threatened with a ban if you modify your fov manually. You can't even comment on their official patch notes and update posts on steam. They are all automatically locked.

The devs do not want to hear your experiences or requests. They want to keep to their vision of a 'PVEVP' world. Everyone can choose to follow along or leave. So we left.

I had some great times with my friends on this game, and I'm thankful for that. But, given that the developers refuse to even allow discussion for an option to play the game without the constant fear of being ganked by some twitch streamer on a sloop or a hacker flying through the air... I will consider this a lesson learned to never buy anything from this company ever again.

What's fascinating about Sea of Thieves is that you never know what's going to happen during a game session. In particular, the unpredictability of other players' behaviour adds a lot of variation. Sometimes they will chase you, sometimes they will steer clear of you, and sometimes they will be friendly. The most spectacular element of the game is the waves, which are not only very beautiful, but also such an essential part of sailing. 

[b]Impressives[/b]
[list]
[*]beautiful and highly optimized graphics
[*]the waves
[*]day cycle, fog, storms
[*]music and sound effects
[*]ship appearance customisation options
[*]open world depth with multidimensional reward system
[*]on-going game development
[*]the human sailors are totally unpredictable as opposite to the environment
[/list]

[b]Challenges[/b]
[list]
[*]PvP skill level disparity
[*]long sessions without an option to pause or save
[*]bugs in tell tales and voyages
[*]player respawning process takes sometimes too long that may practically ruin the session
[/list]

[b]Wishes[/b]
[list]
[*]bug fixes
[*]enhanced open crew matchmaking
[*]anti-cheating system
[*]more space for positive player interaction
[*]the log book should not get entries of islands you just pass by
[*]more fish variety
[/list]
