138983587.review:
There's a recipe in this review.

Played this game on and off for years from when it was still in beta on Microsoft Store. I have seen it's ups and its downs. Its toxic player side to it's pirate brothers side. I'm a pirate legend and I do enjoy my adventures with friends. I have enjoyed watching this community grow. So much so that I don't know what else to say, so instead I'll tell you how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy! ~Rab

138476576.review:
Ahoy there, landlubbers! Prepare to set sail on a pirate adventure that's as vast as the open seas and as unpredictable as a drunken sailor. Welcome to Sea of Thieves, the multiplayer pirate paradise that will have you plundering, pillaging, and occasionally questioning your life choices.

In Sea of Thieves, you'll step into the worn boots of a pirate, ready to chart your own course through a beautiful world that feels like it was ripped straight from the pages of a child's storybook. From sandy beaches to sunken shipwrecks, this game is a visual treat that will make you say, "Arr, that be pretty!"

But be warned, mateys, Sea of Thieves is as treacherous as the Kraken's tentacles. The game throws you into a vast open world with little direction, leaving you to figure out the pirate life for yourself. You'll embark on quests, hunt for buried treasure, and engage in fierce ship-to-ship battles. And trust me, it's all fun and games until someone forgets to patch up their ship and finds themselves sinking to the depths of ol' Davy Jones' locker.

One of the joys of Sea of Thieves is the camaraderie that comes with sailing the high seas with your trusty crew. Whether you're sailing on a majestic galleon or manoeuvring a nimble sloop, working together is essential for success. But beware, for treachery and betrayal are as common as a peg-legged pirate.

While the game excels in creating memorable moments with your crew, it can sometimes leave you searching for buried content. Sea of Thieves has been criticised for its lack of variety in quests and activities, which easily becomes a never-ending loop of fetch quests and chest digging.

But fear not, ye scurvy dogs, for Sea of Thieves is constantly expanding with regular updates and new adventures on the horizon. The developers continue to listen to the community and add exciting content, like ghost ships, cursed skeletons, and even fire-breathing sharks. So, keep an eye on the horizon for new plunder to claim.

So, if you're looking for a pirate experience that's more "Yo Ho Ho" than "Walk the Plank," Sea of Thieves might just be the treasure you seek. But remember, the real treasure is the memories you make with your crew, the friendships forged through chaotic cannon fire, and the hilarious mishaps that will have you laughing like a jolly old pirate. Set sail, ye dog, and may the winds guide you to a pirate's life worth living. Yo ho, yo ho, it's a pirate's life for thee!

134849587.review:
Rare's [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] is, if nothing else, a game that is fully committed to being itself.  From the expressive, cartoonish character models to the goofy cannon physics, it's a game that is determined to sell you the pirate fantasy in a child-friendly, [i]Muppets Treasure Island[/i] or [i]Pirates of Dark Water[/i] package.  You go on procedurally-generated piratey adventures, featuring standard piratey setpieces like sunken ships, sea monsters, trade shipping, and going ashore to dig for treasure.  These procedural adventures give you goods that can be sold for gold at port, which can in turn be used to purchase cosmetics (there are no mechanical upgrades).  Rinse and repeat for a piratey good time, yo ho!...

...oh, and lest we forget, this childish pirate game has some of the most ruthless, obligatory, high-skill-ceiling, running PvP battles in video game history, in a decision that is certainly [i]compelling[/i] but is nevertheless kind of [i]mystifying[/i] as to the target audience of [i]Sea of Thieves[/i].

[h1]Who Is This Game For?[/h1]
Beneath the surface of the shallow initial game ("do these six varieties of automatically-repopulating [i]Skyrim[/i] quests, forever"), [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] has a frankly fascinating risk-versus-reward metagame.  This is because all of those salable goods that you generate from questing - which does get boring and samey after a while - can be stolen by other players, leaving you with nothing to show for your time.  This is mandatory and cannot be disabled; you are [b]always[/b] vulnerable to other players' will to violence, and hunting other players is very frequently a more expedient method to riches than grinding PvE content.  If you're playing [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] solo, as you probably will be when you're first getting into this game, you need to be very prepared for every few treasure-hunting outings to end in a crew of several veteran players making you bite the nautical curb.

This incentivizes new players to either burn out or make friends [i]very[/i] quickly, because the best defense against marauding players is a crew of your own players and good core gameplay skills.  Sailing with a crew will allow you to blast through the grindy content faster, and sail your ship better, thus allowing you to make it back to port faster and sell the gold, and so forth, in addition to defending yourself against other, hostile players.  Just as you start to come to grips with not constantly getting drubbed every time you just try to get a little questing in, [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] introduces the Emissary system, which gives you large gold multipliers if you stay out at sea longer without returning and cashing in your winnings, which gives you more opportunities to get killed by other players, die, and lose everything, starting from scratch.  And all the while, the gold prices of the cosmetics get more and [b]more[/b] and [b]MORE[/b] expensive, pushing you towards those riskier plays, pushing you towards flagging as an Emissary when you quest...

...pushing you towards just saying "screw it, enough is enough" and spending your play sessions hunting other players who are doing all the grind for you.

[h1]Sea of Thieves, Beneath the Eyepatch[/h1]

In other words, the core draw of [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] initially [b]appears[/b] to be fun piratey adventure, but once you've spent enough time in its very samey cartoon isles, all of the game systems point you towards one-or-both of two options: an incredibly brutal grind to earn lategame cosmetics, or becoming the genocidal PvP sweatlords that mad-dogged you to death in the early game.  And, despite the silly cartoon exterior, as a vicious naval warfare sim it [b]works[/b], in large part [b]because[/b] of the push-and-pull of the game's lackluster questing and its perverse currency incentives.  Since the game was first released, players have begged Rare for a PvE-only mode where you can just do nautical-themed radial quests forever, but near the end of my time with [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] I came to the realization that to do so would be to ruin what makes [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] special.  What animates the PvE adventures is the [i]knowledge[/i] that at any time a gang of players could come in and ruin your day, and even when other players [i]aren't[/i] around, the risk of their presence creates a kind of soft timer.  The shifting nature of its sea combat, where you might be in the middle of fighting a PvE kraken and suddenly get nailed by a player's cannonball, or even be on the other side of that lopsided ambush, adds the endless replayability that comes with a "human element" to a samey, grindy experience.

This may sound like i'm damning it with faint praise, but [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] is a PvP game with just enough variety of peaceful options to keep it evergreen, and although that means it's certainly not a game for everyone, or even most people, it sticks the landing in a way that few other PvE/PvP hybrid titles do with such style and aplomb.

Just don't come to it expecting a stress-free experience, because [i]Sea of Thieves[/i] is white-knuckle the whole way, land lubber.

131982748.review:
Fun, immersive, and a joy to play on one side, and irritating on the other. Rare's golden goose of new players has led to a stigma and prioritization of PVE and its content. Not a bad thing, but when PVE is clearly prioritized on one side for monetization, rather than split 50/50 with PVP, issues arise on the other side. Hourglass is perfect content for the PVP niche, but, following 5 years, no real anti-cheat, or anything has been developed to combat cheaters. Cheater's have been on the rise, and Rare has done nothing. They went as far as to release a reporting system to where you can report offensive names, but not the main problem of cheating. Serving a big F-U to players.

Either way, stigma's within the community following Rare's lack of initiative arose, and PVE players simply, to this day, ignore the problem as why would they? Cheater's aren't a problem in PVE SOT, but PVP, Cheater's are abundant and with PVP being such a low niche in the game, there's no real way to fairly represent a quater of the player base, not when most of well known, respected, and knowledgeable people have been banned either unfairly, or for the use of 120 FOV, which is considered cheating because of its third party application to the game's set FOV of 90.

Even past the glaring issues of Rare's golden goose's, and Rare's lack of updates on cheater's, Sea of Thieves is built on an old, outdated engine, which refuses to be upgraded because of SOT's partnership with X-Box. This of course causes problems such as D-sync, poor performance in some areas, laggy terrain and sea's, and the most apparent, Hit-Reg, which has plagued the game for years, and still remains a constant issue. Hit-Reg essentially boils down to your Bullets, cannonballs, and or any type of projectile not registering with the server, meaning you did no damage towards your target. A controversial topic that has been addressed and somewhat fixed, but still remains constant due to the poor foundation which this game is run on.

Here's to the closure of Rare's partnership with X-Box, and the betterment of the game.

130143613.review:
This is arguably the best pirate game out there, given it's amazing graphics, engaging gameplay, and committed developer team. I have played more than 500 hours of this game as I write this review, and I can positively say that I enjoy almost every aspect of this game as it evolves throughout the years. But why? Why would you play this game?

Before I continue, it should be known that this game is best played with friends or at least other people, as the game is more challenging solo. While it takes some getting used to, flying solo is not an impossible task if you are buying the game for yourself and can provide some pretty valuable experience for survival on the seas. I have probably played 150 if not more hours solo in this game and I can say that it is possible to manage your own ship solo, it just takes a hefty amount of multi-tasking. If you still need a crew to play with, the game will provide an open queue to allow players to play with random pirates across the seas if needed.

The first thing to note about this game is the title: "Sea of Thieves." This game is a high-risk, high-reward game which allows for constant thievery and betrayal across the ocean. It is especially important to remember that that all loot found on the seas is not rightfully yours until you cash it in, which you'll find is a common misconception in this game. Just because you have loot on your ship doesn't mean it's yours, as you'll quickly learn that everybody wants a piece of that glittering bounty stashed on your ship. This will be important as you start out in this game, as it is a few years old and there will be players better than you whom you will come into contact with eventually. This means: you will sink. Sinking or losing a battle is natural in this game, and it comes with the experience. I've lost countless battles on my adventures and lost countless amounts of gold to other players, but it builds experience and in turn helps you become a more feared ship on the seas.

Without spoiling too many of the things you should discover on your own, here are some things to know about the game as you take your first steps:
1. The developers themselves have stated that this game is a shared pvp/pve world, meaning contact with other players is mostly inevitable. Almost everything you do takes place in this sandbox so you will most likely need to defend yourself and your ship.
2. This game revolves around cosmetics. This game is not a pay to win game, as almost everything can be earned in-game via in-game currency (gold) and through unlocking achievements and commendations (in-game achievements). Meaning most clothing and ship cosmetics come from your in-game earnings rather than your real wallet.
3. There are numerous story missions (tall tales) for those who want to play a more guided experience and have fun uncovering the mysteries and lore of the world of the sea of thieves. 
4. Want to get straight into pvp battle? There is a queue for that too! Just check the hourglass on your ship's captain table.
5. The developers constantly update this game as to provide players with a fresh experience. There are frequent seasons that each bring new mechanics and aspects to the game, each bringing a free 100 level pass as well. This game evolves on a regular basis, and the devs love this game to death.

In the end, every session in this game is an adventure. With the numerous amounts of things to do on the open seas, every session will be different and will be a new story to tell. Who knows? One day you could be digging up treasure on the smallest of islands, another day you could be defending your ship from the almighty kraken, or maybe you spend some time solving puzzles in the ancient ruins from a long-lost past (They could all happen in one session too!). The choice is yours. It all comes down to experience, so the more you play and discover, the more fun you'll have making a name for yourself on the seas. You will meet lots of people, fights lots of enemies, and sink many times, but that my friend, is all part of the adventure. 

Thanks for reading.

127230610.review:
So it is with a good deal of confidence that I can say; "Sea of Thieves easily provides one of the most unique gaming experiences in recent years." to my friends, but it does not mean I would recommend them this game either. Despite the amount of hours I have invested into SoT already- I feel like my opinion as a gamer matters just as much as anyone else's when I speak about what I do NOT like about Sea of Thieves.

The concept, mechanics, graphics, and overall functionality of the game are -fantastic-, there is little other titles out today that are going to provide a consistent sensation of exploration and creative enjoyment entirely based on the actions you decide as a player like SoT does. 

However, before I continue, I shall politely warn this is where all of the more "Hardcore players" can stop reading as this next bit reflects some of my own personal experiences within Sea of Thieves.

I completely dislike the aspect of PvP in Sea of Thieves, as it leaves a foul taste in my mouth that prevents me from playing more consistently and daily for that matter. It simply doesn't feel rewarding to me, even if I end up being victorious. I totally understand -why- it is in the game, but by allowing any player to make any choice they wish, you can imagine how a complete stranger on the internet is going to treat another stranger with some confidence. I have over 250 hours in sailing the seas, fishing for Battlegills and Stormtails, riding the waves to chase the sun, even repelling giant Sea-Monster attacks to protect my loot, yet, regrettably I have only been in a single instance of jolly cooperation with a total stranger within my entire playtime. That one instance was only caused by me calling out a TTVer while he was streaming my ship being destroyed, and I pretended to recognize him just to get a ceasefire.

Would I recommend SoT to a casual player or my other friends? No, especially with Season 8 being my final nail. This game fits a certain niche for those who don't mind playing with such a punishing risk vs reward system that also has one of the biggest in-game grindfests I've witnessed. On top of all this it hurts me to see all the people, like myself, who desire for PvE-only servers so that we can enjoy the game we paid for. As much as I would want to keep sailing the seas, unlocking its secrets, cosmetics, curses, and playing the game with my friends who already do; the paranoia of being engaged by other anti-player friendly individuals heavily outweighs my sense of enjoyment every time I consider reinstalling.

I wouldn't ask for the Developers to change Sea of Thieves even more for the few of us who struggle to enjoy something we'd really want to. But we are out here, just in other games.

126730018.review: Grumpy Merchants - A short story by Chicken.                                                                                      Merchant life is a laid back one for sure.  Most days are spent cleaning up wrecks of previous failed merchants, or running errands for those too lazy to do it themselves.   This particular day I was catching snakes in the wild to sell for a small profit. Looking for the last Black Scaled Snake needed, I hear an explosion - a keg.  Certain my snakes had all been reduced to ashes, I ran to my ship and see the culprit himself. He too was dressed as the very weapon he used to try and ruin my day. As the only one to not to make it out alive, the man quickly returned to the ferry.  Luckily, snakes are immortal and they made it out alive, allowing me to finish my commendation.  I then made it my SOLE.LIFE.MISSION. to bring an end and ruin the entire career of the crew who tried to take the lives of my snakes and my boat.  I knew exactly who they were, too. A crew running FOTD but a few squares away. I detach the rowboat and immediately start sailing in their direction. The plan was simple. Sink them. Steal the life-changing chest of legends! Certain they had me sunk from a single keg, they recklessly began to loot, without even watching the horizon. Foolish mistake. Perhaps the last mistake they'll live to make----   And it was. One-blunder to the back of the head, the harpoonist was the first to fall. One Blunder to the next, trying to climb the ladder and aid his fallen crewmate. respawn time was more than long enough to secure a nearby keg, and bring it aboard. lighting the keg I could hear a third top deck. He immediately runs below to extinguish the fuse and prevent catastrophe, but it was far too late, Karma had already struck. Mere moments later the ship was no more. and neither was the crew. No amount of gold was more valuable than the lives I stole from them, but I still helped myself to a few trophies.     The Merchant life is laid back for sure, but we'll fight anyone who intends to disrupt our course in anyway. So I encourage you, sailor, keep it that way.  Next time you see that emissary flag on the horizon, sail away. Lest we see you first.

142337515.review:
Eh.

I had some good memories with this game, you can see the hours. It's not the worst. But Sea of Thieves suffers from a crisis of direction.

This is a game with a fanbase that overwhelmingly loves PvE and grinding. You can't swing a stick in any community for this game without hitting someone complaining about getting sunk by another player. There was once a matchmade PVP skirmish mode that was deactivated for lack of traffic -- and the traffic that was there would, every match (I kid you not), park their boats and go fight each other with the profoundly monotonous melee/gun combat.

I'm one of the people that a lot of reviewers here are gonna call "griefers." I once loved a little airship-to-airship combat game you might have heard of called Guns of Icarus Online, and at first my enjoyment of SoT was carried by its parallels to that once-awesome game with SoT's open-world twist. I loved player combat, I loved sinking ships, I loved stealing and fencing other player's loot, just as I'm sure others loved doing it to me and my friends whenever we were feeling less pvp-inclined. Pitched battles between two competent crews were incredible affairs that sprung up organically and felt like a truly epic high-stakes experience.

But as time went on, and Rare kept shrugging at the part of the fanbase who loved PVP, pumping out more and more and more pve content to keep the most possible fans happy and retained, all the best PVPers left and all the best SOT players kept playing PVE content that gets progressively more isolated and instanced. All this leads to an environment where the most piracy you do will either be against people too new or scared to fight back. The capable players are all doing the 4th part of some scripted quest chain off in their own special segment of the game where nobody can see or hurt them. Landlubbers.

I stopped playing SoT a long time ago and am really just leaving this here because I'm so disappointed every time I see new news about it in my feed. Always new PVE events. If you want to sail and do treasure hunts and fetch quests and lengthy multi-quest chains, and occasionally get sunk by people wishing they were playing a different game, then I guess you might have fun on the sea of thieves. The only thing that could entice me and my friends back is the reintroduction of accessible pvp and players that actually want to play it, and I have a feeling we'll all be long condemned to Davy Jones' Locker before Rare/Microsoft ever consider it.

125849045.review:
While there's a ton of potential for a great game, and even plenty of satisfying ways to enjoy yourself with Sea of Thieves, the gameplay itself doesn't feel like it's building towards that end. Instead, there's layer after layer of achievements, gold, the secondary "gold", actual cash, faction influence, unlockables, titles, faction ranks, and whatever else keeps flashing on my screen. From the perspective of a new player who isn't looking to make a full time job out of a game, this was not for me.

As you're playing the game, you're bombarded relentlessly with so many achievements that you're not even sure what's worth keeping track of or where to find the results. There's categories upon categories of things to track, but I honestly have no idea how to navigate them because most of them are purely decorative. I'll go into the menu trying to find more information about my mission only to end up scrolling past pets and seasonal events. You'll be trying to read a comment in one corner while notifications blip away in the top left, bottom center, and top right simultaneously. Displacing each other in their fight to win your attention. It feels like I've got a slot machine running on my screen.

I'm personally not very keen on the idea of the modern multiplayer mechanic tropes that invade every MMO. I don't want to study a wiki or be present when the game releases in order to experience a fresh new world. You won't ever feel like you're just starting out, because you'll see a thousand locked items and quest buttons and maxed players everywhere you go. There's no humble store selling a stack of wood and a few apples. The whole game from beginning to end is presented to you as soon as you land. As a new player it's overwhelming and comes across as flat.

Even the basic tools you're given are ridiculously presented. Here's a sword and here's a banana, great! Oh, and here's thirteen different instruments you'll never need and half a dozen minor tools without explanation, all of which receive equal priority in your baffling control scheme. Controls are poorly layered on keyboard, feeling almost arbitrary. Scrolling works for your weapons, which strangely don't appear in the quick menu, and the dedicated inventory has almost no use. The quest menu appears more keen on telling you about seasonal unlocks and generic faction relations than your actual mission. Worst of all, there are at least three different buttons used as a back button: E, Escape, or X. Controls are clunky and tedious to memorize, making them frustrating to deploy in a hurry.

Meanwhile the actual game is buried behind those relentless notifications and customization features. Searching out, digging up, hauling and defending treasure is fun, though unloading is pretty boring. Managing the anchor, sails, wheel, and repairs of the ship is extremely satisfying. Ship on ship battles is likewise pretty great if everyone's into it. The world looks great and has all the right elements.

But, again, there's a thick layer of not-so-great on top of that. You're introduced to characters at the start of the game who very quickly lose all personality, becoming cash registers with the same cheap jokes on repeat, leaving you, the player, as the only living thing in the entire town. You're introduced to resources, yet will be disappointed to find that nothing is saved between sessions--not your ship's goods or your inventory--and all those things you stockpiled were meaningless. You can carry so few things that even the stockpiling itself is annoying. Everywhere you go you find barrels full of seemingly useful resources, the same ones that appear in the hold of your ship. Surely some extra fruit and boards will improve your stores, right? Wrong. There's no admission of this either, you'll just realize they're worthless after a few hours and never bother after that. They're resources you can't sell, can't carry in bulk, can't use more than one at a time, can find literally anywhere, disappear at the end of the day anyway, and have minimal impact on your experience. Why even have resources that have no rarity, persistence, or significance? Once you realize those things are worthless you stop exploring islands with the same excitement or interest. It's just more junk you can't keep or use. Get the treasure and move on. Grind.

Armor and weapons don't have any upgrades at all that I can see, just expensive customization. So much customization. And everything is part of a set, too, so you'll gravitate towards unoriginal clones rather than something that feels special to you.You either look like a new player, or you're a glowing dread pirate. Same health, same damage.

Sea of Thieves chose to expand its collectibles library and multiplayer mechanics rather than cleaning up and working through some of its missing base elements. Resources without value, NPCs without depth, menus upon menus, notifications without end, mandatory optional equipment, and a world presented all at once like an amazing, glorious burp.

138276955.review:
I can not recommend this game for a multitude of problems,


:Cheaters.

:game breaking bugs and glitches.

:and lack of content, or good content that is walled behind something tedious.

The first problem I have is cheaters, I Often run Into cheaters no-matter how hard I try to do content to avoid them.
Me and my Friend play this game nearly daily, we both enjoy the fort events such as Fort Of Fortune, or Fort Of The Damned, We often get in the game looking for these events, but when we do we are often punished. There have been times where we get there and the loot is just not there because there are hacks that can steal loot from uncompleted world events that nearly take 30 minutes, Imagine playing 30 minutes, just to find an empty room.Another problem we have is we also like P.v.P but the hourglass P.v.P is riddled with cheaters and there is nothing you can do unless you are very skilled to go against them, This is very annoying because the skeleton and ghost curse (That turns your character into the respective skeleton or ghost) are locked behind a game mode that is riddled with cheaters.


One of the other big problems with  the game is constant game breaking bugs, that are confusing and detrimental, Lets take an example, Just tonight me and my Friend were in a hourglass P.V.P fight and we had a good spot, We  were circling around the enemy loading cannons into them and my game decided the grab the sail angle changer while i was all the way at the front of the ladder looking at the steering wheel of our sloop. Another example from yesterday, I was on a galleon with four friends and we ran into a very talented brigantine, that kept knocking our masts over, and a multitude of times i was repairing the mast and it started to auto fall over again, (I don't think this is intended) we made sure not to have anyone on it holding the up or down key we had the mast partially fixed and it re-fell every time before it got fixed. 

Another problem we have run into in this game is that there is not enough content, the only very rewarding content is the fort events, and the hourglass pvp (If you can win) We either need multiple world events at a time or other "Rewarding" things to do or else it is very easy to lose interest





Good thing about this game though is it hold to the pirate way your loot can be stolen while you are grinding it, or the opposite, you can sale the seven seas, do cool story quests with captain jack sparrow, unlock pirate legend and have new things to grind for, and you can really have fun with friends as long as you avoid all the negative things I commented.

So for these reasons I can not recommend the game. but If you do not mind playing around the bugs and cheater this game is a spot on pirate game.

135864759.review:
Summarized in one sentence, [b]Sea of Thieves is a game about making others have a bad time so you can have a good time. [/b] 

Mindcrushingly flawed design in a modern multiplayer game.
The game is not intended for solo, as every activity is slower and places you at risk.
The game is not good with randoms, as they can sabotage your experience with zero consequences. There are no tools for dealing with them, except voting them into jail - where they still take a player spot from your crew, receiving normal gold and progress from sold loot. This is also assuming they don't vote you in first.
No benefits to being friendly or neutral, as the game rewards hostile and scummy behavior. Using lowly strategies to secure loot is always more safe & effective than sharing or making an alliance. No reason to befriend players as it's potentially riskier than trying to battle them.
The UI was made for controllers, and while functional, navigating the menus and tabs on PC becomes abrasive. Searching for a specific commendation is looking for a needle in a haystack.
Voyage types, which serve as 'quests', are heavily unbalanced despite scaling with levels. Some give vastly greater rewards with minimal time investment while being risk-free. 
The sessions are too long. 1 hour is fast with small rewards, typical sessions extend 3+ hours.
The servers are unstable with occasional hitreg issues, physics issues, choppy players at high speeds and sold loot progress not registering.
The best-looking cosmetics are either locked behind FOMO or  €30 ship sets.
There is no anti-cheat... in a world PvP game.

The longer you play, the easier it's to see massive design and server issues with the game.
Now, you may re-read the first sentence of the review.

145238881.review:
For what it's worth, behind Sea of Thieve's beautiful visuals, and goofy nature, behind the fact that you can control a somewhat functional sail ship, and behind all the nice additions they have put into this game, the main two factors overshadowed and marred what would have been a good game.

Forced PvP
While some PvP or PvE battles between skellys and other players are fine, forcing everyone to be hostile to you when you are simply trying to complete missions WILL NEVER BE accepted for ANY reason. Forced PvP stunts progress, and makes it a frustrating play for those who do not want their progress stolen by otherwise is a toxic group of players. By defending this failed "feature", you are the problem and the reason why no one plays this game.

Monetization and Very Little Rewards
One may say that a cosmetic-only monetization system is fine. By why are the in-game shop items so expensive? 120,000 gold for one ship skin? Are you nuts? When it takes 80 hours just to pimp out your ship with one set, you know the grind is too hard or the shops are too expensive. Seriously, the forts are easily 8-12,000 gold, and it costs well over 2 million for one set? THE PRICES ARE TOO DAMN HIGH!

For these two factors, I cannot recommend this game, unless you want to have a frustrating time playing it. I recommend Rare to step up their game and make games worthy of their legacy games from the 90s.

Title: Sea of Thieves: A Breathtaking Voyage into the Pirate's Life

Introduction:
Ahoy, matey! Set sail with me as we embark on a thrilling journey into the vast and captivating world of Sea of Thieves. Developed by Rare, this open-world action-adventure game offers a pirate's life like no other. From treacherous seas to hidden treasures and epic ship battles, Sea of Thieves promises an unforgettable experience. So grab your cutlass, raise the anchor, and let's dive into this amazing review!

Graphics and Immersive Environments:
Prepare to be mesmerized by the breathtaking visuals that Sea of Thieves has to offer. The game boasts stunningly realistic water effects, vibrant tropical islands, and dynamic weather systems that will leave you awestruck. Whether you're caught in a tempestuous storm or basking in the golden light of a beautiful sunrise, the attention to detail and art style make every moment feel like a work of art.

Living the Pirate's Life:
Sea of Thieves truly excels in its ability to make you feel like a swashbuckling pirate. You and your crew can set sail on a fully customizable ship, complete with different sail designs, figureheads, and even instruments to serenade your adventures. The cooperative nature of the game encourages teamwork and coordination, whether it's navigating treacherous waters, manning the cannons during heated battles, or searching for buried booty.

Dynamic World and Quests:
No two voyages are ever the same in Sea of Thieves. The game features a dynamic world where you can encounter other players, form alliances, or engage in thrilling ship-to-ship combat. From embarking on perilous quests to locating hidden islands or battling legendary sea monsters, there's always a sense of excitement and discovery around every corner.

Endless Adventures and Progression:
Sea of Thieves offers a vast array of activities to keep you entertained for hours on end. Whether you prefer hunting down skeleton forts, unraveling riddles, or engaging in epic naval combat with other players, there's no shortage of things to do. The game's progression system rewards you with reputation, gold, and exclusive cosmetics as you complete quests and rise through the ranks of the Trading Companies, providing a satisfying sense of accomplishment.

Pirate's Playground:
One of the greatest strengths of Sea of Thieves is its commitment to fostering a vibrant and engaging community. The game actively encourages players to interact, cooperate, and engage in thrilling adventures together. From sharing tales of triumphs and mishaps in taverns to engaging in impromptu sea shanty sessions, the social aspect of the game elevates the experience to new heights.

Constant Updates and Support:
Rare has shown an incredible dedication to the ongoing development of Sea of Thieves. Regular updates bring new content, events, and quality-of-life improvements, ensuring that the game remains fresh and exciting. The developer's engagement with the player community is commendable, with active listening, frequent communication, and a genuine commitment to incorporating player feedback.

Conclusion:
Sea of Thieves is an absolute treasure trove of adventure, camaraderie, and unforgettable moments. With its stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and a world brimming with endless possibilities, it's a must-play for fans of the pirate genre and open-world experiences. So, raise your tankard, rally your crew, and set sail for the high seas—it's time to become a legend in Sea of Thieves!

137252588.review:
Simply put, a great game with an unholy amount of things to do. You can go and dig up treasure from a x-marks the spot map, you can uncover ancient vaults and get as much loot as possible for the gold hoarders, you can go around and take out skeletons and bring their skulls back to the order of souls for secrects to be learned, or run cargo from island to island, or you could find lost shipments for merchant alliance. You could also fish and slay the kraken and one of several megalodon species and turn the meat in. Or, if you think all that grinding is too time consuming, run with the reapers bones, and turn in others stolen loot and emissary flag for coin instead. 

There are several story missons as well, called tall tales for you to play to uncover the lore the game has. From the shores of gold, which tells a massive story, to the pirates life tall tale story about Jack Sparrow. This game has anything that a pirate could wish for. And I didn't even cover cosmetics that you can unlock for your pirate, pet (if you buy one), and your vessel. Save up enough gold and buy your own ship and give it a name of your own to add even more personal touches onto your boat. 

You can play solo, or up to four friends. And the last thing to remember, this is a pirate game after all. Trust no pirate, else that loot you carry could put coin in someone else's pockets.

131860292.review:
The premise of the game is interesting; "Be a pirate & sail about." The way it's handled could be better. The story missions (Mainly Tall Tales) get tedious at times, & multiple require replaying the mission multiple times for completion. Not in a "There are multiple choices/paths" sort of way, but in a "Only a fraction of the needed items for completion spawn per run" or "You must complete this mission X times" sorts of ways. Although there are PvE and PvP encounters, the lack of separation means that at any point whatever you're doing, someone can mess it up for you. Though the number of hackers/exploiters may not be colossal, the lack of decent anti-cheat is disturbing.

Like with any other game, truly the worst part is other players/the community. Yes there are great people; but there are also the kind of people who would burn a barn for "fun".

Do I recommend this game, as it is currently, to people; no. At least, that is, until proper separation for those of us who mind our own business and prefer PvE, for those who lack the basic human decency to realize not everyone wants to PvP. Until proper anti-cheat is implemented. And, until story quests drop multiple clear requirements.

Would rather play "Salt 2"

137291888.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This game is best played with friends. While the tutorial is laggy, the game itself is amazing, and great way to make memories with friends, as each session you never know what it will bring, whether you have a goal in mind or not. There are some low points, as it does have "thieves" in the name, so you can be sunk and have your loot stolen, but it gives back so many more pleasant memories, including when you are the one stealing. It has varying types of game play, from pvp, pve in form of skeleton, ship combat, or just digging up treasure, even the fishing will keep you busy trying to 100% all the related commendations. It's not pay to win either, and while there are paid for cosmetics, you can through time and luck earn them yourself with smart spending, either way, with none of addition content behind a paywall, some paid cosmetics are a small price to pay for this beauty of a live server game.

139687354.review:
This game is NOT chill. Despite it's cartoony aesthetic and interesting premise of sailing a little ship to have adventures, there is also a constant and permanent PvP element that cannot be disabled. Your head has to be constantly on a swivel lest another crew swoop in, sink your ship, and steal the work you've just put hours in to get.

This is what I love about it. I can get attacked at any point. It feels like a fun version of Escape from Tarkov, getting loo, getting supplies, and then making a mad dash to the outpost to cash it in.

PvP is a really multilayered experience of Ship Based and Person Based combat, and that overlaps when boarding other ships, but maintaining the ship itself requires Bailing, Repairing, FireCrew, Helsman, Sails (length and angle), Cannons, and Cannonballs. It's a rewarding feeling when you get it all coming together.

125730348.review:
I love this game, but I can't give it a positive review. Here's Why:

STORY: They exist, but they're not good. The "Tall Tales" are just doing the same things you've been doing, but with long sailing in between. The speaking is very well done, but there was no effort to make it new or engaging, just repeating solo mode with NPCs telling you why you're doing it.

TECHNICAL WORK: I move this up because it's become increasingly problematic. The game seems to run well, considering how demanding it is on your computer, but they've been sacrificing gameplay for new content. Much like Destiny, they're so focused on putting out mini-adventures that no one plays, and microtransactions that only tryhards pay for, that they've slipped on maintaining the actual game you bought. As more Adventures are released, i've faced more and more bugs in normal adventure mode:
OLD BUGS: Slingshotting, projectiles disappearing, enemies teleporting, barrel contents being invisible.
NEW BUGS: can't turn left or right after jumping into water, can't fire myself from cannons, can't load cannons, can't use emotes, can't pick up crates.
Every time a new adventure is released these bugs get worse, and more frequent, which deeply concerns me about the long-term care that will be shown to the playerbase.

REGULATION: In the true spirit of a free pirate game, there is no regulation whatsoever on PVP. In fact they further encouraged it with the Reaper's Bones alliance. Oddly enough, the reapers I meet tend to be silent, or at least polite. How nice :) the unfortunate aspect is the players flying alliance flags who fire without warning (as a pirate might do) while screaming slurs, profanity and insults (typical shut-ins) I'm sure the devs are trying to do what they can, but this is more of a warning that the player base seems to be becoming increasingly toxic and abusive as the game slowly dies, due to the lackluster content.

On a positive note, the game itself is still quite a work of art in terms of realistic sailing mechanics and ship combat. I would only recommend it if you are willing to quit and restart until you find a server that's pretty quiet, or you're a salty bleached ***hole who wants to assert your virtual dominance rather than getting a job.

129164276.review:
Disappointing.

The game promises to be an open world where each player can choose their own path - be whoever you want to be.  If that's what appeals to you, then skip Sea of Thieves.  It is just another MMORPG combat game set in a beautiful world that could have been something special.  Instead, the developers just opted to emphasize combat above all else.  Seamanship doesn't even really matter.

If you just like to game your resources so you can run around attacking other players, and you would like a game that looks cool while you do that, then Sea of Thieves will probably be just fine for you.  But, if you're looking for anything else, you're going to be disappointed.

I don't understand what the developers were thinking.  It's like they built a world rich with sounds and imagery for a really great fantasy pirate vibe but then said, "OK, now how are we going to make a game out of this?"  And, lacking any good ideas, they just said, "Eh, let's just make it another PvP combat fest like every other game and go home.  Coming up with ideas is hard."

It's like they built Fantasyland at Disney World and decided just make it into paintball field.  That's all this is - a paintball match with a gorgeous backdrop.

What a waste ... unless that's what floats your boat.

125195080.review:
If this game had an offline option (not even was offline, just had the option) it would be great.

As is, playing this game has been akin to an abusive relationship, with a game play loop with just enough addictive hooks (like season progress) to keep you coming back even after constantly losing everything to other players that you are on a timer to avoid.

The PvP combat isn't even that well designed either. Boarding from the ladders ends up making the ship combat itself superfluous, since any time spent loading a cannon ball is better spent getting in your enemy's ship, because even with the cursed cannonballs you can do infinitely more damage to an opponent on foot than with heavy artillery. 

The game play incentives mean that there is no benefit beyond risk aversion to choosing not to fight other players. On paper this should make seeing another ship on the horizon a tense encounter, as you both silently weigh your odds of besting your opponent against the treasure you stand to lose should you sink. In practice, however, spotting another ship on the horizon is often an exercise in frustration. Players who want to engage in combat will be frustrated because the ships they see will either flee for fear of losing their loot or outgun them so heavily that its not worth the encounter. Meanwhile, players who just want to enjoy the game's many PvE loops will either become filled with panic upon seeing an enemy ship and immediately disrupt whatever task they actually wanted to do or will slowly die from the background radiation of stress that comes with doing any task that takes you from your ship because, even with a vigilant eye, another player could show up at seemingly any moment to sink your ship and, depending on how long you've been actively avoiding others, waste potentially hours of time and loot collection.

Explicit incentives toward PvP combat beyond just stealing your opponent's loot also means that the game's community naturally biases toward aggressive, toxic players who are often, at best, unsympathetic to players who get sunk in combat they didn't consent to, and at worst actively hostile or dismissive to anyone to anyone unwilling to enthusiastically participate in it.

On the whole, Sea of Thieves is a game made of two disparate experiences awkwardly stapled together. On one hand there is the PvP ship combat that fails to reach its full potential because both the ships and the combat itself are designed around NPC encounters and thus are easily exploited by thematically dissonant tactics. On the other is a perfectly enjoyable pirate themed PvE adventure game with a good variety of tasks and just enough of a story element to not be completely vacuous, which itself is unable to reach its full potential due to the ever present specter of other players interrupting your relaxing sailing experience like a proverbial older brother coming to knock over your hard built sand castle. Neither element as they currently exist fully complement the other, and without a significant revamp to one or the other the game will continue to shamble like the forgotten, hate-riddled prototype of Frankenstein's monster until the servers shut down and the game is rendered unplayable to all but the most committed to video game piracy and preservation.

Also the sniper rifle is worthless in PvP which feels like a personal slight.

134979690.review:
One of the standout features of Sea of Thieves is its gorgeous visuals. The game's art style is colorful, vibrant, and highly detailed, with lush tropical islands, crystal-clear waters, and realistic weather effects. The world is alive with wildlife and other players, giving a sense of immersion that few other games can match.

The gameplay itself is centered around exploration and discovery. Players are encouraged to explore islands, search for treasure, and engage in naval battles with other players. The combat mechanics are simple yet satisfying, with a range of weapons and tools at the player's disposal. The game also offers a range of quests and missions, both solo and co-op, that provide a sense of progression and reward players with new equipment and cosmetics.

One of the key selling points of Sea of Thieves is its multiplayer aspect. Players can form crews with friends or join up with other players online, making it easy to team up and tackle the game's challenges together. The game's mechanics encourage cooperation, with players needing to work together to sail their ship, repair damage, and fend off attacks.

Overall, Sea of Thieves is an exceptional game that offers a unique and engaging multiplayer experience. With its beautiful visuals, exciting gameplay, and strong emphasis on teamwork, it's a game that's sure to appeal to anyone who's ever dreamed of being a pirate.

The game is super fun. If you have friends to play with on this game, then 100% play with them, it is so much more fun playing with friends.
 You can fish or hunt animals, kill krakens, fight skeleton ships, or kill megalodons. You can explore regions such as the shores of plenty a carribean like place
 There are also pets in the game but those cost money. If you play the game for a while skeletons might show up that carry this elusive currency known as ancient coins which buy you pets.
  It can take a while to grind and to become a pirate legend (Pirate Legend is a Title that can be earned in Sea of Thieves) but that what makes it worth in the end, and do not expect the game to have many friendly pirates.
 you will at some point in the game get grieved and you will be left with a heartbroken mess if you had a lot of treasure waiting to be turned in.
 If you just want an easy grindable game, then this isn’t the game for you.
 Overall I recommend this game to players that are looking for some fun and a real adventure.

There is however (somewhat) a lack of content, unless you are the kind of person who can make their own adventures.

With that said my main issue with the game is this;

The developers decision to make certain adventures, events, skins and so forth into limited timed events. It forces you to play the game if you want to get these things, and since many of them require you to perform certain tasks (often several times at different locations) it is just a VERY time consuming game. So either this is your main game or you can miss out of a lot of content

I've had lots of fun playing this game, I really have. I just couldn't keep forcing myself to play even when I wasn't in the mood, just to get things that were there for a limited time.

144458950.review:
I've been playing this game for years. At first, it was fun. The PVP was a lot of fun and was completely under control. I miss arena mode. 
With these most recent seasons, the gameplay has not only gotten worse (with the new pvp included), but the amount of hacking that's allowed on this platform is ridiculous. I'll get to that in a minute. 

Yeah a bunch of new features have been added that could potentially make the game great, but along with that came devs who dont give a single shit when it comes to people ruining the game for others. 
The new PVP that was introduced forces you into an ongoing circle with another player with a chance to lose everything you have including all of your materials. I've spend hours going in circles with a ship that didnt want to fight and it was the most boring interaction I've had in the game. I refused to touch PVP further and just continue doing world events, tall tales etc. 

Then come the hackers. 
Today, I witnessed a sloop take out a galleon, and then approach our ship. They parked a mile away, shot a member out of the canons and although it was nearly impossible for them to approach right away, they spawned on our ship with a keg and blew us up. 
We managed to scramble together and fix our ship. In no less than ten seconds, and without any players near our ship, an athena keg already lit spawned in the center of our ship and nuked us. 
My crew mates managed to get to their ship and were unable to kill them no matter how many hits it took. The members of the sloop also moved around unreasonably fast. 

This isnt the first time this has happened. Players like this make the game incredibly unfun for everyone. I've spent hundreds of dollars on this game and I want my money back. I know I'll never get it, so in return I'll be telling everyone to avoid playing this game. 

I will be uninstalling it. This game isn't fun anymore. Its a matter of who has the better cheat codes at this point. 
Severely disappointed, Rare. 
Never again.

The galleon was hungry for an easy meal, but god bless my lucky stars, the brig too was hungry, only faster. I watched patiently through my spy-glass. Finally, the galleon had no choice but to turn and fight. With all parties occupied, I slipped behind an island and made way for the nearest outpost. That's good seamanship. And the gold hoarders guild paid well that night.

142682590.review: You don't need me to explain why Sea of Thieves is a classic. I'm writing this review to celebrate the recent release of the Legend of Monkey Island update. The update is risky, and I can already hear complaints that it's a boring and unnecessary nostalgia-grab for a handful of boomers, and it is. But it's also a triumphant proof of concept. For those with nostalgia for the original game, this is a transformative reinterpretation and a clear passion project created by genuine fans. The SoT art and game mechanics translate perfectly into the Monkey Island universe, and the family-friendly, 4th-wall-breaking comedy is faithful to the original. It's probably too much to ask for, but a fully realized, slow-paced, puzzle-dense campaign through the Caribbean would be extremely exciting.

123817687.review:
Fun game, but buggy. Invisible players. 

I have fallen through rocks and boulders on islands and other players not in my crew are invisible. Three times so far, I've had invisible players easily board my ship, wreck it through various ways, and kill me without me being able to see them. Typically, its just two shots with a blunderbuss coming out of nowhere.

Grieving is REAL in this game. 
We were fighting an Ashen Lord on an island, when 2 guys in a schooner decided to raid our ship, and blow it up. They could've just taken the treasure, who cares, but they decided to camp the island for 2 hours for treasure worth a mere 5000 gold at best. They didn't fight the boss at all, they just stayed on their ship and harassed us. 

If you want PVP naval combat, you willnt find it on this game. All people do is canon over to your ship, invisibly board it, drop your anchor, set flame to your ship, or keg it. Larger crews will easily overpower you. For no reason, they attack smaller vessels that have very little reward. 

I'd like to see a feature that allows for PVP to be turned off.

128726458.review:
In Sea of Thieves, players take on the role of a pirate and explore a shared open-world environment set in the Caribbean. The game features a wide range of activities for players to engage in, including battling rival pirate crews, solving puzzles, and completing quests for various in-game factions.

One of the standout features of Sea of Thieves is its emphasis on cooperative play, with players working together to operate their ship, defend against enemy attacks, and complete quests. The game also has a strong focus on player choice, allowing players to customize their pirate character and choose their own path through the game.

The visuals in Sea of Thieves are stunning, with a beautiful open-world environment and highly detailed character models. The game's soundtrack is also noteworthy, featuring a mix of original compositions and licensed tracks that fit the game's pirate theme perfectly.

Overall, Sea of Thieves is a highly enjoyable and immersive multiplayer game that is well worth checking out for fans of action-adventure and cooperative play. Its stunning visuals and unique setting make it a standout title in the crowded multiplayer market. If you have the opportunity, I highly recommend giving Sea of Thieves a try.

I'll also use a tactic of loading up a rowboat going behind an island or rock dropping the rowboat leaving my ship sailing on a random course and selling the loot. 

The puzzles and tall tales are amazing which is what I play the game for. I also enjoy the sea fortresses and Treasurys.

I'll sail with the wild Rose cosmetics and try to make a name for myself as that guy who sets his own ship on fire.

144458465.review:
This game is a clustertruck of good quality, high graphics, and great multiplayer, but it is also a double edged sword.

Here's a pros and cons list of Sea of Thieves:

PROS:
- Great multiplayer
- Stunning graphics
- Good voice acting
- Challenging, but fun gameplay

CONS:
- Do NOT play this game by yourself, unless you're doing a Tall Tale.
- Combat is kinda slow with the weapons, given that they take an entirety to reload.
- Some of the Tall Tales tend to be boring, and it sucks to replay the same Tall Tale to get the entire Commendation.
- The fact that you cannot have 5 player crews, and it's capped at 4. Having 5 or more players would be really fun, and trying to manage an even larger ship than the Galleon would be great.

This is my overall review of the game. While I do come across as negative, I still enjoy this game. Although, the only way I can have fun with it is to play with my friends, but I guess that's the point of the game.

I would give this game a solid 7 or 8 out of 10. It's great, but it has some glaring flaws in my eyes.

Was going to leave the detailed version of my review up, but instead find that it would easier to be brief and to the point.

[h1] As a parent talking [/h1]
[list]
[*]This game is sadly an abuse and cheat fiesta, admittedly by the developer and producers.
[*]They are trying hard to get a proverbial tourniquet on it, but it may be...  scratch that... "definitely too late" to save the community at this point. Please Read on.
[*]When they get the hacking/cheating controlled to any reasonable amount, then you have the bullies issues that are in equal numbers. So the kids that have no friends because they are bullies, and are home without parents, finding a place to continue their misbehavior and bully in a game where there are no consequences.
[*]My seven year old son, who was infatuated with the Jack Sparrow® and Pirates of the Caribbean® franchise, could not wait to play. My son never made it out of the tutorial. He was simply trying to learn to command his ship, before being attacked pointlessly and endlessly. Never got upset, kudos to my son, actually laughed the first few times, and attempted to befriend the attackers. Instead racial insults, vulgar language, unprovoked was out of hand. To now allow a new player to experience the mechanics of your game, is beyond pathetic.
[*]Do not allow people to learn to play, is about the saddest and insulting production of a game I have encountered in 30 years in the industry. I have seen most of the good and ugly but this game takes the cake.
[*]Even with waiting a bit, walking away, then returning to inform the attackers that he was new, was accepting of their attacks, the verbal onslaught and vulgar disposition was something I have not seen this bad, continued. When you handle it right, there should be reward and respect. Returned four hours later, literally, still the same nonsense.
[*]The developers and producers have problems galore, but they focus on cheaters and not the whole picture, and refuse to have GM employment. To their credit they have banned over 16000 accounts in June 2023, and it has not made a dent, and it has made this game a non stop feast for abusers sadly, in what was an exciting video and nostalgic happiness turned quickly to complete deflation.

[h1] As a gamer talking [/h1]

Graphics are cool. Theme is really good from the video. The music and animation is very good from the moment my son loaded in. The FPS was terrific.  The art team has done amazing. If you can get past the bullies, abuse and tutorial, you may enjoy it with a team of friends. The community is toxic as anything I have ever seen in 30 years. As I stated, they are trying damage control, but its so massively mismanaged and out of control, its going to take years, and then it will be outdated material.

[h1] For developers [/h1]

Get mass GM help, as a deterrent, with ban capabilities, that are increased with each offense, which can also assist on both issues at the same time. If you cant afford the GM's, then offer protection servers for Solo players, looking to make friends and a team, and a tutorial server for those to learn and get their feet wet for a period of 24 hours, not being attacked except for NPC engagements, when they enter their world servers. Not rocket science.

You have to be really into PvP to like this game. Its essentially a game made for trolls. People just roam around looking for people to kill. Do you want to spend 30 minutes to be someone elses entertainment? Go right ahead. Nevermind that some of the quests are bugged. Got a voyage to deliver cargo to a merchant that doesn't exist anymore. Spent 15 minus sailing here  against the wind because this game makes it so the wind is against you 75% of the time. While im doing this, a random person rides by and destroys my ship for shits and giggles. Every once in awhile Ill get the urge to play after seeing a picture of the sailing, log in, only to be reminded how flawed this game's design is in the long term. Its been bleeding players for awhile now with 2023 being its worse year to date on steam. Issue is that in order for sea of thieves to work, people need to be "farming". Can't have a pirate game when there's nothing to pirate. Well people figured out that they don't want to be someone elses content. To farm for someone elses sake. So they stopped doing that. They either quit like I did or they just roam around looking for things to kill while partaking in no farming of their own. So what happens? Then all those players disappear and goes back to bleeding for another 3-4 months.

129289385.review:
Sea of Thieves is advertised as an exploration adventure game.    This is mostly a patented lie.  Sadly.  

Now before you down load this game, go on youtube and watch how the game is actually played.  This game is Player vs Player battle fest.   Players regularly just walk up to you or your ship and just slaughter you.   The game encourages this behavior, truly encourages it.   

Yes there is adventure.  LOTS of it, but you will always be interuppted to such a degree that you practically have to wage guerilla warfare to actually finish most adventures that are part of the content of the game.   This is as the game is designed,  it is not error, it will remain exactly this for as long as Rare owns the game.

As for Exploration, this is an out and out joke.  The world, even using the in  game "watch" that you have times out that the actual area you a playing in is a mere puddle less than 30 miles by 30 miles square.  You could drop that square mile area into one of America's Great Lakes and never touch the shores of that lake.

Many will liken this Sea of Thieves as a "haven" for Pirates.  I disagree.  This place is a tiny "penal colony" and the Pirate Lord is the warden who controls the way out.   You can't even DIE to get out of this place.  The Ferry Man always sends you back, never ever does he send you ON.

Now to be fair this game is a visual master piece.  I kid you not.  It is a visual master piece.  The Ocean Dynamics is AMAZING.  I have yet to get my mind around the idea that Rare thinks that squarerigged ships can sail dead into a head wind and make progress.  They do in this game, but it is a game "thing" that allows the three different ship types to behave in ways that allow them to escape from each other should they choose to.  But, the learning curve to achieve that skill level is steep.

So visually so gorgeous that even though I have more beefs with this game than any other I have ever played.  I do keep coming back.  But there are days. ...

140303680.review:
If you haven't already, don't bother. SoT suffers from the same toxic community problem as every other online game, either you've been playing from the beginning and know the game inside out or you're going to have a bad time. 
No matchmaking, no dedicated PVE mode, no way to report toxic players, just you, the open seas and whatever try-hard douchebags in need of contact with grass are squeaking into their mics about how bad you are as you sink on your way to the story missions for the fifth time in an afternoon.
Can it be fun? Sure, sometimes.
Is there a lot to do? Absolutely!
Does the game look good? Yes, if you're into that cel-shaded cartoony style.
Are the servers responsive? Absolutely not. Have fun defending yourself against PVPers you can't even see due to the rubberbanding issues.
Is it polished? Cosmetically, sure. I'm sure putting together an open-world game with a huge map full of content is difficult, and the way multiplayer is handled could DESPERATELY use some work, but what made me quit the game for good was a glitch at the end of a story mission that put a necessary quest item out of reach.
Sorry, SoT. There's a lot to see and do here, but you're just not a good game, and the people playing you make things worse.

140826861.review:
I mean it's [i] Sea of Thieves [/i] isn't it? It doesn't have content, you make the content with your friends. If you don't like repeating the same activity with long periods of doing nothing in between getting dunked on by players with three times your playtime, then I can't recommend.

"But it's fun with friends!" This is, quite obviously, a virtue of your friends rather than the game. Any game is fun with friends. Poking a dead dog in the road is hilarious with friends, you know? Or maybe my friends are just weird. I'll keep playing this game even after this review, but the second my friends stop, so will I. May Davy Jones have mercy on the poor souls who play this game solo.

This game is slow paced in moment-to moment gameplay. Painfully slow. You might spend more time sailing across empty, lifeless waters than looking for treasure on islands that all feel the same, or shipwrecks that [i] are [/i] all the same. PvE combat features all the complexity or Cookie Clicker, when all you can do is mash left click against hordes of enemies who are powerless to stop you. There is no dodge mechanic, so ranged AI will just flip a coin to decide if their aimbot locks on to you or not. When shot, you can heal to full in about a tenth of the time it takes them to reload. There are no consequences for death either, although losing your ship does mean [i] another [/i] fifteen minutes of restocking supplies and potentially losing all your loot (not that there is anything to buy other than cosmetics).

Recommending this as a chill game is tough too however, because it can turn around in an instant. The moment you randomly meet another player, the gloves come off. Running around a galleon in 4v4 ship combat is amazing, when everyone is yelling out and laughing it's great. Assigning roles, working together and pulling off a dumb strat feels good and usually rewarding. 

Mostly that's the case. But, a lot of the time, losing might not even be your fault. There's no skill-based matchmaking, so you will either stomp or be stomped 80% of the time, neither of which feel fun. Hitreg in this game is atrocious, and unfortunately it [i] will [/i] decide some fights. Not to mention that the longer you've been on in a session, the more supplies you will have. So sometimes, you might lose a fight before it even starts because the enemy had a ton more wood, or you might win a fight solely because you had like ten overpowered cursed cannonballs. And remember that sinking means more resupplying, losing all your loot and even more waiting!

There are definitely better games to play with friends. Games with deeper and more entertaining mechanics, stories you can care about and hopefully better servers. But I [i] guess [/i] it's fun with friends, for what that's worth. Besides, what other multiplayer pirate game are you going to play? At least this game nails the pirate aspect. It basically bleeds cheap rum and bad facial hair.

137013797.review: Crashes none stop across multiple top of the line systems.

125446605.review:
So I have hundreds of hours on Sea of Thieves (on the Microsoft Store, rebought on Steam when I switched over to Linux), but the only scenario I can recommend buying this game in is if you already have multiple friends who play it. It's a chore to play on your own, and by joining an open crew you are literally handicapping yourself.

The problems with this game are many:

[list]
    [*]Xbox social is as sluggish and clunky as you'd expect a Microsoft product to be
    [*]The game is a buggy mess, and every patch introduces something new. You'll get launched off of platforms, black screen back to your boat, get stuck between rocks and trees, get a hit marker but deal no damage, respawn without clothes, lose wind visuals, lose sound, or any multitude of unique and varied bugs that are so extensive and bizarre you'd think you were accidentally setting off anti-piracy measures.
    [*]New content is almost always a new fort or fleet or other PvE element to fight, and the PvE is truly terrible. Left click to sword, hold left click to sword lunge, left click to shoot, right click to aim down sights, that's it. That's literally it. There's no depth to it, and the big challenges the PvE offers up are either send more enemies, or increase the damage dealt and absorbed by boss type enemies. It's all meant to be means to an end, an obstacle to gate rewards behind and not a thing to be enjoyed in its own right. By design, this creates incentives to drive players to compete over control of the PvE and also the loot earned by completing the PvE, but this is also a problem because...
    [*]The PvP is also very, very bad. While the sail/wind management and repair triage is fun and strategic, combat is over when one crew manages to put one or two holes in an enemy ship, immobilize it with chainshots, anchor balls, or a good board, and then repeatedly spawn kill the enemies before they have any opportunity to fight back so they are unable to come back. And if you do somehow manage to mess up this process, the entirety of the process simply starts back from square one, because you can then repair every bit of damage done to you and go right back to fighting.
    [*]Thanks to the Xbox crossplay, this combat is also extremely lopsided. Also, if you join an open crew, you will learn that every last one of these players are incapable of simply breathing like normal people. If you have an Xbox, you are rotund, annoying, and need to stop inhaling Cheetos and start inhaling corticosteroids. Please go outside and stop joining my crew, I know you're not going to help me manage sails no matter how many times I ask.
    [*]Awful community. Reapers (PvP emissaries) will hunt for sloops docked at islands and sink them without a fight, then run away for an hour the second they face any sort of adversity. It's very rare to meet other crews that don't shoot on sight. Today the galleon of Reapers that ran away from me and my friend accused me of being a p*ssy. They're not wrong, but how could they have known when they were the ones running? They were also terrible at managing their sails, but that's beside the point and not a strike against the game itself.
    [*]Everything takes so long. Want to collect loot? Pick up each individual piece and walk it back to your boat, and if you really want to optimize it you walk it into harpoon range, drop it, and then harpoon each individual piece the rest of the way. Then you get it back to the outpost and do it all in reverse. Want to join a game and go sail? Gather supplies for five to ten minutes, then raise your anchor (takes ages on larger ships, and you might as well retire if you want to do so on an open crew galleon because you are absolutely doing that on your own), then drop your sails, then turn your wheel, then angle the sails. The game doesn't lend itself well to just playing for a few minutes, because you start fresh on resources every time you boot it up. The devs have made efforts to improve this, and things are way better than they used to be, but at a fundamental level the game will always have you waiting on a bar to fill up so you can put something in a cannon, waiting for the entire reload animation to play so you can shoot your gun again, waiting for the sail to move as you dynamically hold down a single button and watch the mast slowly turn, waiting for the door to slowly open, waiting for the next wave to spawn, waiting for your ship to get to the place you're trying to go. It's a game that takes far too much patience for the average person, and if you join enough open crews you'll realize most people are not even patient enough to raise the anchor and move their ship and will simply keep joining crews until they land on a ship that's already done it for them. (This isn't an indictment of me as a person by the way, I've literally spent 45 minutes rowing across the entire map just to sneak up on another ship and blow them up with kegs just to steal two pieces of loot and it was honestly more fun than playing the game like a normal human being).
    [*]Too complicated. I understand the game perfectly fine, but I can't for the life of me figure out what is so hard for people to grasp about playing this game but most just never figure it out. People run around in circles on their own boat, smash into rocks and islands, do nothing when you ask them to help you raise sails, stand on the front end of the boat and look at the islands with a telescope, shoot harpoons at a ship well out of range that they could actually catch if they'd just turn the sails, Google every riddle, refuse to repair their own boats, or do anything for themselves. The community is too fragmented between people who know what they're doing and people who just can't figure out how to engage with it in any sort of way, and now that the game has removed Arena they're all here, sharing the same server, ruining each other's good time.
[/list]

The game's initial luster wears off pretty quickly once you stop being impressed by the best looking water in all of gaming, the expansive world, the nice looking characters, the top-notch aesthetic, the fun shanties, and the sheer thrill of just being a pirate in a pirate world. That's probably a good way to summarize the issue with the game: it looks excellent and seems exciting and everyone knows that they want a game [i]like[/i] this, but the devs will break two things every time they fix one and fundamentally do not understand that no amount of tutorial popups are going to make sense of the game if it doesn't [i]feel[/i] good to operate. Conceptually, Sea of Thieves is the perfect game, but because its issues are tied to its engine and its entire design philosophy, the only real fix for this game is to wait for somebody with the same idea to finally make a better one.
